item.name: 1830: The Game of Railroads and Robber Barons
item.comment:
[b][media=480486]Replayable Episode 3[/media][/b]
[i]Posted: 27 JUN 2024, Rated: 9[/i]
If you're reading this comment, then you know about [family=19]18XX[/family]. You might just be dipping your toe in this pool, in which case I advise you to move along to [i][thing=17405][/thing][/i], and come back when you know how to swim.
[i]1830[/i] is the full experience. Here there be dragons, and barons, and ne'er-do-wells. And a lot of math. Repeated calculations as you re-evaluate routes to see if there is one that can eke out another $10 for your company.
And that's a good point to mention: you have to get used to the idea that you're not the company. You are a raider, looking to milk as much money from it as possible before discarding its rotting husk on some poor, unsuspecting opponent. That may not sound pretty, but you'll play better if you think in these terms.
It's also a long game. Be prepared to play for at least four hours. That's four hours of following noodles through a plate of spaghetti and keeping track of a running total. Of recognizing that if you short a stock here, then you can force your opponent to buy that last green train and open the luxurious world of permanent trains just before you operate your own company.
Against all the other games on BGG, it's a 9. But in the realm of 18XX, it's a 10.

item.name: 1846: The Race for the Midwest
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9/28/15, rated: 9[/i]
Clearly a member of the [family=19]18xx family[/family], [i]1846[/i] is a streamlined entry by [designer=150][/designer]; the same gentleman who brought us [i][thing=28143][/thing][/i]. 18xx games are played in the following sequence: a Stock Round (SR), and then a series of Operating Rounds (OR). In the case of [i]1846[/i] there are two OR's each game round. Play continues in this fashion until the bank runs out of money, or until all players but one have gone bankrupt. In this game, players rarely go bankrupt.
And that actually is one of the reasons why this game is "streamlined:" it is focused more on successfully running trains rather than brutal stock market maneuverings. This belief is supported by the way that new railroad companies are started: it only takes a player purchasing 20% of their stock to open them. As its trains run, the dividends for any unpurchased shares remaining in the company's treasury are paid into the treasury itself. In other words, the company makes money for itself to keep on expanding (building track, buying new trains, or buying "tokens" which you can think of as travel "hubs").
The other interesting mechanism is the way private companies are distributed at the start of the game. You can think of private companies as "special power cards" which influence players' opening strategies, and have an effect through the early and mid games. Most of them (save for one, the Mail Contract) are removed by the end game.
These mechanisms mesh together really well. [i]1846[/i] focuses on what I currently feel are the fun parts of an 18xx game, without all of the dastardly options or punishing environments in other 18xx titles. I'm really enjoying it. With that said, an 18xx game is an acquired taste: they're not for everybody. They're very math-heavy, and long-range planning is required.
For this reason I am docking its score a full point. A "10" should be a perfect game all around. The limited appeal of [i]1846[/i] means it won't be a "go to game" for every group. But if you're curious about 18xx games and want to step up to the plate, then definitely give [i]1946[/i] a try. Especially now that [publisher=52][/publisher] are offering it on a [url=http://www.gmtgames.com/p-554-1846-the-race-to-the-midwest-1846-1935.aspx]P500 list[/url], at a much more reasonable cost.

item.name: 6 nimmt! Jubiläumsedition
item.comment:
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1994[/b]
[i]Posted: 1/5/09, Rated: 7[/i] {2P: 6, 3P: 6, 4P: 7, 5P: 8, 6P: 8, 7P: 8, 8P: 7, 9P: 7, 10P: 6}
[i]6 Nimmt![/i] is another game which I originally learned on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BSW[/url], and had played many times before acquiring a copy (other such games include [i][thing=15512]Diamant[/thing][/i], [i][thing=17240]Verflixxt![/thing][/i], and [i][thing=15818]Heckmeck am Bratwurmeck[/thing][/i]). As such, I was sentimentally attached to the bulls from the German version of the game, as well as saying "Moooo!" whenever a player has to take a row of cards. More on that in a bit.
The game is very straightforward: each player starts with 10 cards in her hand. The goal of each hand is to play all of your cards without taking any points in the process. There are four rows of cards laid out on the table, in ascending order. Each row can have up to five cards in it. If the card you want to play will be the sixth card in the row, then you have to take the previous five cards and say "Moooo!" (it's not an actual rule, but you should do so anyway). Each of those cards you just took has a number of bull icons on it. Your card is then played as the first in a new row. Your score for the round is the total number of bull icons on the cards you collected.
The rules are simple enough, and tell you how to arrange the cards. The frustrating part about this game is when you think you can squeeze a card in under the limit for a particular row, but when everyone reveals their cards, that row fills up before your card is played and you end up having to say "Moooo!" The game is exhilarating when you've resigned yourself to clearing a row in order to play a low card from your hand, and then another player plays a lower one.
With more players, the likelihood that these events occur with greater frequency increases: every card is in play. The game becomes chaotic, as rows will almost certainly shift before all the cards are played. With just a couple of players, the game becomes more strategic, but also less certain: very few cards will be in play. Can you fill a row to the brim, or does your opponent have a card that she can sneak in ahead of you? I find that while the game accommodates a wide number of players, its sweet spot is in the 5 - 7 player range.
[i]6 Nimmt![/i] is a compact game which travels well. I specifically sought out the [i]Jubiläumsedition[/i] for its tin, although its rarity makes me reluctant to actually play the game. It can scale if needed, and is easily taught. That makes it a platoon player which can support just about any collection. Moooo!

item.name: 7 Wonders Duel
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 28 NOV 2022, Rated: 8[/i]
I love civ builders. More accurately, I love the idea of civ builders. Blame [family=4756]Sid Meier[/family].
The actual implementation of them in board games tends to be clunky. It's hard to hit all the right notes when players are responsible for all of the rules enforcement and upkeep, as opposed to the program. Those notes include resource collection, infrastructure, a technology tree, military encounters, and hopefully multiple paths to victory.
[i]7 Wonders Duel[/i] manages to hit all of them. Not all of them are perfect, but well enough to scratch the 2P civ builder itch, and do so in a surprisingly short playing time.
Resource collection is managed by the cards you draft, or by buying missing resources from the bank. There is no way to prevent the other player from getting what they need, but you can make it more costly for them to acquire a specific good from the bank if you can manufacture it yourself. It's not enforced trading between players, but rather a way to wage economic battle.
Progress is managed through three Ages, which provides a clean way to introduce more advanced capabilities as your cities grow. The tech tree isn't there as technologies aren't linked, but some buildings have a "build for free" path if you already own the prerequisite. Close enough, especially for this playing time.
There are three ways to win: military supremacy, scientific supremacy, or else by most points. If you focus on grabbing the military buildings then you may be giving up scientific advancements that will enable your opponent to win instantly. It's an interesting balancing act.
The real meat of the game is in the drafting of cards. Each age has its own layout, alternating between rows of face-up cards, and face-down cards. You cannot turn over a face-down card until the cards that are covering its corner(s) have been taken. This creates delicious tension: do I take a card that will allow my opponent to get a peek at something that might be better? Managing the market is the true centerpiece of the game, and the cards you get feel like they are building your civilization.
Of course, it can't be 7 Wonders without wonders! There is an opening draft of these special cards at the start of the game. You will have your own hand of 4 wonders that can be built. Each one of them confers different benefits. This opening draft turns out to be the second level of the game. Understanding these benefits and integrating them into your market control strategy ends up being another vital piece to playing well.
I really enjoy this game! I wish the technologies were more integrated and linked, but that's to be expected for a 30-minute game. I've also had a play or two where the card layout was simply insurmountable for my opponent. I was able to manage my selections to prevent him from taking something I wanted. I realize that any randomization in a game can come up snake eyes, and ultimately one 30-minute mulligan isn't terrible. This one's a keeper!

item.name: Advance to Boardwalk
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 3/31/08, Rated: 6[/i]
I originally obtained this game back in 1985. I [i]loved[/i] [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i], and to be honest, I still do. The theme was immediately recognizable, so my family picked up a copy. We only played it a couple of times because it wasn't "[i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i]-lite" as we expected. It was a completely different animal, and it didn't click with us. Short note: the fact that it [i]is[/i] different from its progenitor ought to be interesting for those of you who are fanatical [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i]-bashers.
Fast forward some twenty-odd years. I have faint memories of this game, and decide that I want to revisit it. I rescue it from its dusty death in my mother's game cabinet. Lo and behold, it turns out that this game was ahead of its time! There is a ready analogy to [i][thing=199]Manhattan[/thing][/i], a game which was released nine years later. [i]Advance to Boardwalk[/i] is a property control game, where having the most "units" -- I choose to think of them as "floors" -- on a given property equates to ownership of it. Owning the property increases your overall score. A deck of "Fortune" cards can affect player strategy, as these cards can pack a whallop of a punch.
There are a few areas which miss the mark. The amount of revenue a player has to spend on her turn is determined by rolling two dice. Where she can spend it is shown on a special, third die. A player must build at least one unit (floor) on her turn, but it is possible to roll a low number and a color group which do not allow her to do so. Unused revenue in a turn is lost, as there is no form of currency to maintain a balance in between turns. Color groups exist to accommodate the third die, with no benefits being conferred for achieving dominance or a monopoly of a group.
The end result is a quick, light game that feels "Eurogame-ish," but is still very much luck-driven. It is a great gateway to a meatier game like [i][thing=199]Manhattan[/thing][/i]. I believe that [i]Advance to Boardwalk[/i] could be improved with a few, small tweaks. I'm looking forward to more plays, and possibly uncovering those effective variants.

Aggravation
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/1/05, Rated: 3[/i]
Aptly named, [i]Aggravation[/i] is a mindless roll-n-move game. It is an Americanized version of [i][thing=2136]Pachisi[/thing][/i], played with only one die and without the latter game's blockades or safe spots.
"Short cuts" have been added, which are the circled corner positions that lie closest to the center of the board along the standard path. If you land on one, then on your next turn you can move by jumping from short cut to short cut. In this manner, you can circumnavigate the board with a single "6" roll. There is also a "super shortcut" in the exact center of the board, but you have to roll a "1" to exit.
Without the second die, there aren't as many decisions to be made as in [i][thing=2136]Pachisi[/thing][/i]. [i]Aggravation[/i] has some redeeming value in the fact that it can easily be taught to children. But really, don't be that cruel to your kids.

Air Baron
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/15/05, Rated: 5[/i]
Wow, what a brutal experience. There is [i]so[/i] much randomness to this game that solid play just can't account for it all. Let's see here: random payoff draws can feed your stiffest competitor while you starve. You can enter "fare wars" (thus forfeiting your opportunity to earn money) and then get worked over by a randomly-determined turn order. You can achieve dominance of a hub, only to see it vanish quickly in a roll of the dice.
Jumbo jets can be purchased to double the payoffs for specific routes. However, you're more likely to place them on the cheapest (and therefore most vulnerable) routes that you own, to protect them from takeovers. Losing a route can cause you to lose dominance or even control of a hub (most or all of its attached domestic routes). Losing control will cause you to lose market share, which is the primary means towards winning the game. The war can be lost for the want of a nail.
Due to this extreme volatility, the game can take a long time to complete. Still, there is something attractive in its simplicity, which is surprising for an Avalon Hill game. The rules aren't as "fiddly" as many of their other entries. I'm considering adding some house rules to mitigate the randomness, such as bidding for turn order, and adding "phases" à la [i][thing=2651]Power Grid[/thing][/i] that would allow for drawing more payoff counters. I think there could be a fantastic game under the skin, if I can find the time to uncover it.

item.name: Alcatraz: The Scapegoat
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/30/11, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Alcatraz[/i] was the darling of BGG.con for me. A dynamically shifting, asymmetrical cooperative game. I haven't played anything like it, and when played with the right group it was amazing.
The players are inmates, working together to complete their plan of escape. The plan has six elements, labeled A through F. When the plan is complete, the players escape and win.
The catch is that someone is going to be left behind. Each round, someone is elected to be "The Scapegoat." If the other players can assemble a complete set of plan elements between them, then they win and the Scapegoat loses. However, if the Scapegoat possesses a unique element of the completed plan, then the Scapegoat escapes and a different player whose contributions aren't critical (his letters are duplicates) is left behind.
This set-up creates an atmosphere of, "I'll help you by being the Scapegoat if you don't try to duplicate my letters." If you're elected Scapegoat when you're already non-essential, then you do everything in your power to keep the other players from escaping that round. The game is brilliantly full of backstabbing and betrayal. Which means it only works if you're playing with people who like that sort of game. At BGG.con, I spent most of my time playing games with friends from [geekurl=/werewolf]the Werewolf community[/geekurl]. This type of game was just our style, and it was incredibly enjoyable as a result.
While visiting the Funagain store, I heard that this game had been picked up by a U.S. distributor. I'm looking forward to picking it up at my first opportunity!

item.name: Alcatraz: The Scapegoat – Maximum Security
item.wishlistcomment: My interest in this now-hard-to-find expansion still lingers. I enjoyed the base game back in 2011, but I don't think I ever had a chance to get this.

item.name: Alchemists
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9 OCT 17, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: 7, 3P: 9, 4P: 8}
[i]Alchemists[/i] is one of the first "app assisted" games I have played. I love the simple way players can coordinate the initialization of the app and then start to use it to examine outcomes. Even better, there is actually a compelling game here beyond the app-gimmick.
On the surface, this is a very straightforward game: collect ingredients, mix them together, and try to figure out their "natures." Now add in some tougher elements such as selling potions, publishing theories, and the last round display of your alchemical prowess. These are all opportunities to prove you know what you're doing. That money from selling is useful because there are money considerations including buying artifacts! And one-time abilities called "favors." And the competitive nature of space selection is all gated by the opening bid for player order.
In short, there's a lot here beyond just scanning cards with your phone.
When describing the game, each of those mechanics sounds like it was just bolted on. When playing the game, they all melt together and a seamless experience emerges. It has taken me several plays before I finally feel like the deduction algorithms "clicked" in my brain, and even still I loved playing this game.
The only things holding me back from a higher score are the intimidation factor for new players (there's a lot to this game), and how brutal the game can be with respect to action selection. I also suspect that the game doesn't scale down as well. I think it may be best with 3, still great with 4, and not as good with 2. I also fear that the app may one day be abandoned, but it's still working today after nearly 3 years. There's also an analog capability, but then you need a moderator. Play this one while you can!
item.wishlistcomment:
Interesting game that uses an app to check your recipes; too many 'combos' to try to remember, and they may even be randomly generated. I like how some companies are looking to use mobile phones as game accessories.
Finally got a chance to play it during the last night of BGG.con '14. I absolutely loved it, but boy am I bad at this game. I can't wait to try it again.

item.name: Alchemists: The King's Golem
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9 OCT 17, Rated: 9[/i]
I love [i][thing=161970][/thing][/i]. There's something about that game that has always intrigued me, even though I am horrible at it. Until recently, I just couldn't get my head around the "deduction tree:" what results will a pair of ingredients produce? I still had fun using the app and recording results, but any overall strategy other than "I haven't tried these two things before" eluded me. That being the case, an expansion that adds even [i]more[/i] complexities doesn't sound like a Good Thing, right? It turns out that an expansion is exactly what this game needed.
[i]The King's Golem[/i] offers four new modules, and for the most part you can pick and choose what you want to add. You can read about their descriptions on the front page for this expansion. I like to include them all. The first two add variability to player setup and to the first phase of every round. The Royal Encyclopedia offers another venue for publishing your theories. I find it helpful when one of my tests has resulted in the "neutral potion:" I may not be able to publish a theory about one ingredient and only hedge on one color, but I can submit an article to the encyclopedia about ingredients.
Lastly, the eponymous "King's Golem" is a new deduction puzzle that adds fun and more importantly a new deduction mechanism: "Visit the Library." Every ingredient is associated with the Sun or the Moon. By visiting the library, you can effectively cut the number of options for an ingredient's identity in half. Here's the catch: if you do visit the library, the ingredients available for research are randomly selected for you. There's no guarantee you'll get the one you want, but maybe you can still get closer to an answer based upon how it has reacted with other ingredients on previous tests.
All of these additions ended up working very well together. They also reduced the amount of competition for each space on the board (by offering more options). [i][thing=161970][/thing][/i] is a fine game, and a definite improvement over [i][thing=1294][/thing][/i], but it's personality really comes to life when you attempt to animate the King's Golem.

Andromeda
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/12/08, Rated: 8[/i] {3P: 8, 4P: 8, 5P: ???}
[i]Andromeda[/i] has been hanging around on the edge of my radar for quite some time. The comments from my group of "correlated" GeekBuddies weren't stellar enough to launch this game into the "must have" category. However, its recent status of being out-of-print meant that I could not postpone its acquisition any longer. A few mouse clicks later, and UPS delivered its payload to my door.
Now, a little about me: [geekurl=/geeksearch.php?action=search&advsearch=1&objecttype=boardgame&q=&include[designerid]=9&searchown=ON&searchuser=Beowulf]I like Alan R. Moon titles[/geekurl]. I have found them to be colorful, thematic, and easy to teach. [i]Andromeda[/i] is no different: the board is gorgeous, and the rules are straightforward. The theme is a bit hurky jerky: fostering interstellar trade by establishing "economic centers" on the satellites of seven planets in the Andromeda galaxy. I'd prefer something along the lines of space colonization, so that's what I have in mind when I'm playing.
Like [family=17]other games of his[/family], [i]Andromeda[/i] is primarily a set collecting game. This mechanic is well-worn, and needs a little extra push to be interesting. Here, the "push" comes from forced trading: the starting player must trade cards with someone else. Every other player has to offer the same number of cards, even though these cards may not end up being traded with anyone. This forced interaction is the heart of the game. It is slightly reminiscent of the card drafting in [i][thing=25554]Notre Dame[/thing][/i]. It doesn't bother me, but if you prefer having a choice à la [i][thing=13]The Settlers of Catan[/thing][/i], then this aspect of [i]Andromeda[/i] will be grating.
Finally, we get to the Cosmic Puck/Ashtray. I'll sidestep the pseudonym debate, and refer to the game piece by its official name: the Planet Ring. The Ring is the randomizing element that determines whether or not your attempt to establish [-]a colony[/-] an economic center on a satellite will be successful. And this is the one element that will make or break [i]Andromeda[/i] for you. Think of it as [i][thing=30869]Thebes[/thing][/i] in space: you strategize and then execute your plan merely for an [i]attempt[/i] at success. I'm not crazy about this mechanic. I enjoy being rewarded with concrete success after all of my efforts. However, at least with [i]Andromeda[/i] a negative result for me also reduces my opponents' chances for success by removing their "stations" (a.k.a. "wooden cubes") from the planet. The fun of shaking the Ring combined with a beneficial result for failure makes [i]Andromeda[/i] less of a heartbreaker.
Other games offer more complexity than [i]Andromeda[/i]. There is admittedly a lot of luck involved. However, [person=9]Alan R. Moon's[/person] games have a knack for actually making it to the table, and they're fun to play. My family enjoys them, and that fact propels my rating an additional point.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 7[/i]
Here we are three and a half years later, and [i]Andromeda[/i] hasn't seen the table very often. The added propulsion has stalled, and [i]Andromeda[/i] coasts to a "7."

item.name: Ankh: Gods of Egypt – Guardians Set
Ankh: Gods of Egypt – Tomb of Wonders
Anno 1800: The Power of Gold Mini-Expansion
Antike
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 2006[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 12/22/06, Rated: 9[/i]
Ah, honeymoons. They are wondrous, anxious, and exciting. Such is my response after my first few plays of [i]Antike[/i]. But before I wax on about this game, let me tell you a little bit about myself.
I love turn-based, 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) games for the PC. I've logged weeks' worth of time with such titles as [i]Master of Orion[/i], [i]Master of Magic[/i], and of course the [i]Sid Meier's Civilization[/i] series. The complexity of that genre doesn't translate well to a board game: a lot of the "bookkeeping" can get overwhelming if you don't have a computer crunching all of the numbers behind the scenes. Trying to approximate a computer's behavior at the gaming table takes up a lot of time, and usually a ton of fiddly rules.
[i]Antike[/i] is the long-awaited exception that proves the rule. It is so incredibly streamlined, that it captures the essence of a 4X PC game without inflicting horrendous calculations or player down-time.
The much-discussed [i]rondel[/i] is the engine at the heart of this game. Simply put, it shows the eight available actions. In a fit of elegance, each player can move up to three spaces clockwise around the rondel for free each turn. She can choose to go further, but she must pay resources to do so. This balance between resources and actions is exquisite. The rondel develops a personality of its own. You can envision the epochs of your civilization as they pass. Certain periods are flush for resources (Iron and Gold, which are close to each other), while others are more militant (Maneuver and Arming). Gauging your opponent's position within the rondel cycle is also important. Did he just pass "Arming?" If so, then he is ripe for an attack!
There is no random element to this game, which is highly attractive to me. The outcome of a battle is perfectly predictable; there are no dice involved. The simplicity of the mechanics permits players to focus on strategy and diplomacy. This game can be highly social, and an astute player will avail herself of those options. Each side is identical in its abilities, which is a slight drawback. I would have liked to see advanced options that give each civilization its own unique "flavor," perhaps in the form of a starting technology, an extra resource, or a military unit.
I'm infatuated with [i]Antike[/i] at the moment. Its weight scales well with players of varying levels of interest or skill. I think it is a great way to introduce new players to civilization-building games, and therefore it is a welcome addition to my collection.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=20]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2007[/SIZE][/COLOR] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 6th Place 2007[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 1/4/08, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: 9, 4P: 8}
Here we are in the new year, and I have something to confess. No, it's not that I plan on failing in my resolution to work out more this year. Rather, I'm experiencing a bout of Eurogame burnout. After running into different mixtures of the same mechanics over and over again, the line between games starts to blur. On the surface, [i]Arkadia[/i] appears to have elements of [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i], [i][thing=555]The Princes of Florence[/thing][/i], and [i][thing=88]Torres[/thing][/i]. That's quite the stable of excellent games, but I had my doubts about [i]Arkadia[/i]'s ability to stand on its own.
Those doubts were unfounded. I should have more faith in [person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person]. The man who created [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] is not likely to disappoint.
Blah, blah, settlers, builders, influential families, and a castle. We've covered this ground before. Once you get past the overused theme, [i]Arkadia[/i] really starts to shine. There are family seals in four colors, which are essentially a commodity market. Cards determine which buildings may be placed, and for which families. Play a card from behind your screen, place the building, and then draw a replacement. There are three face-up cards, or you can draw a card from the face-down pile. This idea has seen a lot of use (as in [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i]) because it mitigates the luck factor.
Like [i][thing=555]The Princes of Florence[/thing][/i], the buildings themselves look like [i]Tetris[/i] pieces: they have different shapes which use a block as the atomic unit. When a building is surrounded by other buildings or by worker figurines, then it is considered to be "completed," and a payout occurs. Players with workers around the building earn a family seal for each one. The player who completed the building receives the seal from it. In this manner, you collect the commodities (family seals). Therefore the first part of the game is about placing buildings and workers so that you maximize the number of seals you receive, while limiting the opportunities for your opponents. There is plenty of room for player conflict, as you can either place a building, or workers, but not both in the same turn. That familiar angst of "I wish I could do one more thing" is definitely present here.
Complete a building, and you also get to add a piece to the castle. This step is done by placing one of the [i][thing=88]Torres[/thing][/i]-like towers on the castle's foundation board. Each tower has a family seal seated within its crenellations. The castle acts as a fixed-ceiling market: the number of seals of a particular color that are visible when the castle is viewed from above determine the current market value of those seals (in gold coins). Thus, by completing buildings you earn the seals as well as the ability to adjust their value on the market. There are only ten such spaces available; once they are all filled, then you start building on the next level. You also have the opportunity to have a personal payout. This step provides you with two more workers in your color, and allows you to exchange your seals for gold at the current market rate. Early profit taking in some colors leads to long-hold strategies in others, while balancing hand management and your resource pool of workers.
There is one, final, well-worn attribute about [i]Arkadia:[/i] it is a very enjoyable game with surprising depth. These characteristics are becoming a hallmark of [person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person] titles, and they are ones with which I will never get tired.
item.conditiontext: Multi-lingual version by Ravensburger © 2007. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Arkham Horror (Third Edition)
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/29/19, Rated: 6 {3P: 6, 4P: 7, 5P: 5}[/i]
[i]Arkham Horror[/i] is a system that I want to like. There is something about this universe that I am drawn to. I can't get enough of it, which is to say I've bought lots of games and expansions and not played them enough. When this version came up for preorder, I decided not to buy it but was glad when someone else in my gaming group did.
The third edition is almost unrecognizable with its modular board and (relatively) streamlined components. Game play would feel derivative of [i][thing=30549][/thing][/i] with its [-]untreated infections[/-] unwarded doom resulting in outbreaks, but that undercurrent is masked beneath layers of polished writing and chrome. Fantasy Flight took an entire [i]book[/i] of pages from [thing=205637]the LCG[/thing] by implementing the Codex: an event-driven storyline for each scenario. This is the best part of the game, hands down. I absolutely adore how tightly the narrative is woven into this game.
There's a steep learning curve here. I've played it six times now, and I still don't feel completely comfortable with it. Investigator selection is of paramount importance: start with Calvin Wright and Marie Lambeau, and then fill in the rest of your group. I believe this game distills down to the ratio between successful investigator actions and mythos token draws. If you're 100% successful on your rolls (and you won't be), then the game is designed to be lost at a ratio of 1:1, which is the default. If you focus on gaining extra actions alone, then you stand a great chance of defeating the scenario. Adding players to the game will dilute the benefit of those extra actions while giving you greater map coverage.
All of the above happens in a long playing time. The games I've played clocked in at three hours or more. This is why [i]Arkham Horror (Third Edition)[/i] isn't rated higher: I can get all of that wonderful, horrifying narrative from [thing=205637]the card game[/thing] in a fraction of the time.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/29/19, Rated: 9[/i]
At last, the version of [i]Arkham Horror[/i] for which I have been unknowingly waiting. Creating a card game was an absolutely brilliant idea: every facet of the game contributes to the overall narrative. Each card contributes meaningfully to the experience, lending its art and its story to the sinister narrative being spun by the scenario.
Even the "board" gets constructed out of cards as you progress, thanks to clever iconography denoting the connections between locations. This developing environment makes the game feel more claustrophobic, which is a major departure from the preceding board games. You simply [i]do not know[/i] what's coming next, at least not during your first play through.
The scenario is implemented through an Act and Scene deck that contains a branching story line: you don't have to win in order to advance. The plot thread is so tightly woven into the fabric of the game that it is indistinguishable from the mechanics. I have not experienced better storytelling in a game before. It's so good that the idea was lifted and modified to work within [i][thing=257499][/thing][/i] as the "Codex."
Learning this game from the rules is torturous. Here's an example: your investigator has to pass a Will check against a value of 3. His starting Will is 3. You draw the Cthulhu tentacles token, which indicates instant failure. You need to know by how much you failed the check. One option might be that you failed by 0 -- it's still a failure. Scouring the rules for "skill check" covers every token symbol in the bag other than the Cthulhu tentacles. Elsewhere in the rule book I found that for an auto-fail token, the affected investor's skill is considered to be 0 -- in other words, I failed by 3! I had to bounce around the rules reference in order to piece that outcome together. Shame! Provide a better index!
The other torturous activity is the deck building. These are not familiar cards, nor is it a familiar PvP system. The one drawback of CCG's or LCG's is that they represent a [i]lifestyle:[/i] if you want to fully appreciate this game then you'll need to dedicate yourself to it. I was still able to build the starter deck and have fun with it, but the next step requires a lot of work that won't be as much fun. The quality of the storytelling, and the terrifying apprehension that goes along with each new scenario will justify and reward the effort.

item.name: Attack on Titan: The Last Stand
Attika
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 4th Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 4/21/06, Rated: 8[/i] {2P:9, 3P:8, 4P:???}
[i]Attika[/i] is game that is easy to learn, looks great, has intriguing pieces, and a veritable "tech tree" of building relationships that closely resemble a Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game on the PC. All of these are good attributes.
The 2p game is fantastic. The 3p game is a bit more hectic, and in some cases play feels a bit forced: are you going to do anything about that other person or do I have to do it? Minus one point for the drop-off in play.
Ideally, you spend your last card to play your winning tile. That's a mechanism that I have enjoyed in [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] and in [i][thing=9217]Saint Petersburg[/thing][/i]. Using cards to represent the different resources is a mechanic that I really like. It worked well for [i][thing=13]The Settlers of Catan[/thing][/i] and for [i][thing=6249]Alhambra[/thing][/i], and it works well here, too.
The welcome frustration of "I wish I could do one more thing" is somewhat diluted by the implementation of "amphoras:" these are basically extra action tokens that can be earned during the game. One one occasion, my opponent didn't draw the tile that he needed to connect two temples and win the game. I thought "Whew! I dodged a bullet!" Then he played an amphora, and won with the extra move. Maddening when it happens to you, and exhilarating when you do it to someone else.
Most of the time, [i]Attika[/i] is a wonderful game. Yet there are still occasions where you can't get ahead of the game due to unlucky tile draws. If the occasional bout of rampant bad luck doesn't deter you, then you should give [i]Attika[/i] a try.

item.name: Auf Achse
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1987[/b]
[i]Posted: 4/1/06, Rated: 5[/i]
No, this isn't some sort of April Fool's Day joke (see posting date). [i]Auf Achse[/i] is the second [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i] (SdJ) winner I have played that just didn't thrill me right out of the box (see my comments for [i][thing=256]Mississippi Queen[/thing][/i]). The components are cute enough: little trucks with flatbeds onto which you can load freight blocks. And the streamlined concept of taking contracts and then trying to deliver them is inviting enough for me to want to play this game.
[i]However.[/i]
I feel like I'm missing some integral part of this game: the [i]fun[/i]. Okay, I want to buy contracts that are along my route. Try to have two contracts (or more, with trailers!) loaded at the same time if possible. Keep your opponents from buying convenient contracts cheaply. I get all of it. It just hasn't yet coalesced into a compelling game experience yet.
Maybe part of the problem is the "closed auction" system. What I mean by that is the auction bid increments are forced: you can't drive up the price beyond a certain extent. Playing with open auctions adds a little more interest to the game for my group. Outside of the auction system, there is little opportunity for "ganging up on the leader."
The Event Cards in this game are quite frivolous, and feel like Chance cards from (gasp!) [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i]. That's not necessarily a bad thing, as they allow players who are falling behind to take some risks in an effort to fulfill a contract quickly, or to use a "Stau" (traffic jam) event to block the path of the leader. The cards do add some spice to an otherwise bland game.
I'll continue to play from time to time, and perhaps I will find the right set of people and variants to make it truly shine. Until that time, someone else will have to suggest it.

item.name: Battleship
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/13/07, Rated: 4[/i]
[i]Battleship[/i] is another one of those ageless classics that seems to work its way into every game cabinet out of nostalgia. Or out of mass-marketing, you decide. A simple enough game in concept, where the packaging ends up making a difference. I find the peg boards in my version to be more exciting with their cardboard inserts of radar displays, but I miss the old red versus blue feel of the set with which I played as a child.
I think this game works better with a pad of paper and a pencil, so that you can arrange your ships diagonally if you choose. It also eliminates my compulsive need to ensure that there are precisely 34 red pegs, and 68 white pegs in each case. Yes, you should pity me for knowing that piece of useless trivia.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game – Daybreak Expansion
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game – Exodus Expansion
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game – Pegasus Expansion
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/1/11, Rated: 8[/i]
Many of the reviews I've read about this expansion have focused on Cylon Leaders, and the New Caprica board. While those are interesting, those aren't the only additions to the base game! I loved the addition of the Treachery deck: those cards add a creatively wicked dimension to the game. For example, forcing the human players to pick up Treachery cards, and when they try to discard them being able to play "Sabotage" to damage Galactica.
More character options are always appreciated, and the Pegasus itself is a challenging addition. Its locations offer higher risk/reward opportunities. And of course, there's the airlock: you have the chance to execute a player, which is a very attractive option for first-timers.
All of these options can be used in various combinations along with the New Caprica board, and the Cylon Leaders. Overall, I was quite pleased with this expansion, and am looking forward to incorporating it in future games.
item.conditiontext: Complete and in excellent condition. All components are in pristine condition, but the box has two bruises which were presumably inflicted during shipping. Sleeved.

item.name: Belfort
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/15/12, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: ?, 3P: ?, 4P: ?, 5P: 9}
[i]Belfort[/i] feels like it could be a city in the [i]Harry Potter[/i] mythos, or perhaps more appropriately in the faerie world of [i]Artemis Fowl[/i]. You are seeking to gain the most influence over the city with your Elves, Dwarves, and Gnomes.
At first glance [i]Belfort[/i] is a worker placement game with different types of workers. This is an interesting start. I can't recall another game that has different workers: in [i][thing=34635]Stone Age[/thing][/i] they're all the same. Ditto [i][thing=24480]The Pillars of the Earth[/thing][/i]. Meeples are contextually different in [i][thing=822]Carcassonne[/thing][/i], but their roles vary throughout the game.
Worker placement equals resource management. Four different resources (wood, stone, metal, and gold) are gathered to do something, which in this case means constructing buildings. Buildings which have been constructed can be activated à la [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i], [i][thing=35677]Le Havre[/thing][/i], and the like. Normally, buildings are constructed to do something, only now we're not adding to a cathedral, or the king's palace; The buildings themselves are a means to an end.
For [i]Belfort[/i] really is an area control game. Each building you place goes somewhere on the city. You can choose the "quarter" (although there are five sections), and place your marker on a matching building there. The players with the first- and second-most markers in each quintile earn points. [i]This is the central point-scoring mechanic of the game, and it's easy to overlook![/i] For while you are planning your builds, tallying your resources, and marshaling your workers, it is easy to lose sight of the ultimate goal: to obtain a scoring plurality in as many quintiles as you can.
For me, all of these mechanisms gel together effortlessly. My mind instinctively groks how the game works, and therefore it is a lot of fun. The fantasy theme adds just the right touch of whimsy to keep [i]Belfort[/i] from feeling like work. The powers provided by the Guilds help to keep each game fresh. It's a wonderful combination of seemingly heavy mechanisms in a single box with a reasonable playing time. It's almost like a fairy tale.

item.name: Blitzkrieg!: World War Two in 20 Minutes (Second Edition)
Blitzkrieg!: World War Two in 20 Minutes (Second Edition)
Blokus
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/7/07, Rated: 8[/i]
Imagine someone taking the old video game [i]Tetris,[/i] and morphing it into a four player board game. That is basically what you get with [i]Blokus.[/i]
Each player is given a quota of pieces to place. The difference in [i]Blokus[/i] is that when you play a piece, it must touch at the corner of another one. You cannot have a straight side touching at all.
This one, simple limitation means that you cannot interlock two pieces to shut out an opponent: there is limited board space, after all. Careful placing of your pieces can allow you to worm your way through your opponents' formations, seeking out those big pockets of empty space that will allow you to play your larger pieces.
The pieces themselves acquire personalities as a result. Long straight pieces are good defensively, or to flank a position. Pieces with lots of corners provide more flexibility for future placements. All in all, the simple rules and shapes come together to create strategic options.
Perhaps the most important thing for me is that my wife loves to play [i]Blokus.[/i] Even though it is a simple game, that earns it an extra point in my book.
item.conditiontext: Educational Insights © 2005. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Blood on the Clocktower
item.wishlistcomment: Would another social deduction game actually get played? The theme is so well integrated with this one that the answer is "maybe." But the price is too great to experiment. To put it another way, I invested in [i][thing=328866][/thing][/i] instead.

item.name: Blood Rage: 5th Player Extras – Kickstarter Exclusives
Blue Moon
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 3/10/08, Rated: 8[/i]
I really enjoyed playing the collectible card game (CCG) [i][thing=463]Magic: The Gathering[/thing][/i] until I realized that in order to be truly competitive, I was going to have to spend a lot of money buying special cards. I was resentful of that fact, and ultimately lost interest in playing it. Although I haven't played a game in years, I still have fond memories of its highlights, chief among those being the process of building a deck.
The idea of a game which was CCG-like [i]without[/i] being a money pit like [i][thing=463]Magic: The Gathering[/thing][/i] was quite appealing. I felt disoriented during my first few games of [i]Blue Moon:[/i] the game presents a different world, with its own unique mechanics. Once I began to understand how it worked I realized that there was a beautfiully strategic battle to be fought.
There is no concept of "damaging" the other player's hit points. Instead, you are trying to beat the other player's deck. This is an important distinction, because losing a game doesn't feel as personal. You can try for a fast win by overwhelming your opponent's ability to match your attack strength. Alternatively, you can try to grind out a win over long rounds where more cards and special powers come into play.
The base game comes with two "races." The "Vulca" are fiery creatures who can quickly blaze to victory. The "Hoax" are about deck control, and can neutralize that big offense. These decks are not one-dimensional, as they actually have a few cards from other races as well. This one matchup alone is excellent.
When you're ready for some more variety then there are expansions. Unlike a true CCG, these expansions are also fixed-decks, which means you will get the same set of cards each time. This is the feature which I love: I can spend a relatively small amount of money (the equivalent of two or three booster packs from a "traditional" CCG), and know in advance exactly which cards I'm going to get. Since one of the rules for building a deck is that every card must be different, it is not useful to buy a second copy of any of them.
[i]Blue Moon[/i] is a well-conceived game that plays quickly, and with a lot of excitement. It definitely scratches that CCG itch, without inflicting the pain of a true CCG. If you're looking for that type of game experience, then give [i]Blue Moon[/i] a try.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: [url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=52]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: Blue Moon City: Zusätzliche Gebäude 1 & 2
item.originalname: Blue Moon City: Expansion Tile Sets 1 & 2

item.name: Blue Moon Legends
item.comment: Even though I own the original [i][thing=9446][/thing][/i] and all of its expansion packs, this copy is inclusive in a single box, and should give me two of every card. That means Rowan and I could draft our own decks which could include the same cards. Hopefully the card backs will be distinctive; I think they are.

item.name: The BoardGameGeek Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/10/10, Rated: 6[/i]
I love this site. I registered back in 2004, and have been coming here faithfully ever since. My board game collection has expanded to the point where the closet is bursting. Here is a game about my beloved hobby by [person=134]Richard Breese[/person], the designer of [i][thing=12962]Reef Encounter[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=4099]Keythedral[/thing][/i], two excellent games in their own right. I'm telling you all of this so you'll know that I wanted to like this game.
That actually says a lot, right? I mean, you're apt to overlook things that you wouldn't typically forgive other titles. The board here is [i]busy[/i]: this is a tribute to board games, after all. There's even a neat "key" on the back of the board, listing the games from which all of the pictures were taken. The eye doesn't "rest" on this board; instead, you're constantly focusing on different items, and can get distracted from the game. Worse, it is possible to overlook the tiles.
The game itself is clever, and ultimately simple: as a game publisher, you want to earn the most money -- in this game, points are called GeekGold! -- for your games. As a publisher-collector, you want to collect sets of games other than the ones you publish yourself. The theme is well integrated: I like the idea of geeks going "window shopping," but I'm the only person in my family who appreciates it.
I affectionately refer to [person=134]Mr. Breese[/person] as a "bit-head," because his games often have a [i]ton[/i] of components. [i]TBGGG[/i] is actually a conservative offering in this respect. It still includes player screens, another favorite device of his. There are dice which take on the roles of "Geeks," and which are used to acquire games. The closest analogy I can make is that the dice in [i]TBGGG[/i] are placed like those in [i][thing=27162]Kingsburg[/thing][/i], only here they're not used in combination. You can also spend your GeekGold (points) to change their distribution, which can mitigate the impact of bad rolls. Spending your points as currency is an idea which I feel was perfected in [i][thing=46]Medici[/thing][/i], and I'm glad to see it re-implemented here. Movement of your Geeks also has an impact on determining the start player, which can be very important.
You will be trying to create "sets" of games of the same value. This is where strategy comes into play: you should always aim for "net positive value" on your acquisitions. Claiming a game pays its publisher a certain price. Note: you don't have to sacrifice your own points to acquire that game. However, if you "buy" a game of value "3," and the publisher earns 4 points for it, then you've lost a point relative to that specific player. If you have a full set of tiles, then each tile is worth 6 points to you. Taking that same example, the "3" for which the publisher made 4 points netted you two points relative to that player when played as part of a complete set. This mindset should be at the core of your every action. Going first or second can make all the difference in your being able to complete a set.
What remains then is tile placement. If you always pursue the same strategy of "getting the most for your products," then the other players will be able to correctly guess how to obtain your specific tiles. Your predictability will enable them to complete sets, and earn the maximum number of points. I can see several different tactics which could be employed: placing a game in a shop with a break-even "bottom shelf" in order to optimize your earning potential across all stores. Placing your tile on the top shelf so that if it isn't claimed, then it goes off of the board, and the other players miss out on a chance to complete their sets. There are even two "blank" tiles which can be used to disguise your play style.
All of these items work together well. The problem is that the theme isn't very compelling to my family. It's not likely to make it to the table very often for these depths to be explored. I think that [i]The BoardGameGeek Game[/i] represents a fantastic tribute to our hobby, and has a clever design by a renown developer. Ultimately, though, it doesn't hold a wider appeal, and that limits its success.

item.name: La Boca
item.wishlistcomment: A 3D puzzle game that was highly recommended by friends at BGG.con. Very interesting.

item.name: Boggle
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/1/05, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Boggle[/i] isn't for everybody. The largest hurdle to overcome is that you should have an extensive vocabulary. This requirement automatically excludes younger players from being competitive with older ones.
There are sixteen cubes, each of which has different letters on its sides. These cubes are shaken, and then fall into place on a 4-by-4 grid. Every player now has three minutes to write down as many words -- of three letters in length or longer -- that she can form by following an unbroken path through the cubes.
Therefore, the second attribute that is necessary is pattern recognition. Most people do well at following straight lines, or making right-hand turns. However, following diagonals, or being able to see a word whose path crosses over itself requires the development of a new skill.
The learning curve to satisfy these two requirements is steep enough to dissuade most new players from continued playing. With the right crowd, [i]Boggle[/i] can be a blast. With the wrong crowd, it can turn people off to word games altogether.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 5th Place 1997[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 2/12/06, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Bohnanza[/i] is a fun little game, that takes a different view on set-collection, and introduces a new mechanic to card games with which I have not yet played.
You can only collect two sets at a time (later in the game, you have the opportunity to expand this number to three). At the beginning of your turn, you [i]must[/i] plant the first card in your hand, which means you may have to harvest a bean "field" in order to make room, often before you would have liked to do so. This limiting mechanic is a fun addition that creates tough decisions: do I take the easy, one coin from a field now? Or do I hold on to those beans, hoping they will earn more later, and instead harvest my second field which doesn't yet have enough beans to earn anything?
The "first card in your hand" is easy to determine because you must play your cards in the order in which you drew them. You may not adjust the order of the cards in your hand. This is a new idea, and I really like it. This card order often influences your play in the current turn: you could plant two beans of the same type now, or you could hold on to that second one because you think you will be able to play it as the first card in your next turn. Of course, you may end up trading for other beans before the start of your next turn, have to harvest that very bean field, and then that first card is an albatross around your neck.
Trading and haggling are also a vital part of [i]Bohnanza,[/i] and in my opinion that kind of interactivity always enhances a game. [i]Bohnanza[/i] plays well from two to four players. The box says it goes up to seven, but I haven't tried any more than four yet. The two player variant is different enough to allow for longer-range planning, which I enjoy. Lastly, the whimsical artwork on the cards has been well-received by my two sons, ages seven and five, who enjoy playing as well. A solid, lightweight game for the family!
[i]Updated: 1/4/08, Rated: 7[/i]
Re-asserting my original rating of "7." This game is still a lot of fun. My sons are shrewder in their trades now, which makes the experience more interesting. I'd bump it to an "8," but longevity alone is not enough to warrant the increase.
[i]Updated: 8/9/10, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: 5, 3P: 7, 4P: 8, 5P: 9, 6P: ?, 7P: ?}
Have we really been playing this game for four years? The answer is "yes." Like a fine wine, [i]Bohnanza[/i] has gotten better with age. Not my cards, unfortunately, and my wife tells me that she will refuse to play this game if I sleeve it!
I think we've finally reached a level of expertise where the game has fully opened up. Ironically, it is still usually in your best interest to trade away beans your opponents need, if only to keep your own hand optimized.
Now we realize the importance of being in markets where other players aren't competing. We also track the number of each particular type of bean available after it has been harvested; no one wants a Garden Bean or a Red Bean if the others have already been sold. Lastly, keeping track of [i]when[/i] cards are placed in the discard pile is an important consideration, especially before the last trip through the deck. All of these considerations merge beautifully, and the 4P game is very enjoyable.
We had the chance to play the 5P game while my niece was staying with us. It's even [i]better[/i]. Both of these realizations finally bump [i]Bohnanza[/i] up a point.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 29 Nov 2020, Rated: 7[/i]
This is an intentional attempt to rate games more critically. [i]Can’t Stop[/i] at its core is a wonderful implementation of pure statistics: it is more likely you will roll a 7 on two dice, but you’ll have to do it more times in order to score that column. 12 and 2 are far less likely, so you don’t need as many of them.
What make these statistics even more opaque is that you get to roll four dice and group them into two pairs. Suddenly the math isn’t as straightforward: how likely are you to roll a 7 when you can select two out of four dice? The answer is 64.35%. During your turn you can have up to three target numbers of which you must roll at least one in order to keep going. If you have 6-7-8 then the likelihood that you roll at least one of them when selecting two dice out of four is a whopping 91.98%! With odds like that, the name of the game becomes very apparent!
It’s pure push your luck, and it results in epic runs and heartbreaking busts. It has worked with everyone to whom I have introduced the game, making it a go-to for new players. It’s fun to play even if it’s not intellectually satisfying — in other words, it’s a great filler game in a not-so-filler form factor.
item.conditiontext: [geekurl=/wiki/page/Guide_to_Selling_Games_on_BGG#toc8]Like New[/geekurl]. Sets of orange and black cones added.

item.name: Canasta Caliente
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/23/12, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Canasta Caliente[/i] is apparently a variant of [i][thing=17104][/thing][/i] -- shocking, I know. It is a Rummy variation using partners, where the value of your initial meld increases as your team crosses scoring thresholds. So what makes this game so "caliente?" As far as I can tell, it is having the point values of cards clearly marked; a "Stop" card (although there may be a similar provision for "Stop" in regular [i][thing=17104][/thing][/i]), and some 100-point bonus cards.
All of these frills result in a game that feels like scoring is chaotic. It makes sense, eventually, but wild point swings are very possible. As with any [i][thing=15878][/thing][/i] variant, control of the discard deck is vitally important. Often times the first team to seize the discard deck ends up winning that round. The other trick is to manage your hand size: it is tempting to play all of your cards as you go. However, if you get down to having only one or two cards, then you can't play a set after you draw and still have something to discard.
My wife and I have friends who love to play this game, and they consistently beat us. Another annoying property of this game is that I just can't seem to get better at it. I'm sure this frustration is reflected in my rating, but ultimately I would choose a different game to play if possible.

item.name: Capitol
item.conditiontext: [geekurl=/wiki/page/Guide_to_Selling_Games_on_BGG#toc8]Very Good[/geekurl]. I picked up this one used off of eBay, played it, enjoyed it, but haven't touched it since.

item.name: Carabande
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 1996[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 11/19/05, Rated: 9[/i]
This game is a sure-fire hit. I knew it would be. I actually hesitated to introduce it to my kids, because I'm afraid that it will make them forget about all of the other games that we have to play. We'll see how that goes.
The entire family loves this game, including my reluctant gamer-wife. Once she realized that she was going to be flicking these tokens around the track, she got into it with gusto. Soon she's arguing rules with my sons -- a sure sign that competitive juices are flowing!
The track itself feels rather short, but it does take up the entire table. I can see how some people would be motivated to purchase multiple sets to make even more interesting tracks.
Next up: the [i][thing=1526]Carabande Action Set[/thing][/i].

item.name: Carabande Action Set
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/7/07, Rated: 6[/i]
[b]chi·cane[/b] [shi-[b]keyn[/b]] [i]noun[/i]
1. a bridge hand that is void of trumps
2. a movable barrier used in motor racing; sometimes placed before a dangerous corner to reduce speed as cars pass in single file
The [i]Carabande Action-Set[/i] provides two, 90° curves, one X-chicane, and one Y-chicane. What it's really known for, though, is its [i]jump.[/i] As if you needed any help sending your "cars" off the edge of the track, now you can launch them.
The curves are useful for adding the other parts to the base set. The jump itself fits perfectly up against a section of cross-track. It's important to note that the jump in the [i]Carabande Action-Set[/i] is [i]not[/i] the same as the one found in the [i]Pitch Car Extension.[/i] There is not an "overpass," nor a down-ramp for the other side. The orange press-in rails are consistent with those found in the original [i][thing=150]Carabande[/thing][/i].
The chicanes add a certain amount of visual interest, and can slow play down a bit. Successfully completing the jump can be very difficult. In three and four player games, with each person playing with two cars, a real bottleneck can occur as people repeatedly mis-flick.
I'd like to say that the enjoyment this expansion brings is worth its cost. However, if you're looking to expand your existing [i][thing=150]Carabande[/thing][/i] set, I'd advise saving up a little extra money, and buying a second base set. The additional configurations that a second set would provide would far outpace the fun of this expansion.
item.conditiontext: [geekurl=/wiki/page/Guide_to_Selling_Games_on_BGG#toc8]Very Good[/geekurl]. All pieces present and in pristine condition. Box had several long tears in the bottom that have been repaired, and has visible shelf wear.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2001[/b] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2001[/b]
[i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Carcassonne[/i] is a fun game, with easy mechanics. My five year-old (at the time of this writing) is able to play effectively. I do have a couple of small complaints, though. The first has to do with tile memorization: when it is my turn, how I place a certain tile should be affected by my knowledge of the remaining pieces. I feel that my understanding of the game is limited by not memorizing all of the different tile configurations with respect to roads, cities, fields, etc.
The other complaint that I have is how overwhelmingly strong a well-placed farmer can be. In some games, I have found myself eschewing the completion of cities or monasteries, just so I could extend the reach of a single farmer. The farming score at the end of these games was obscenely large, and resulted in what appeared to be a huge come from behind win.
[i]Carcassonne[/i] can be taught to new players very quickly, and is a good introduction for those who have never played a European game before.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Carcassonne[/i] is still a good game, but it's not a "go to" title for which I would go out of my way to find a game. Perhaps with the right blend of expansions it can still be an "8," but not on its own.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 3 – The Princess & The Dragon
Carcassonne: Expansion 8 – Bridges, Castles and Bazaars
Carcassonne: The River
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/14/05, Rated: 5[/i]
This "expansion" was included in the base set that I purchased a while ago. The river tiles do enhance the appearance of the completed map, and that is about all.
When we do play with this expansion, we use a house rule that the spring and the lake tiles do not allow a farm to wrap around the river. A player would have to add seven extra tiles around the outside of the spring or the lake in order to do so.
I can see then where the river can break up monster farms. In essence it can divide the board into two separate playing areas, allowing two players to play solitaire. With three players, two usually end up battling on the same side of the river, while the third operates in an unmolested fashion. With four...well, you get my drift. [i]Carcassone - The River[/i] plays best when the number of players is a multiple of two.
My gaming group (including my family!) enjoys the confrontational opportunities of the basic game when played without this expansion. I could take it or leave it, so most of the time we leave it.

item.name: Cargo Noir
item.conditiontext: [geekurl=/wiki/page/Guide_to_Selling_Games_on_BGG#toc8]Very Good[/geekurl]. Box lid has a tear on one edge that doesn't go all the way through. It was like that before the shrink wrap was removed. Components complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Carpe Diem
item.wishlistcomment: A new Alea game, and I collect them. Played at BGG.con 2018. Looked rondel-ish to start, but then you have to follow the lines from one "bowl" to the next. Easier to learn than other Alea games, but there's some definite depth here as well!

item.name: Carson City: Father Christmas Promo Card
Cartagena
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/9/09, Rated: 9[/i]
I was first introduced to [i]Cartagena[/i] on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BrettspielWelt[/url] (BSW). It was and is an easy game to learn: spend a card to move one of your pirates to the next empty space with the same symbol as your card, or else move your pirate back to the first spot that only has one or two pirates on it, to pick up one or two cards respectively. It was an interesting one, but a frustrating one as I had not yet learned how to "manufacture" card-earning opportunities.
With repeated plays, I learned how to work the first part of the board, generating a lot of cards, and allowing other players to trailblaze: their pawns would pave the way for more efficient leapfrogging of my own. [i]Cartagena[/i] rose to be a "6" or a "7" with me.
Next we explored the variations: "Jamaica" allows the players to hide the cards in their hands, and cards are drawn blindly from the deck. "Tortuga" requires open information: players' hands are known, and a number of cards are dealt face-up from the draw pile. "Tortuga" turns an easy game into one with many strategic considerations: do I attempt to build a "monopoly" in swords, so that I can move my pirates more effectively? Or do I want to hang on to a few pistols, because the player to my right has a lot of them? Analysis paralysis can creep in, but it's still a very satisfying game. It rose to an "8."
Finally, I got a chance to play in person when I met BGG user [geekurl=/user/Javal]Javal[/geekurl] and his now-wife at a local pub. It was a ton of fun. And despite my nostalgic preference for the graphics I knew from BSW, the new version was quite acceptable! I made sure to pick up a copy with my next game order.
I have since taught this game to at least twenty other people at various gatherings, and it has been a winner each time. Being easy to learn, hiding depths of strategy, and being well-received are all hallmarks of a great game. It has plundered a "9" rating from me, and deservedly so.

item.name: Cartagena: Die Goldinsel
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/10/09, Rated: 7[/i]
Some background about me: I have become a fan of [person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person]. His games have resonated well with me, and I don't think I'm alone. [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=12002]Jambo[/thing][/i] in 2004. [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] in 2005. [i][thing=25643]Arkadia[/thing][/i] in 2006. [i][thing=37907]Diamonds Club[/thing][/i] in 2008. All of these games have been hits with me. On top of that, I really enjoy the original [i][thing=826]Cartagena[/thing][/i]. Picking up a copy of this game was a foregone conclusion, and I [i]wanted[/i] to like it. Now you know.
But here's the thing: I haven't made up my mind about it, yet.
A common thread between [geekurl=/boardgamedesigner/381/rudiger-dorn#linkeditems]Mr. Dorn's titles[/geekurl] is one of choice when faced with multiple paths to victory. That's his trademark. However, the original [i][thing=826]Cartagena[/thing][/i] was a very simple, straightforward game. Your choices were tightly constrained to the positioning of your pirates, and hand management. The movement track was extremely linear. These attributes are practically polar opposites. I shouldn't have been surprised when the mash-up between them turned out to be...unusual.
The first thing I noticed was that the six-fold board turns out to be deceptively big when removed from the small box. This isn't the modular board you've come to expect from previous games. Each player gets her own stack of 16 action cards, from which she will be drawing her hand. Players won't be competing for these cards. Each card has a movement value, and also a special power. During a player's turn, she must play one card to [i]move[/i] (ignoring its ability); she may then play a second card for its [i]ability[/i] (ignoring its movement value). At the end of her turn, she refreshes her hand to four cards: there isn't a need to manufacture card-earning opportunities in this game.
There are pirates in four different colors, digging permits (because pirates care about following the local regulations), hidden treasures, gambling, and rule-bending artifacts. Okay, all of that sounds like fun, but there aren't a lot of parallels to the original [i][thing=826]Cartagena[/thing][/i] to be found here, either.
But wait, there's more! A deductive component is also present: every player must find "Die Goldinsel," The Gold Island. Each of the twelve treasure islands in the game has a corresponding "map card." One of them is set aside at the beginning of the game, like a one-dimensional version of [i][thing=1294]Clue[/thing][/i]. Failure to have one of your digging permits on The Gold Island at the end of the game results in [i]player elimination[/i]. Yes, you read that right: you automatically lose, regardless of your score. Here's where the potential for player conflict arises, as some of the action cards' abilities allow you to rob other players of their map cards in order to solve this mystery.
Shake well and pour into a chilled glass. Or swig it straight from the jug, matey. Your call.
[i]Cartagena: Die Goldinsel[/i] gets many things right, but so far has failed to emerge as a [person=381]Dorn[/person] classic. The original game rewarded clever movement when you captured two cards in one move. The closest [i]Cartagena: Die Goldinsel[/i] comes to that feeling is when you are able to play two cards during your turn. Since many of the abilities are location-constrained, you can find yourself in a situation where you simply cannot take a second action. Each treasure island has a unique symbol reminiscent of the symbols from the original game, but that is a tenuous association at best.
Player movement in "The Nest" (on land) is simple, and linear. It provides several opportunities to take that second action, as well as to avoid creating such opportunities for your opponents. This part works well. However, once a player has acquired pirates, digging permits, and map cards, his ship weighs anchor and sets out to sea. At this point, movement isn't so linear, as there are multiple routes between islands. This part of the game feels foreign to me. I never played [i][thing=25823]Cartagena II[/thing][/i], so I don't know if this is a natural evolution from that title.
Here's an example of how the game bogs down at sea: I want to sail to Skull Island (because I haven't seen its map card yet, and therefore it could be The Gold Island), and it is two spaces away. However, I don't have a card with a movement value of "2." I might find a different route that takes me to the same place in four movement points, which is a card I do have. Hopefully I will still have an "Ashore" card for me to play as my second action. If I don't, then there are some tempo cards that can be played for that second action to open up hand room if I don't have a good pair now, but I always have to move at the beginning of my turn. The cards I have next turn may not be the right ones, either. Being at sea feels like a separate game, and my family has yet to discover the synergy between the two phases of sea & land.
What does end up happening is a race to place your six digging permits. If you avoid the islands whose cards you have already seen, and spam the rest with your digging permits, then you stand a reasonable chance of finding The Gold Island in the process. This approach combined with some luck appears to be the the most prosperous one, and it's hardly satisfying. To complicate matters, each treasure island is worth an unknown number of points. Ideally you are placing your stronger (higher valued) digging permits on those islands which are worth more points, but that requires you to spend your "Seer" actions peeking under the treasure chests. You will be losing time against a player utilizing the "race" strategy above.
Small nitpick: you have two discoverable columns of information ("Not Gold Island," and "Treasure Chest Value") with the expectation that you [i]remember[/i] these details unassisted. Keeping notes is listed as an easier variant, but I suspect it's going to become the norm in my house.
My early rating is thus highly volatile: if it turns out that the "race" strategy is the only viable one, then the whole game comes down to a crap shoot at the end: did you find The Gold Island or not? That would warrant a lower rating. Right now, the final verdict is still out. My appreciation of both the designer, and the progenitor title are eking out an extra point. If the game opens up after repeated plays, then my rating could go higher. What is immediately obvious is that this is not the light, tactical game it has been marketed to be. Arrrgh!

item.name: Chess
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/20/04, Rated: 9[/i]
The game mechanics are sleek and refined after centuries of polish. Luck plays no part in this game at all.
[i]Chess[/i] is the perfect example of "what you get out of it is what you put into it." I simply don't have the free time to spend learning "the openings" as I somehow feel obligated to spend. The last thing that I need from a game is guilt.
On the plus side, there will always be an avid [i]Chess[/i] following, and if you know where to look, you can always find a game.
[i]Updated: 8/1/05, Rated: 6[/i]
I'm dispensing with the guilt. If this game were a true "9," then I would want to play it at every opportunity. That simply is not the case. I like to play [i]Chess,[/i] but there are many other games that I would reach for first.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/5/11, Rated: 8[/i]
It's confession time again. I own [i][thing=421]1830[/thing][/i], but I don't feel that my understanding of its genre is sophisticated enough to appreciate it. [i][thing=94]Union Pacific[/thing][/i] is more my style. [i]Chicago Express[/i] appears to be the "missing link" when it comes to train games: it has just enough share auction and corporate valuation to be intriguing, without a lot of rules surrounding it. In fact, I think the gameplay has been smartly pruned down to the bare essentials for a game of this type.
Side note: some people say a rule set is "elegant," others say it is "pared down." Either way, you have a game whose rules are simple to understand, yet encompass a surprising depth of play. [i]Chicago Express[/i] is one of those games.
I love the artwork of the board, and the wooden train markers. The company status boards look sharp, and I appreciate their being double-sided to support an individual preference for organization (I prefer the side with $1, $5, and $25 spaces). This is a game I definitely want to climb back aboard!
item.wishlistcomment: Looking for the new Queen Games version, not "Wabash Cannonball."

item.name: Clue
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/5/09, Rated: 5[/i]
I didn't have a fond memory of this game growing up. My family owned it, I played it, and I never won. I wasn't too keen on revisiting it as an adult. I was willing to let Ms. Scarlet get away with it.
That disdain vanished when my wife mentioned that she wanted to play it with our boys. Then she uncovered a mystery of her own: she wanted to play the version which she grew up playing. The one where the Dining Room was sky blue with a lace doily, and the Ball Room had a parquet floor. I had a lead on just such a copy: my mom still had one. Thus, after collecting dust for a quarter of a century, it migrated into my collection.
And it turns out that the game is more interesting than I originally remembered. My challenge now is to develop a note-taking style that isn't too complicated; merely checking the box for my own guesses isn't enough. I still really dislike the roll-and-move aspect of the game, especially when your progress to a "remote" room like the Library is thwarted by another player's suggestion.
[i]Clue[/i] is a decent game. I'll play the sleuth if someone else requests it, but I secretly hope the family discovers [i][thing=915]Mystery of the Abbey[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=438]Scotland Yard[/thing][/i] instead.
