item.name: Coimbra
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/15/18, Rated: 6[/i]
Visually, [i]Coimbra[/i] is absolutely stunning to behold. It reminds me of [i][version=32607][/version][/i], which is high praise indeed. I doubt it will have the same staying power as that modern classic.
Dice drafting for priority in a card draft, leading to area majority-style scoring on upgrade tracks. Wonderful conceit about first using dice for their value, and later for their color. Additional interactions with a bonus node map, and let's throw in some end of game specials as well.
Did you see the weakness there? "Dice drafting for priority in a card draft." That sequence alone makes it very difficult to plan ahead, at least in a 4p game. That inability is compounded by all of the intricacies of the remaining mechanics. I love the way that the colors of action cards, dice, and progress tracks are tied together, but it's those influences that lead to severe downtime issues.
Could be better at lower player counts, which is why I'm still interested in playing it some more. Not the first game to suffer at max player count, see [i][thing=182874][/thing][/i], a game I thoroughly enjoy.
item.wishlistcomment: A visually beautiful game with interesting dynamics that nonethelesss suffers from prolonged downtime. Not as vulnerable as [i][thing=182874][/thing][/i] with that game's "out and back" player turn order, but evocative of it. I have a suspicion that its sweet spot is 3P.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 9th Place 2003[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 4/11/06, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Coloretto[/i] is a fun, light filler game. It is easy to teach, and plays very quickly. It has elements of strategy in the card drafting (creating piles of cards that your opponents may select) alternating with a "push your luck" style if you are the last person to select a row. Do you fill it up completely, hoping for something good, and risking an extra card that you don't want?
My sons (ages five and seven at the time of this writing) were playing well right off of the bat. Probably closer to an "8," but I'm taking off a point for the lack of official 2-player support. The score might creep up there after I have an opportunity to try one of the 2-player variants listed here on BGG.
item.conditiontext: Box has been ripped due to excessive travel (and subsequently taped). Cards still in mint condition. Sleeved.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/10/09, Rated: 7[/i] {3P: ???, 4P: 7, 5P: ???}
Ratings are subjective, pure and simple. Thus, let me tell you about my preconceptions regarding [i]Colosseum[/i]: I suspected that it was a bad game.
Days of Wonder offered a copy [i]for free[/i] in December of '08 if you spent $50 or more on their site. One copy of [i][thing=21348]Ticket to Ride: Märklin Edition[/thing][/i] later, and I owned both titles. What kind of game do you give away for free? "One that isn't selling well on its own," was my reply and also the reason I suspected the game was bad.
Was I ever wrong.
[i]Colosseum[/i] is a good game. It might even be great, but we'll get to that in a moment. First, let's talk about the absolutely ridiculous production values. Days of Wonder is known for their lavish offerings, but they've really outdone themselves this time. The sculpted noble meeples are exquisite. The artwork is detailed, pleasing, and is highly saturated in color. The theme has been consistently applied in every aspect of the game. I love how [i]Colosseum[/i] looks on the table.
It must be the game play which comes up short, then, right? Wrong again. If anything, [i]Colosseum[/i] is too deep for its own good. There's an investment phase, with seemingly equal choices which in reality are not; an auction phase, which is going to paralyze new players who don't yet have a handle on valuing tiles; and then a trading phase which is also difficult for new players to quantify.
A good starting place is to compare the relative benefit of the items in question to the receiving players. At this point, the game feels calculation-heavy, like the worst parts of [i][thing=2651]Power Grid[/thing][/i]. If you believe that [i][thing=2651]Power Grid[/thing][/i] has no "worst parts," then go out and secure a copy of [i]Colosseum[/i] immediately. All of these auctions and trades should be pursued with a long-term strategy in mind: producing a show whose components you are trying to acquire throughout the game. Try to select your end-goal at the very beginning, and hope the show you want to produce is still available when you're ready to purchase it. If you're counting, there are at least three mechanisms in play which are going to require a deeper understanding before the game starts to "click."
Scores for the round are tallied using that same calculation, everyone suffers some attrition, and then there is a charity step where the poorest gets to steal from the richest. Wash, rinse, and repeat for five rounds. The trick is not to set too high of a score early on: the charity step serves as an inducement to choose your shot wisely -- a fourth mechanic which requires several plays to appreciate.
[i]Colosseum[/i] looks great, hides surprising depth, and is an exciting title for veteran players. Why doesn't it earn a higher score then? Perhaps those preconceptions are still seeping through. Or maybe it's because competition at the higher ranking levels is very fierce. One thing is for sure: I'm looking forward to playing it again. Only time will tell if it has true greatness, or if it is merely a crumbling façade.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/5/11, Rated: 9[/i]
At this point I have to say that I'm a fan of [person=25]Richard Borg's[/person] "Commands" mechanic. I have copies of [i][thing=10630]Memoir '44[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=25417]BattleLore[/thing][/i], yet I still wanted to try this title, too. Am I ever glad that I did!
While I love the production value that [company=1027]Days of Wonder[/company] poured into the other two titles (now [company=17]Fantasy Flight[/company] for the latter), they have always felt frivolous with their miniatures. That's not a bad thing as games are meant to be fun, after all. Still, when I finally emerged from the wracks of sticker torture, I was rewarded with a game whose appearance resonates with me. The look of blocks on a muted board makes me think of the sand tables used in military classes. The look is admittedly simplistic, which fits this time period perfectly.
Mechanics-wise, [i]C&C:A[/i] feels very familiar. We're still learning how to move a large host across an open field: should we be methodical, maintaining support even though we're taking opportunity fire from archers? Or should we rush headlong into battle, forsaking support to close with our enemy? The learning curve here is a challenge.
But the one thing that I truly enjoy about this game is logging the game play afterwards. By taking the pile of discarded orders, you can effectively recreate the battle. The titles of the cards themselves provide the narrative. It's a metagame aspect to be sure, but [i]Commands & Colors: Ancients[/i] truly delivers on multiple fronts.

item.name: Condottiere
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/11/10, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Condottiere[/i] feels like a multiplayer adaptation of [i][thing=9446]Blue Moon[/thing][/i], with a dash of [i][thing=372]Schotten-Totten[/thing][/i] or I suppose the more appropriately-themed [i][thing=760]Battle Line[/thing][/i] for flavor. That may sound like a good thing, as [i][thing=372]Schotten-Totten[/thing][/i] is a "10" in my book: I think the tension added by the inclusion of "proofs" to capture stones is exquisite. In [i]Condottiere[/i], players are trying to capture provinces in Renaissance-era Italy. [b]Yawn![/b] [thing=8045]Haven't[/thing] [thing=555]we[/thing] [thing=46]seen[/thing] [thing=35572]this[/thing] [thing=24762]before?[/thing] If one player captures any five territories or three adjacent ones then she wins, just like [i][thing=760]Battle Line[/thing][/i].
The struggle for control of a province is conducted by playing cards in a fashion that feels very similar to [i][thing=9446]Blue Moon[/thing][/i]: play one card at a time, and announce your "line strength." Special power cards allow you to affect the cards in play. It works well, and leads to unpredictably wild outcomes as you may decide to stop contributing to your line in the belief that you have the province wrapped up, only to see your line gutted and then be unable to fortify it.
If I'm being fair, then [i]Condottiere[/i] was probably an excellent game when it was originally released in 1995. [i][thing=372]Schotten-Totten[/thing][/i] was developed in 1999, and [i][thing=9446]Blue Moon[/thing][/i] in 2004. It's very possible that the [person=2]Good Doctor[/person] was inspired by it. In today's market, [i]Condottiere[/i] has a difficult time making it to the table over better entries. If I want a 2p game, then I'll choose [i][thing=372]Schotten-Totten[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=9446]Blue Moon[/thing][/i]. If I want a multiplayer game, then there's always [i][thing=21882]Blue Moon City[/thing][/i].
Despite its uninspiring gameplay, there are two areas where [i]Condottiere[/i] stands out. First, it scales up to six players, and I suspect that it gets better with more players. Second, the [geekurl=/boardgameversion/27409]Fantasy Flight Silver Line version[/geekurl] is packed into a very small box. Compact games are always nice to find.

Exploration and colonization is a tried and true theme that I like very much, and the nautical aspects are appreciated by this Navy man!

item.name: Copycat
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 3/25/16, Rated: 6[/i]
You've read the blurb about the games from which Friedemann drew inspiration. Heck, most of the other comments mention them as well. I like the baldfaced audacity of blatantly stating "I'm copying," and love the fact that the other designers allowed it. I don't fault the creative process this game followed at all.
But a bit like Frankenstein's monster animated by mechanical means, this game lacks a soul.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/19/09, Rated: 9[/i]
This rating is based on the version of the game released in 2000 by [company=4871]Avalon Hill[/company]. Yes, I know there are a lot of people who say that it is the worst version of them all. Still, this is the only version I know, and my family enjoys it immensely.
I can't believe that original design for this game is over thirty years old! The rules are streamlined and easy to understand. The ability for each alien race to break those rules in its own fashion feels like a more modern title, and adds a vast amount of replayability.
We particularly enjoy using the order disks to determine which player will be attacked: they remove any guilt or resentment from choosing to pick on someone. A player who accepts an alliance request isn't so immune from blame: there is still plenty of opportunity to build up resentment and to exact your revenge.
The board in this version is cleverly designed, with options supporting 2-4 players. My sons love putting their fighters into the Mothership, or into their Carriers when assisting with a planet's defense.
A game with simple rules, offers lots of player interaction, and has fun components. That's a sure-fire winner in my book. I'll make a 1-point concession for those nay-sayers who say the older version with more powers and flares is even better. Perhaps I'll need to pick up the newly-released [thing=39463]version by Fantasy Flight Games[/thing] as well.

Diamant
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/11/08, Rated: 8[/i]
I was first introduced to [i]Diamant[/i] on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BrettspielWelt[/url]. It felt like a big randomfest (yes, I just made up a new word, I hope you'll forgive my precocious nature), and I didn't care for it. Part of my reaction was due to my not fully understanding the rules, even though they aren't difficult. The good news was that it never lasted very long. Sometimes I even won, although I didn't know how I managed to do so.
Still...the game stuck with me. And when my sons displayed a tenacious appetite for "press your luck" games, I remembered it. Suddenly the Indiana Jones-esque (precocious) theme wasn't corny, it was cool. Browsing the gallery showed inviting, fun images instead of the sterile, computer-rendered ones from BSW. I decided it might be a game worth owning after all.
It turns out that [i]Diamant[/i] is a real gem when played face-to-face. It is an extremely easy game to teach, and provides an enjoyable, social experience. My family immediately took to it, and we've introduced it to other families with universal success. It is a perfect, light "filler" game, that has the added benefit of being playable by up to eight people. Despite my initial misgivings, [i]Diamant[/i] is a diamond in the rough.
item.conditiontext: [geekurl=/geekmarket/sale/details/33820]BoardGameGeek Order #33820.[/geekurl] 1st edition of German version (with the board!). Complete and in excellent condition. The paint on the adventurer-meeples is starting to look more like a wash after many plays.

item.name: Diamonds Club
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/10/09, Rated: 9[/i]
[person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person] has done it again!
I received a copy of [i]Diamonds Club[/i] from my [geekurl=/user/SteveK2]2008 Secret Santa[/geekurl]. I hadn't even heard of the game before then, which is surprising. The last Dorn title I tried was [i][thing=25643]Arkadia[/thing][/i], which I really enjoyed. [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] is a personal favorite. And then there is [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i], which is a classic. I should be monitoring his games more closely.
Speaking of [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i], I immediately felt there was a similarity between it and [i]Diamonds Club[/i]. The board is essentially a frame, into which are placed randomly-selected strips. Once completed, this board forms the "market" of actions on which players will be bidding. Each player's bid ends up increasing the cost of orthogonally-adjacent actions for future buyers. In this manner, players can effect each other's options based on what has been selected on a variable board. It's not the exact same scenario as the staged tiles and contiguous paths from [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i], but it feels familiar.
Actions result in set creation as well as a competition to be the starting player. There are bonuses available for investing in the starting order, as well as finishing the buying round with the most unused coins. These benefits offer additional possibilities if you cannot afford the actions you want to purchase (or if they have already been taken).
Collecting sets leads to acquiring gems. Gems are essentially different forms of currency. If we were talking about [i][thing=6249]Alhambra[/thing][/i], then we'd be using cards. I like the fact that gems are used instead of cards: they give the game a more unique feel. Gems are used to buy additions to your park, which is another form of set collection, and also what determines most of your victory points.
There are also three "technology tracks" in which you can invest. This aspect of the game also feels like [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i], with only three options instead of five. These tracks represent long-term investments.
At first glance, the goal would be to acquire your actions at reasonable costs, convert them to gems, and then expand your park as efficiently as possible. However, it's not quite that simple. You can't keep a completed set of gem-collecting tiles from one turn to the next. There are a limited number of spaces to buy park improvements. Therefore the idea of hoarding your gems and taking your time to improve your park will fail when another player fills up her board, and all of your wealth cannot afford you the opportunity to buy enough tiles. I [i]love[/i] the tension, and the sense of urgency that this dilemma creates!
I have to say that this theme isn't the most logical, or compelling one I've ever encountered, although it is very family-friendly. There are many decisions to make, but each one is simple enough that the game is not a brain-burner. [i]Diamonds Club[/i] is an excellent game which may end up earning its way into the pantheon of "10" games.

item.name: Dice Forge
item.wishlistcomment:
I have [i][thing=150146][/thing][/i] and really like the idea of "dice building" -- literally creating the dice you're going to roll -- but the rest of the game is so bland it's off-putting. [i]Dice Forge[/i] has the same central mechanism of dice building, but is supposed to be a huge improvement on the rest of the game.
Interest in this has waned since [i][thing=269734][/thing][/i] includes this same "dice forging" mechanism.
Side note: I realize that games like [i][thing=91536][/thing][/i] are considered "dice builders" as you are building your dice pool. Perhaps they should be called "dice pool builders, else I need a different descriptor for [i]Dice Forge[/i].

item.name: Dice Realms: Trade Expansion
item.wishlistcomment:
The idea of being able to customize your dice by prying off the faces and adding new ones was first attempted by [i][thing=150146][/thing][/i]. While the mechanic worked, it was unfortunately not a very good game.
[i][thing=288080][/thing][/i] gets closer, but isn't quite there. It needs a little more oomph. If I had to come up with an analogy, it's like [i][thing=194607][/thing][/i] without any expansions: fast and forgettable.
With the added die faces, events, and play options in this expansion, we may finally have a worthy implementation of this fun mechanic. It's also an upgrade for 1st edition owners of the base game (like me) to the 2nd edition!

item.name: Don't Break the Ice
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9/1/05, Rated: 1[/i]
This child's game is quite simply the most frustrating thing I have ever played. It takes five minutes to place all of the cubes into the frame, and about five seconds for my sons to bust them all out.
Okay, that's an exaggeration on both ends, but it feels like my reality. To make matters worse, you have to disassemble the frame to get it to fit inside of the box. It comes apart so abruptly that if you're not careful, you will scrape some skin off of your fingers in the process. Its only redeeming feature is that it comes with hammers instead of ice picks. Ice picks would be easier tools with which I could gouge out my own eyes instead of playing this game.

item.name: Don't Spill the Beans
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9/23/05, Rated: 2[/i]
I'm starting to see a trend here: don't play kids games with [i]Don't[/i] in the title ([i][thing=4888]Don't Break the Ice[/thing][/i] is the other). I really dislike this game because it is too easy to nudge the pot when placing a bean. Too much friction between the posts and the forks inside of which the pot rests can catch the pot in a severely-tilted position with only one or two beans on top. Time required to get rid of all of your beans greatly exceeds the novelty of the tilting mechanism. Even my two children end up yelling at each other when they play. "Don't buy this bean game."

item.name: Double or Nothing
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/21/08, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Double or Nothing[/i] is another light filler game from Reiner Knizia. Instead of having convoluted scoring rules, the game has been distilled to its purest essence. It is a textbook example of how to create a push your luck game. Every desirable facet is present: stay in as long as you dare, long shots for big payouts, and a nice dash of "screw your neighbor" for flavor. The game can end suddenly, so you have to maximize your every scoring opportunity.
Despite these streamlined mechanics, it's spartan composition fails to be engaging. Knizia has been accused many times over of "pasting" a theme onto his games. In the case of [i]Double or Nothing[/i] that theme is of standard [i][thing=1115]Poker[/thing][/i] suits. Does it get any more bland than that? I've seen those in spades, if you'll pardon the pun. Some people have said that [i]Double or Nothing[/i] is a gambling game. I could argue that any "push your luck" game is a form of gambling, but here the theme supports this impression. At least [i]try[/i] to do something more interesting.
If you're going to make a card game about [i]cards[/i], then at the very least your cards ought to be good ones. This is another area of disappointment: the cards in [i]Double or Nothing[/i] are slightly larger than a standard Bridge deck. They are floppy. Their exaggerated linen finish makes them stick to each other. The graphics are simplistic, having been created with the same brutal efficiency as the rules. The scoring track is reminiscent of a [i][thing=2398]Cribbage[/thing][/i] board. I keep thinking that I should be able to create this game from components which I already own.
[i]Double or Nothing[/i] is an enjoyable game. My expectations were pretty low since it was offered for free (plus shipping) on Tanga over the holidays. I was pleasantly surprised by it. But if I had to pay double for it, then I'd choose "nothing" and look elsewhere.

item.name: Dragon Parade
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/7/07, Rated: 5[/i]
Let's be honest, shall we? No amount of wishing is going to turn [i]Dragon Parade[/i] into [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i], or [i][thing=12]Ra[/thing][/i]. To rate this game with those expectations would be unfair. [i]Dragon Parade[/i] is an extremely light filler game. Judging the game for what it is, the question becomes how does it stand up against other fillers like [i][thing=337]Circus Flohcati[/thing][/i], or [i][thing=172]For Sale[/thing][/i]? I had a lukewarm response.
The game looks great. The "dragoneeple" is a cool piece. The artwork on the board is attractive, and the large coins with their square punch-outs are novel. [i]Dragon Parade[/i] is a fun game to bring to the table. Once you set it up, though, your options are quite limited. From a hand of six cards, you spend the first three rounds playing a card, and moving the dragon to the right, or to the left. After each move, you place a "vendor" on the board at a location which you think will be close to the dragon's final position. There are some restrictions for where you can place vendors that are intertwined with the typically creative scoring found in a Knizia game. Each player then discards two cards, and a final round ensues in which each player moves the dragon once more. The board is then scored. In [i]Dragon Parade,[/i] the scoring radiates out from the dragon. There is an extra bonus for someone who correctly guessed its final location. A gaming session is comprised of a number of games equal to the number of players so that everyone can be the starting player once.
There are some subtleties to the game, but these are readily apparent. If you're strong in one color, you can try to keep the dragon on one side of the board. If you have the the last vendor closest to the edge on that side, you could try to move the dragon off of the edge and trigger an early end to the game. In my gaming session, the dragon hovers close to the middle as my family tries to prevent such a runaway strategy. We place our vendors so that we maximize our chances of scoring points, without necessarily guessing the final position. Sometimes one of us will get lucky, and that person usually ends up winning the overall contest.
With such simplified game play, [i]Dragon Parade[/i] doesn't arouse any passion in me. It does have the benefits of being small (9" x 6" x 1½"), and for being a filler game that supports 2-5 people. I first want to take a look at [i][thing=2569]Pick Picknic[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=15410]Walk the Dogs[/thing][/i] before I recommend this title.

item.name: Dueltrack: A Car Wars Deluxe Supplement
The Duke: Lord's Legacy
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/14/20, Rated: 6[/i]
TL, DR: It's good, but not as good as [i][thing=160477][/thing][/i].
[i]The Duke[/i] employs enjoyment through uncertainty, which to me doesn't belong in an abstract. The conceit is that pieces have two movement modes. It's as if the designer thought "wouldn't it be cool if this rook could move normally and then move like a bishop?" When familiarizing myself with the game, I was always picking up my pieces to see what they would do next. The rules even state that part of the fun of the game is trying to remember all of the combinations!
Umm..[i].no.[/i]
Fortunately, there are reference pages available in the manual. I need to print those out and laminate them. Once I get past that obstacle, the insurmountable one is the draw bag. You start with three basic pieces, your Duke and two Footmen. Any time you choose to introduce a new piece on the board, you draw it from a bag and then place it in an orthogonally adjacent space to your Duke. Here's the thing: you obviously don't know which piece you're going to draw.
You could draw a bunch of basic pieces while your opponent draws awesome ones. Sure, you will have to adjust your game accordingly, but again I don't favorably view such uncertainty in an abstract game. Maybe you will appreciate this introduction of randomness, and if so then cool! I prefer to plan ahead. Compare this to [i]Onitama[/i] where the randomness is found in which five movement cards will be available during the game and [i]will never change[/i]: so much better! I can (and should!) influence how my opponent will be able to move.
The production on the game is very good. I have a dark Footman tile that got munched in production, but otherwise the screen printing is good on all of the chunky wooden tiles. Only time will tell if it starts to scrape off when they're jostled inside of the draw bags. If you're a fan of abstract games and don't mind a healthy dose of randomness, then give it a shot. For me, I'd rather play [i]Onitama[/i] or perhaps even [i][thing=146278]Tash-Kalar[/thing][/i].

item.name: Dune: Imperium
item.comment:
[b][media=476137]Replayable Episode 2[/media][/b]
[i]Posted: 27 JUN 2024, Rated: 10[/i] {1P: 9, 2P: 9, 3P: 10, 4P: 10}
What a perfect blend of game mechanics and themed ideas. I absolutely adore the way that the icons on the cards in your hand control where you can place your Agents. That you have to decide whether to use a card for its placement power, or save it for its reveal abilities. That you have to balance your Influence with the four main factions with your military might in the Conflicts. And so on.
This is no easy game to understand at first. Rather, the mechanics are simple enough, but knowing when to go all-in on the Conflict versus your purchasing opportunities from the Imperium Row, to gauging your opponents' abilities to take the spots you want. Do they not have 6 Spice yet? Then you probably don't have to worry about them beating you to Heighliner, and you can take another turn.
I have the [i][thing=324114][/thing][/i], and have painted most of the miniatures. With that, this game is a 11. But it's pretty near perfect even without it.

Elfenland
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1998[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 1998[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 4/17/06, Rated: 6[/i]
I had read a lot about [i]Elfenland[/i] before I actually got around to playing it. How it wasn't complete without [i][thing=158]Elfengold[/thing][/i]. I was still interested in playing the game that was awarded the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i] (SdJ) in 1998.
The game is basically the "traveling salesman" problem: you have 20 cities to visit, and you must do so as efficiently as possible. To turn this classic computer science exercise into a game, Alan Moon added cards, tiles, and of course, [i]opponents.[/i]
These factors introduce a high degree of luck into the game. First, you are dealt cards. Your cards will be used to pay for travel. The type of travel you do is determined by tiles, which you will draw next. You lay the tiles along the roads before you can move. Some modes of transportation are better-suited for the varying terrain. Unicorns can run quickly through the woods, but surprisingly they cannot run across open fields. If you're lucky, you have the right cards, for the right tiles, that are efficient for the terrain over which you want to travel, and nobody else ruins your carefully laid plains.
Yeah, [i]right.[/i]
Obviously, the game is about doing the best you can with what you have, even when it falls far short of that ideal. I enjoy this game more than [i][thing=110]Auf Achse[/thing][/i]. The theme is well done, and the pieces are of a high quality. It can suffer from long downtimes in between turns, if people are constantly trying to recalculate their best routes after an opponent's tile has thwarted their original plans. Maybe that skill will improve with practice, or maybe we should bring in a computer science major to streamline the process.

item.name: Enchanted Forest
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1982[/b]
[i]Posted: 11/30/07, Rated: 6[/i]
You never know what you'll find as you play through the older recipients of the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i]. In the case of [i]Enchanted Forest,[/i] you will find a roll-and-move game. The first objective is to follow the intertwining paths around the board, peeking under the trees to find the King's treasures. A stack of placards at one end of the board displays the next treasure the King wants found. Race to the castle, reveal the correct location, and claim your prize.
There are a few wrinkles: on your turn, you roll two dice. You move a distance equal to the number of pips on one die, then have the option of changing direction for the movement value on the second die. This flexibility adds a modicum of control to the game. Landing on another player's token with either movement value sends them back to the beginning. If you roll doubles, you can use "magic" to take some special actions. These twists do add some extra options to the game: if you can't stop someone from reaching the castle, you still might be able to shuffle the deck and reveal a treasure whose location is unknown to them (by rolling doubles).
[i]Enchanted Forest[/i] is also a memory game. Remember what you've seen, and where you saw it. You may glean additional information about "not" locations if your opponents reach the castle and guess incorrectly (resulting in their being sent back to the beginning).
The theme is one of a fairy tale kingdom, with the treasures to match: Puss's boots, Cinderella's slipper, Sleeping Beauty's spindle, etc. My sons love to play, although they usually don't pay enough attention. I find the game to be quick, light fare: we could definitely do worse. I'd give [i]Enchanted Forest[/i] a honeymoon score of "7," and then let it settle to a "6."
[i]Refreshed: 11/1/10[/i]

Euphrates & Tigris: Contest of Kings
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/3/09, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: 8, 4P: ???}
It was bound to happen: after so many [thing=533]card[/thing] [thing=8217]game[/thing] [thing=12589]ports[/thing] of [thing=437]successful[/thing], [thing=3076]larger[/thing] [thing=12]games[/thing], it was only a matter of time before [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i] was given the same treatment. To a seemingly vast number of BGG users, modifying such a classic title is pure heresy. However, I must admit that I was intrigued by the idea. I have found card game versions to be satisfying, and in at least [thing=27364]one case[/thing] more enjoyable than its [thing=18602]progenitor[/thing]. My expectations of such an adaptation are a streamlined set of rules, which provide a gaming experience that is reminiscent of the progenitor title, while offering increased portability. As my collection swells, I value packaging efficiency more and more dearly. As I type this, I think that "most bang for your [storage space] buck" would make for an interesting GeekList.
[i]Euphrates & Tigris Card Game (ETCG)[/i] definitely provides a nostalgic experience. With an initial card setup that reminds me of the stones in [i][thing=372]Schotten-Totten[/thing][/i], [person=2]Knizia[/person] manages to capture the same sense of turn angst that is present in the original game. The unease felt as spaces between kingdoms dwindled with each tile is successfully mirrored as the number of cards in each column grows. The old familiar faces of internal and external conflicts are back. And while it may seem redundant to say that card games use a lot of cards, by no means do they need to be exclusively comprised of them. The wooden leader disks are also here. Simply put, there is no mistaking this game's heritage.
The rules are definitely streamlined. Instead of two catastrophe tiles, each player has only one such card. The six monuments comprised of all of the color pairings have been replaced by three ships, each of which has blue as a common color. I would hazard a guess that it is due to the lack of a board with pre-printed river spaces. The player screens are also gone, which only makes sense as cards provide a natural way to conceal their values.
For all of the similarities, there are a couple of items that I wish were different. The first has to do with tracking your score. In [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i], players keep their scoring cubes behind their screens. This mechanic creates hidden but trackable information. The pros and cons of this type of data has been thoroughly discussed in [thread=110984]a favorite thread of mine[/thread]. In [i]ETCG[/i], players' points form a face-up stack of cards. Players are not allowed to look through these stacks, not even their own. A stated variation allows players to create four stacks (one per color), so that the "number of points are visible to everyone." I dislike both approaches. I assume that they prevent players from cheating, since cards represent both tiles and victory points. I would prefer to trust my gaming friends, and adopt a house rule allowing players to look at their own, face-down scoring stacks.
The other objection I have with the game is more of a nit pick. In the original game, a player whose Trader is present when two kingdoms are connected may have a choice between two treasures. This player must choose one of the four corner treasures first, if it is an option. This small, seemingly insignificant rule is very effective at focusing the game's development towards the center of the board. However, there is no such provision in [i]ETCG[/i]. It is easy for a player to "hide" a treasure on the edges of the layout. I am going to try another house rule which requires treasures to be taken from the outside edges first, when there is a choice.
The changes in [i]ETCG[/i] aren't all bad. The one area where I think this game truly shines is in the earning of victory points. When a player can score a point, she places a card of the appropriate color from her hand onto her stack of scoring cards. If she cannot play such a card or [i]chooses not to[/i], then she does not score the point! Now I have to pause to consider whether I want to use all of my red Temple cards for an internal conflict, or if I want to save one so that I can swap out a Treasure card on my next action (after an external conflict). If my Trader is connected to the blue/green Ship card, then I may not use all of my green Market cards in an external conflict so that I can score a point at the end of my turn. This simple, clean mechanic works wonders, and gives [i]ETCG[/i] its own, unique personality.
During game play, [i]ETCG[/i] does take up a fair amount of room on the table. I don't mind. I'm more concerned about the amount of storage space required in my cabinets, or in my suitcase. It is smaller than the original [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i] (I have the Mayfair version), but that's not saying much; there is still a lot of "box bloat," here. I can envision a different insert which would allow the cards to be stacked on their sides, in a single row, as opposed to the two "drop holes" which are provided. Two more channels with rounded bottoms could be used to store eight leader disks, each. Such a configuration would likely reduce the overall volume of the box by at least sixty percent. If I were better at crafts, then I could try to create a prototype myself to take on the road.
[i]Euphrates & Tigris Card Game[/i] provides a gaming experience that is familiar, and that shows its lineage. For the most part, the rules are as elegant as is expected given the source material. The pivotal mechanic of using cards from your hands as victory points, and deciding when to score them is a refreshing tactical consideration. It may not be everthing that is [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i], but then again it's not meant to be. If I'm at home, then I'll break out the larger game. If I'm assembling a few games to take on vacation, then a more compact version of [i]ETCG[/i] can still scratch that strategy gaming itch in a lot less space.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 8th Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 3/25/16, Rated: 7[/i]
I was originally learned [i]Fearsome Floors[/i] on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/Spiele/FinstereFlure/]BSW[/url], although it has since been archived there. It was a light, fun game that I didn't really understand. I didn't remember much about it except its quirky name. Then [i][thing=175878][/thing][/i] was released, and with it a desire to revisit all things [designer=141][/designer]. I wanted to revisit [i]Fearsome Floors[/i], only this time playing it at the table.
Think "B movie horror," and you'll have the right idea about this game's theme. The players move their character discs on the board, and then the monster moves a certain number of steps according to a simple algorithm. He looks to the left, to the right, and straight ahead. If he sees someone, then he walks towards him. If he sees multiple people, then we walks towards the closest person. And if he doesn't see anyone, then he continues walking straight ahead. The monster reevaluates his next move after each step.
This algorithm can be exploited, and herein lies the real fun in this game: it is possible to lure the monster towards one of your characters, and in so doing have him see an opponent's character that was previously safe. Om, nom, nom! It's a devlish delight seeing your doppelganger devoured in such a fashion.
It also makes [i]Fearsome Floors[/i] the only [b]indirect[/b] programming game I know. Games like [i][thing=18][/thing][/i] or [i][thing=126239][/thing][/i] allow you to program your robot directly. You can't program Furunkulus, but you can influence where he goes, and it is very satisfying.
[i]Fearsome Floors[/i] is thus a light game that can nevertheless surprise you with thinky problems. Should I unerringly advance towards the exit, or should I take a turn to be safe and then move? The artwork is perfectly campy to match the B movie theme. It's a game that doesn't take itself too seriously and yet still delivers some good tension.

Normally "train game" and "Friedemann Friese" don't go together.
It gets even weirder. This game has been accused of having "lumpy" scoring, and a non-intuitive building system that doesn't feel much like trains.
Responding to claims that his bairn was beastly, Friedemann Friese [blogpost=152703]defended his decision[/blogpost]: "I hate that in almost all modern VP games that my focus while gaming is directed to micro-optimizing points...in the end the person who does micro-VP calculations best wins because everything else is so balanced that it is unimportant."
I have to admit that I am more interested in this game, now!

Fjords
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/29/13, Rated: 8[/i]
The meta story: I never pulled the trigger on this little game when it was readily available. Now it is out of print, and I was fortunate enough to pick up a copy in a reasonable trade. Even though I feel like I got a good deal on a game that is in high demand, I am inclined to think well of it to justify having traded away more in value for it than I would have paid just a few years ago.
Additionally, [person=57][/person] passed away back in 2007. I have several of his games, and I am always [article=5517877]saddened[/article] when I think that he is no longer here to share his passion for designing games with us. This melancholy makes me inclined to think well of his games.
So it should come as no surprise that I ended up liking this game. The artwork is reminiscent of [i][thing=822][/thing][/i], even though the artists are not the same. Tile laying and then optionally playing a meeple-like farm only further the comparison. It is a poor comparison though, as [i]Fjords[/i] is its own game.
The first phase of a game round spent laying tiles. As you go you can play your farms, which are the anchor points for claiming your territory in the second phase. This idea of building the board before playing upon it is reminiscent of [i][thing=4099][/thing][/i], or a 2D version of [i][thing=24508][/thing][/i]. I really enjoy this mechanism.
The second phase is spent placing "fields" in such a way as to limit the options of your opponent. Think [i][thing=503][/thing][/i], or a ridiculously simplified version of [i][thing=188][/thing][/i]. Where [i]Fjords[/i] shines is in its streamlined nature: an entire round will be over in fifteen minutes, maybe sooner. Play three separate rounds (starting anew each time; only your score carries over), and you're done.
A quick game that is visually appealing, contains classic elements of strategy, and doesn't take up a lot of space is a surefire winner. I only wish that I could thank its designer personally for creating such a gem.

item.name: Fleet
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Fleet[/i] had good buzz at BGG.con 2012. The sailor in me loves the theme as well. Beyond those two things, I don't know much about it except for the fact that it is very portable -- which is also a good thing.

item.name: Focus
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1981[/b]
[i]Posted: 6/11/06, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Focus[/i] is an interesting beast for several reasons, not the least of which is due to its being hard to find these days. Even under its pseudonym [i]Domination[/i] it can be a challenge to find a copy. Its strange, octagonal board and goofy plastic Easter egg-looking pieces definitely herald an earlier age of board gaming. Is this game really worth all of the effort?
The answer to that question depends upon you. If you are a fan of abstract games, then the easy answer is "yes." [i]Focus[/i] is an excellent abstract game that can be played with 2-4 players. This flexibility is a marked improvement over other titles such as the entire [family=10]Project GIPF family[/family]. The corollary to this statement is that you need 1-3 friends who also love abstract games for it to matter.
The game itself plays very similarly to [i][thing=2346]DVONN[/thing][/i]: pieces stack, and in turn the height of the stack determines how far it may subsequently move. Unlike that other title, in [i]Focus[/i] there is a renewing element of "reserves:" pieces which are returned to their owner if a stack exceeds a height of five. You can also capture your opponents' pieces through stacking. The board has a fixed starting layout which varies according to the number of players, as opposed to the alternating placement of stones in [i][thing=2346]DVONN[/thing][/i]. These traits lend [i]Focus[/i] a feeling of a more scripted experience.
I originally picked up a copy because I collect games which have won the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i]. I enjoy [i]Focus[/i] every time I play it, but I honestly don't get to play it that often. Multiplayer abstract games fill a very small niche, and address a similarly-sized demographic within my game-playing friends.
item.conditiontext: Franckh-Kosmos edition, © 1995. Game was shipped after being wrapped in bubblewrap and brown paper, so one long side of the box is crushed a bit. Complete; board and game pieces in excellent condition.

item.name: Forbidden Desert: Storm Tracker Gear Card
Forbidden Island
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/2/10, Rated: 7[/i]
"It's [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] lite!" Yes, and no.
At first blush, [person=378]Matt Leacock[/person] didn't have to look much further than his first cooperative title for mechanics. Let's see: multiple roles with special powers, four somethings that must be discovered by turning in matching sets of cards, and an event deck whose revealed cards are recycled each time a negative card is found. Yep, sounds like [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] but without that whole disease mess.
However, there are significant differences that lend [i]Forbidden Island[/i] its own unique identity. The first is a modular board constructed from 24 tiles which are placed randomly. Think [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] without the spaces. Instead of finding cures for diseases, players are looking for four ancient artifacts. Each artifact can only be discovered on two [-]research stations[/-] temple tiles (two for each artifact; eight temples in total). And instead of having cities rise in infection, the island is sinking beneath the water as you go.
And here is where [i]Forbidden Island[/i] really comes into its own. You know that whole "three cubes and then outbreak" mechanic from [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i]? If you don't, then go [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/Spiele/Pandemie/]try it online for free[/url] on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BSW[/url]. [i]Now[/i]. I'll wait. In [i]Forbidden Island[/i], it's two strikes and then you're sunk. If you don't "shore up" the flooding, then an island tile will be removed from play after only two appearances of its card in the event deck. More importantly, its matching card is also removed. This means that the event deck is [i]always[/i] going to do something bad to you; No "free actions" if you've found the cure to Black, and a black city is drawn.
This simple change makes a huge difference. The island really feels like it's sinking. There are also new conditions for losing the game: if both Temples for a particular artifact sink before you have retrieved that artifact, then you lose. And if your escape tile "Fools Landing" ever sinks, then you lose. It's a mad rush to the finish, as you try to keep avenues open for your characters to use.
The last thing I want to mention is the "box." It is actually a tin, with a plastic insert inside that stores all of the components well. The artwork on all of the cards, tiles, and the tin is fantastic. [i]Forbidden Island[/i] may sound like [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] lite, but it does have its own character. It doesn't offer the same amount of depth, and I ultimately question its replay value over time, which is why I didn't rate it as highly. It looks great, is easy to teach, comes in a very attractive and portable tin, and can quickly scratch your itch for a cooperative game.

item.name: Formula Dé
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/18/09, Rated: 9[/i]
I purchased this game over two years ago, a copy from the final printing. I had read so much about it, and I didn't want to miss out. Of course, at that time I had no idea that [i][thing=37904]Formula D[/thing][/i] was in the works. I was tempted to pick up a copy of the newer title after watching [url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=117]Scott Nicholson's review[/url], and then remembered that I had never played the original. It was time to give it a try.
[i]Formula Dé[/i] is a great game. Yes, it has dice. Wonderful, colorful, quirky dice. They're fun to roll. It's exciting to get into the higher gears and see how far your car can move.
There are also tear sheets. I absolutely despise the decision to include [i]consumable[/i] components in games. Yeah, I'm talking to you, [i][thing=915]Mystery of the Abbey[/thing][/i]. Even you, my beloved [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i]. Just don't do it, okay? Consumable items are a direct affront to my obsession for keeping my games in pristine condition. How did I alleviate this condition with [i]Formula Dé[/i]? I scanned in the sheets, added some color to the boxes, and then borrowed the resource cubes from [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i]. Voilà! Instant Eurogame feel. In fact, I think playing the game with resource cubes instead of marking on scratch pads makes it even better.
The downside to the basic game at least is the advantage conferred upon the driver sitting in the pole position: when that person wins the game, then it feels like the entire game was decided with the initial role for turn order. Minus one point for this perception.
Taking a risk through the turns to usurp the lead position can pay off when you get to move first in the next turn. I highly recommend enforcing a house rule where players cannot count the moves out ahead of time: move your car, and you're not allowed to backtrack to find a better route. You can count the spaces ahead of you after your turn is over; doing so helps to prevent down time. My family quickly pushed their cars to the limits in an effort to take the lead. And therein lies a now-surprising attribute of this game: player elimination. Push your car too hard, and you are out of the game. Get unlucky with your collision rolls, and you can be knocked out of the race. It's a refreshing twist for a Eurogame.
[i]Formula Dé[/i] is a crowd pleaser. If you don't mind roll-and-move with a little resource management to boot, then I recommend that you race out and pick up a copy of [i][thing=37904]Formula D[/thing][/i]. My only regret is that by the time I had purchased this game, all of the old tracks were long out of print. Here's hoping that [company=157]Asmodée[/company] reprints them for use with their new game.

item.name: Forum Trajanum
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/14/18, Rated: 7[/i]
My opening "hot game" of this year's BGG.con. Had to learn it from the rulebook, which while functional was still a bit of a slog due to all of the special powers.
Quick summary: pull citizen tiles off of your [i]colonia[/i] (player board), keep one, pass one, and then decide which of the two tiles you're holding to use in order to gather resources. Use these resources to do other things, and then choose a building action. Choosing actions and buildings will offer you the opportunity to advance on four different tracks (library, market, vendor, and upgrade), plus one contiguous area puzzle.
Typical Feld game in which most of the time you feel like you're working in your own world, and then looking up to see how you're faring against your competition. Could be some volatility due to the randomness of drawing tiles from your board, and what you're given each round. Might be too rigorous for this foundation, but still fun figuring out the puzzle.
item.wishlistcomment: Played at BGG.con 2018. Brain-burning in typical Feld fashion with too much to do each turn, but I really enjoyed it. Much better than [i][thing=230933][/thing][/i]. Which isn't to say the two games are alike; they're not. I'm only comparing this year's Feld entry to last year's.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/10/04, Rated: 2[/i]
The main problem with this game is that it simply isn't interesting. The only real choices you have are represented by the career fork early in the game, and then if you want to play the stock market later (optional rules). The rest of it is spin-and-move, with little chance for decision making.
[i]The Game of Life[/i]'s theme is too mature for young gamers, and its gameplay is too simplistic for older ones. It fails on just about every level. Most parents can be talked into suffering through it again for the benefit of children -- who are probably going to be more interested in playing with the small cars than really caring about the game itself. Buy Hot Wheels instead.
[i]Updated: 10/23/05, Rated: 3[/i]
I can't believe I'm going to say this, but I actually enjoyed playing this game today, after it was requested by my seven year-old son. I decided if we were going to play, then it would be by the rules, including the stock market, side bets, and "share the wealth" cards -- items that had fallen by the wayside in all of the games that I had played growing up.
Don't get me wrong: a "3" is still a miserable score. But I would choose to play it again over, say, drinking a cup of hemlock.

item.name: The Generals
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9/7/05, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]The Generals[/i] is a better version of [i][thing=1917]Stratego[/thing][/i]. There are a few differences: privates can only move one space during their turn. There are no bombs, and no blocked squares on the board. Flags can move. There are two agents, and they will win any battle except one against a private, regardless of who initiated the attack.
The main difference, however, was the introduction of a conflict resolution computer. When an attack occurs, both players take their pieces off of the contested square, and press them into the sensor pads of the computer (there is an attack marker that is used as a placeholder). After a few series of beeps, the winner is revealed by an LED. In the case of a draw, both LED's light up. If you captured your opponent's flag, "Taps" is played.
The fact that a piece's identity is never revealed greatly enhances the tension of the game. The game board and box were cumbersome, but this is one title that should be remade.
item.conditiontext: Fully functioning computer. Box has quite a bit of wear, [-]but no split corners[/-]. Strike that. Overenthusiastic children pulling the box out by the lip of the cover have caused one corner to split. Grrr.

item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/11/10, Rated: 8[/i]
The last of the "[geekurl=/tag/sdj-winner+dsp-winner/user/Beowulf]double headers[/geekurl]" (winners of both the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i] and the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Deutscher_Spiele_Preis]Deutscher Spiele Preis[/geekurl][/i]) to make it to my table.
It's a bit hard to keep track of the number of [i]caballeros[/i] each player has in the [i]castillo[/i], which is an essential detail during the scoring rounds. It's going to take a few games to get my head around all of the action cards: sometimes a move designed to get more cubes on the board turns out to be suboptimal when your opponent seizes an easy score. Plus the sequencing of the power cards is important: playing the "1" not only allows you to summon six [i]cabelleros[/i] to your court, doing so also ensures you will be the first person to go in the next round. That's particularly useful in the rounds before scoring, e.g. 2, 5, and 8.
A lot of elegant moving parts to this one earn it a weight of "3 - medium."

item.name: Great Western Trail
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/25/19, Rated: 10[/i]
[person=11767][/person] wasn't on my radar until I played [i]Great Western Trail[/i]. I enjoyed the game, but it felt very crowded: there were too many things to try to keep track of. After more plays I grew to appreciate how the different mechanics were interwoven. How pulling on one lever adjusted something else over there. How focusing on buildings meant the herds you delivered weren't going to be as lucrative. How focusing on herds meant you weren't making as much progress along the track and thus paying more in delivery fees. The game really opened up to me. More importantly, each time I played was highly enjoyable, and I looked forward to playing it again. I still do.
I feel that there has been a trend for the past few years of creating games that are increasingly complex versions of multiplayer solitaire: I do my thing, you do yours, and at the end of the game we'll see who did better. Scoring can be very opaque until the end of the game. The enjoyment of games like that is figuring out the efficiencies, and realizing some are better than others, and by then you're done with that game and ready to move on to the next title.
[i]Great Western Trail[/i] has a fantastic balance between pursuing my own goals and still being able to meaningfully interact with the other players. And while it doesn't have an explicit scoring track, there are indicators that show you how well other players are doing. These dynamics make every game a tense, thrilling affair.
The game also scales reasonably well with the exception of tightness: there are spaces on the board for players to build their tiles. In a 2P game, the board is simply expansive. A 3P game is close, but comfortable. A 4P game is vicious. I enjoy the game at all counts, but it does have a different flavor at each. And I've been loving it for over two years; I don't expect that to change. Yeehaw!

item.name: Great Western Trail: Argentina
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 24 JAN 2023, Rated: 8[/i]
Does this replace [i]Great Western Trail[/i]?Hard to say. There’s enough complexity in [i]GWT[/i] to allow for strategic freedom, but it’s concise enough that you are still getting in each other’s way.
A lot has been added to GWT:A. This is more than a bolt-on board with extra decision options like Rails to the North. There are a couple more organs in this body. The result is that I rarely felt like I had been denied an effective play. There was one time when somonel took the farmer/[i]granjero[/i] that I wanted, but I was able to recover just fine. And we didn’t invest in tax buildings in a meaningful way so that it stopped me from buying what I wanted.
The whole shipping mechanism is a learning curve that accentuates the new currency, grain. There is a timing element to it that has knock-on effects in the middle rounds. I misplayed it at the start of our game. Maybe. It obviously wasn’t a fatal mistake as it would have been in a Splotter game.
Over 27 plays of [i]GWT[/i], the average playing time has been 2:15, with one exceptionally fast 3P game clocking in at 1:30. I don’t see GWT:A ever getting down to a 90-minute game.
I rate [i]GWT[/i] a “10.” There’s nowhere to go but down. Okay, maybe sideways. If you’re lucky. Early exit polls predict a best case finish of “9” for [i]GWT:A[/i].
item.wishlistcomment:
Let's chat. I'm a fan of [designer=11767][/designer], although I tend to be partial to the first versions of his games. I prefer [i][thing=156009][/thing][/i] to [i][thing=331265][/thing][/i], and [i][thing=172386][/thing][/i] to [i][thing=359438][/thing][/i].
So it shouldn't be a surprise that I prefer OG [i][thing=193738]GWT[/thing][/i] to [i][thing=341169]GWT2E[/thing][/i]. The small changes in 2E make it a softer game. OG is a 10. 2E is a 9.
Now we have a version that changes the map and introduces a new worker (the farmer). The balance of money and actions has meaningfully changed. I definitely want to check it out.

item.name: Great Western Trail: At the Poker Table
Great Western Trail: El Paso
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 20 MAY 2025, Rated: 5[/i] {1P: 6, 2P: ?, 3P: 5, 4P: 7*}
I am mad at this game. It takes a streamlined approach to one of my favorite games, which should be a Good Thing. Then Lookout Games made a bunch of production decisions that ruin the experience.
I'll get some bookkeeping out of the way first. BGG says that [i]El Paso[/i] reimplements [thing=193738]OG [i]GWT[/i][/thing]. Okay, sure. However, it actually reimplements [thing=341169][i]GWT 2E[/i][/thing], with the main differences from 1E being the addition of exchange tokens and Simmental cows. If BGG only wants to link a single game, then 2E is the correct choice.
[i]GWT: EP[/i] is a member of Lookout Games' Greeline label, which is meant to be more environmentally conscious. So is [i][thing=391163][/thing][/i]. I'm a fan. However, [i]Forest Shuffle[/i] gets an actual game board to use for its Clearing. [i]El Paso[/i] gets a cloth map, and it is ill-suited for its purpose.
First, there is a lot of information printed on this towel. While it can be read, it would be easier to read if it were printed on paper. Second, this rag is folded and doesn't lie flat. This causes problems with the round player markers. I'll get to that in a bit. Third, the insistence on using a napkin doesn't result in a meaningfully smaller box. [i][thing=160477][/thing][/i] uses a cloth board to good effect, and results in a much smaller box. That's not the case here. An actual game board of the same size could be folded in half and fit neatly in the box for [i]El Paso[/i].
Let's talk about those player markers. The wooden cowboys are laughably huge. "Chunky" doesn't do them justice. I assume they're so big because they need the extra mass to stand up on the cloth map that won't lie flat. When multiple players are on the same space, their cowboys will quickly run out of room. You can't see the tile underneath.
Conversely, the little cardboard discs that replace the wooden pieces in the original game are insufficient. They're not heavy enough to stay in place on the washcloth. Worse, they need to be stacked on the depot spaces. Since the sides aren't colored, it's hard to see if you already have a token without pulling the stack apart (note to self: color the sides in with permanent markers). I guess they're cheaper than wooden components, so chalk this up to cost conservation.
The player boards are made out of cardstock like they were in the original [i]GWT[/i]. Since the round markers and the certificate trackers are now made out of cardboard, the player board can't be a dual-layer board like [i]GWT: 2E[/i]. More cost savings.
All of these items are supposed to make the game more travel-friendly. I certainly couldn't play it reliably on a train, which means it'll have to wait until after I have arrived. "Travel-friendly" must mean more portable. See my previous comments about the box size.
In an effort to help with organization without resorting to plastic, Lookout Games provided a bunch of printed tuck boxes. I have nitpicks here, too. First, they're all the same size and in at least one case (coins), it's really too small. All four player color pieces go in the same box (execpt for the chunky cowboys). The tuck boxes lack a thumb cut, so they're hard to open and likely will rip after multiple attempts.
[b]These are not small gripes![/b] Physically interacting with the game components is an essential part of owning it. If all I want to do is play the game then I can do that [url=https://boardgamearena.com/gamepanel?game=elpasogwt]on Board Game Arena[/url] and save money. So now, let's talk about the actual game.
It's definitely [i]GWT[/i], with all of the edges removed. There are no teepee tiles for the Indian trade section (1E), or outlaw tiles for the outlaw section (2E). No hazard sections. No "tax" buildings or spaces that incur a fee. The entire cattle market is visible, and not randomly drawn. Likewise, all of the workers are available. All in all, it is a much friendlier game.
The key difference is in the workers, and how they are used. Your available workers are placed in your tableau. When you take an action that requires them, like using cowboys to buy cows, you move them to your discard pile. They won't be available to you again until you shuffle your discard pile back into your draw pile, and you draw them when refilling your hand. When you draw a worker, you immediately add it to your tableau and then draw a replacement card. Wash, rinse, and repeat until you're at your hand limit.
This creates an interesting dynamic where you are likely focusing on a different activity each time around the rondel: maybe you hire a cowboy and buy a cow this time around, and the next time you're building. The economy is much tighter, because you only get $5 when you deliver your herd to El Paso, regardless of its value. The net-net might be similar, as in the big games you had to move your engine along the train track in order to reduce your delivery costs.
I forgot to mention the coins. They also disappoint. The big games have copper-colored $1 coins, and silver $5 coins. For some unknown reason, Lookout Games decided to go with yellow-gold $1 coins, and gold-yellow $5 coins. Why not stick with what we already know?
In [i]El Paso[/i], the train track has been removed. In its place are a set of train cards. These are an action you can take if you discard engineers and pay money, and are the primary way for you to get objective and bonus tokens.
Playing the game feels like [i]Great Western Trail[/i], with a greater injection of luck. I've had turns where I want to buy a Shorthorn to satisfy an objective tile, but I can't because I didn't draw my cowboy cards in time. So I decide to over-invest in hiring cowboys, while another player got lucky with her draw and was able to diversify easily. The game plays faster so this type of luck is more acceptable, but be warned that it is present.
I'm going to harvest the coins and wooden player tokens from my 1E of [i]GWT[/i]. I'll sleeve the cards, and organize everything using plastic bags. I'll check to see if I can make my own PnP version of the board. If all those things work out, then I might increase the rating. Until then, it has earned its disappointing score.
* UPDATE: After harvesting all those components from [i]GWT 1E[/i], and playing the game with the cloth mat placed under a sheet of plexiglass, a 4P game was a 7. There was a lot of extra work and resoruces required to get it there.
item.wishlistcomment: I think this was recently announced as of 18 NOV 2024. A version of [thing=341169]one of my favorite games[/thing] that is faster and more accessible? Absolutely, yes!

item.name: Great Western Trail: Promo Station Master Tiles
Great Western Trail: Rails to the North
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/2/19, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Rails to the North[/i] adds one big thing, and a few little things. The big thing is a new delivery schedule that overlays the cities at the top of the board. This overlay includes routes into different regions, most of which have to be unlocked using a new basic action. That action requires you to discard a cow of value "2" in order to place a house. Placing settlements in this fashion opens up new routes and cities to which you can deliver your herds.
The net-net is that there are more options to consider which lengthens the game. In 2p or 3p that's fine, but I worry that a 4p game could stretch to 3½-4 hours which would be too long. Opening those routes means you will likely be making more stops before you ride into Kansas City. [i]Rails[/i] does enhance the viability of a pure engineer strategy, with some big point-earning cities available in the Northeast.
The little things the expansion include items which were previously available only as promotions: two station master tiles and two extra buildings per player. Then there are some more station master tiles that synergize with the new board, and finally some chits that you can use to draw and discard cards.
[i]Rails to the North[/i] adds some nice variety to [i]Great Western Trail[/i], but the base game is already so good that the expansion isn't required. Not unless you just can't get enough of the original, in which case having more things to consider is a welcome complication.

item.name: Great Western Trail: Second Edition
item.conditiontext: Very good. Showed up with a bruised corner. Repaired with some glue, but it is still noticeable. None of the components were affected.

item.name: Great Western Trail: Second Edition – Rails To The North
item.wishlistcomment:
An expansion that pulls me in two different directions. I own [thing=245744]the first edition[/thing], and it's good. One of the pitfalls for expansions is removing decision anxiety by offering more options: if you can't get your first choice then there's another one that is almost as good. [i]Rails to the North[/i] doesn't change the rondel of building spaces on the board, which is the primary source of player conflict and decision anxiety. It doesn't fall into the trap.
It adds options for herd delivery, with bonuses for the first player to claim them. It [b]adds[/b] decision anxiety, with a corresponding increase in playing time to consider these additional permutations. The increased time spend makes it an expansion that I would play with 3P max, and preferably only with 2.
I love all things [i]GWT[/i] so I will end up owning this version someday. I just don't know how much play it will get.

item.name: Guess Who?
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/15/06, Rated: 5[/i]
A fun little game that encourages observation and similarity recognition. My wife doesn't like the fact that I'll ask compound questions: "Do you have red or yellow hair?" but that question appears to be legal to me. My sons' favorite question is "Do you have a big fat nose?" which is absolutely brutal if the answer is "yes!"
The most fun to be had is when your opponent has whittled down your character options to one. You have one chance to pre-emptively guess who they might be. What an outburst if you guess correctly! More enjoyable than the typical kids' game.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 9th Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 1/26/08, Rated: 7[/i] {2P: 6, 3P: 8, 4P: 7}
[i]Hansa[/i] is a great representation of a "standard" Eurogame. It has a lot of components, especially for its demurely-sized box. The set-up of the game is involved, which leads to an organizational conundrum: should you store all of the goods counters together, or divide them up by color? I chose the latter approach, since it simplifies the process of actually getting the game to the table. I can always spend more time cleaning a game up after everyone has left.
At first blush, the rules seem fidgety, especially when you're buying goods. In two scenarios you pay the bank. In another you pay a player. In the last, you don't pay at all. This aspect of the game turns out to merge seamlessly with the rest of the rules, but it takes a few rounds to appreciate it. There is also the "wish you could do one more thing at this location" angst, which is mitigated by the fact that you can return to the same location during your turn if you have enough money to do so. The "tax and tariff" phase feels like an artificially-imposed limitation, but at least it encourages you to do [i]something[/i] during your turn, instead of accumulating resources ad infinitum.
The two player game feels too resource-constrained: it's very easy to leave your opponent in a position where she will have to spend a couple of Talers to move at the beginning of her turn, and vice-versa. The three player game is very enjoyable. The four player game is more chaotic, but enjoyably so. You can't plan too far ahead in the four player game, especially if the warehouses are getting depleted, and a player might refresh them before your turn comes around. [i]Hansa[/i] is not incredibly good, but it's not broken or imbalanced, either. It's simply a nice, average game.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.wishlistcomment:

item.name: Hare & Tortoise
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1979[/b] (inaugural award)
[i]Posted: 5/14/06, Rated: 7[/i]
Triangular numbers have never been so much fun!
If you're a math geek on top of being a boardgame one, then you know that triangular numbers are the sequence that is created when you add the counting numbers together for a running total: 1, 3 (which is 1 + 2), 6 (which is 1 + 2 + 3), 10, 15, 21, and so on. A true geek knows why the Greeks called them "triangular," but my point has been made already: this game requires a good deal of math.
Looking at the childish track, and noticing the inclusion of a die might lead you to suspect that this is a roll-and-move game. It is not. Each turn, a player decides how many spaces she will move. Moving is paid for in "carrots," which are the equivalent of currency. The amount paid is -- you guessed it -- the triangular number with the same number of terms. Don't worry, tables are provided. Eight spaces in one turn will cost you 36 carrots. Two turns of four will only cost you 20 carrots. This kind of calculation is the crux of the game.
There is a lack of confrontation with less than five players. With five or six, enough people are vying for the same spaces that it's hard to break away from the pack. Once someone starts to pull away, it is almost impossible to catch them. There are spaces that impart a random effect, hence the inclusion of the die. These effects vary depending upon your position in the game: those that are further behind are more likely to roll something positive. None of the effects can slow down the leader, although someone in fourth place or lower can jump one position ahead with a lucky roll -- assuming there are that many players.
As the inaugural winner of the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl], Hare and Tortoise[/i] will always be a classic. It is definitely a vast improvement over genuine roll-and-move games. What seems to be a kids' game is too demanding for young children, yet the theme is a bit too childish at first glance for adults. I do enjoy playing it, and it gives me an excuse to talk about triangular numbers.

item.name: High Bohn Plus
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/9/10, Rated: 7[/i] {3P: 6, 4P: 7, 5P: ?}
So far have only played with the building expansions ([i]High Bohn[/i]). Have not tried the Cognac Beans, the associated Distillery, or the Order cards from "Plus."
My feelings are mixed with this expansion. I like the idea that the "type" of gold you have can be used in different ways. We quickly fell into using a shorthand nomenclature: "Chili Gold" versus "Stink Gold." That's just plain silliness, and therefore fun. Choosing which buildings to acquire was interesting, and I was excited to see how they would improve my ability to score points.
What ended up happening is that I had too much flexibility: I had five bean fields, one of which was capable of planting "Bean Stew:" I could plant one bean of every type in the same field. Draw a Garden Bean? Throw it in the stew! Oh, is that an orphaned Red Bean? Into the stew with you! I had no need to trade at all.
[i]High Bohn Plus[/i] is a refreshing change of pace if the original game has grown long in the tooth. Once the novelty has worn off, removing the interactive element of trading weakens the game.

item.name: Hive
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/9/06, Rated: 9[/i]
Solid abstract game with a wonderful theme. My sons love playing "the bug game," and they're getting pretty good at it, too!
The only drawback is understanding how the individual pieces actually move; the spider in particular is a bit tricky. Fortunately [url=http://www.hivemania.com/]playing the free "virtual" game online [/url] (it's the full game for one player) helps in this respect.
Gameplay-wise, it's probably more like an "8," but I give the new version with the Bakelite tiles an extra point. Think old-style [i][thing=2394]Dominoes[/thing][/i]. The tactile feel of the pieces, as well as the various paint colors for the different insects (and arachnid), really add to our enjoyment of this game. A fun game that can be played on any flat surface, and portable to boot!

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/4/10, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: 10, 3P: 9, 4P: ???}
My first game of [i]Innovation[/i] was an epic, 2p battle. You can read the session report here: [thread=553768][/thread]. After that exhilarating experience, I had to get my own copy. And as you might have surmised, I knew that I already loved this game.
[i]Innovation[/i] does exactly that. The iconic "ring of cards" with the achievements in the middle challenges you from the get-go. The seemingly-oversized reference cards soon develop their own personality, as you fan cards that have been scored to the left, and your achievements to the right.
Dominance in a "dogma" is determined by how many symbols appear on your played cards. In a novel idea, cards start out in a stack, then get splayed to the left where a single symbol on each lower card is revealed, thus increasing your power. In the middle game, cards can be splayed to the right instead, revealing two symbols on each lower card. Finally, cards get splayed [i]up[/i], revealing three symbols on each lower card. It's a very clever mechanism that imparts the idea of progress.
[person=6001]Carl Chudyk[/person] is also the developer of [i][thing=19857]Glory to Rome[/thing][/i], and there is a similar chaotic feeling to [i]Innovation.[/i] I love civ builders, and was very surprised at how well a seemingly simple batch of cards embodies that genre.
