item.name: Jambo
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/7/09, Rated: 9[/i]
[i]Jambo[/i] has been on my radar for several years, but I never got around to picking up a copy. The theme didn't really appeal to me. And as much as I love [i][thing=9216]Goa[/thing][/i], I had yet to decide that I was a fan of [person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person].
Then came [i][thing=25643]Arkadia[/thing][/i]. And [i][thing=37907]Diamonds Club[/thing][/i]. And wasn't [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] one of his, too? Okay, I am a fan. It was finally time to pick up a copy of [i]Jambo[/i].
I shouldn't have waited this long. [i]Jambo[/i] is a great game. It's just complex enough to be thoroughly enjoyable, without being unapproachable for my family and friends. It's designed to be a two player game, which I consider to be a bonus: I prefer games that have been designed for two players, rather than ones which require rules adjustments or a variation to accommodate that number. Sure, the corollary is that [i]Jambo[/i] won't scale, but that's okay. As part of the [family=78]Kosmos two-player series[/family], I don't expect it to do so. So why do I have any regrets? Two reasons, and neither of them are the result of any flaws in the actual game.
The first has to do with "the cult of the new" here on BGG. The early adopters. This phenomenon is not unique to this site. I was very familiar with it when I was playing computer games online: the mad rush to be playing the latest and greatest titles, with a core group of players jumping from one to the next. As my discretionary time dwindled, I found it harder and harder to keep up, and eventually lost the desire to even try. I was glad to find a hobby in board games that wasn't so fickle that I could share with my family. Only one of those first impressions turned out to be accurate: I can share board games with my family.
The rush to acquire, play, analzye, and ultimately discard games is still very prevalent here on the 'Geek, and I feel like I missed the boat on [i]Jambo[/i]. Many of the forum threads are already three years old, and are lying fallow. I need to reset my own expectations on this score.
My other regret has to do with the principle mechanic of "power cards." I'm not sure what to call it, exactly, but that whole concept of playing cards with abilities in combination, à la [i][thing=463]Magic: The Gathering[/thing][/i]. It's the hip, new mechanic being used everywhere. [i]Jambo's[/i] sibling in the Kosmos line, [i][thing=9446]Blue Moon[/thing][/i] uses it. [i][thing=31260]Agricola[/thing][/i] incorporates this mechanic. [i][thing=35677]Le Havre[/thing][/i]. [i][thing=28143]Race for the Galaxy[/thing][/i]. [i][thing=36218]Dominion[/thing][/i]. I'm not saying that these games are all identical, because each one obviously has its own flavor and personality. However, they all share this same "power card" mechanic which is starting to feel tired.
The fun these games offer is found in the discovery of effective strategies and card combinations. Jambo definitely delivers on this front. It's tempting to hold on to too many cards waiting for the "perfect storm" of a combination, but the People and Animal cards will thwart your plans. The resource management aspect in the form of "wares" is a nice change, adding a dash of complexity with its variety. The pacing feels just right, and the end game culminates in a tense manner. [i]Jambo[/i] is a very tight, and well-conceived game.
These games also beg for expansions, and [i]Jambo[/i] is no exception. With [thing=29510]one already released[/thing] and [thing=46127]another on the way[/thing], there is plenty of replayability to be had. I am eagerly looking forward to all of them, even if I am arriving a few years late to the dance.

item.name: Java
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 9th Place 2001[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 2/1/06, Rated: 6[/i]
The backstory: the first game of the "mask trilogy" that I played was [i][thing=54]Tikal[/thing][/i]. It was said to be the easiest of the three. I enjoy it immensely. I then looked at [i]Java[/i], and saw that it was considered to be the "beefier" game. Sounded great to me, so here we are.
The board in [i]Java[/i] is beautiful. It is very reminiscent of [i][thing=54]Tikal[/thing][/i]. At first blush you might think that it was the same game, only with smaller hexagons so more tiles could fit onto the board. The tiles themselves are amazingly thick -- unbelievably so. The rules explain the game well, provide good examples, and have excellent illustrations.
If these comments feel dry so far, then you're not far from how I felt about playing the game. It's [i]nice[/i]. The overlapping placement of land tiles is interesting. Developer movement is interesting. I see the quandary between creating avenues of access of the same terrain type versus expanding cities or villages, trying to maximize your action points. The festival bidding is...[i]interesting[/i]. It adds a much needed break to the tile placement dilemma, and provides an alternate scoring mechanism for people who can't get the "highest rank" in a city to improve its temple.
Yet for all of these interesting mechanics, [i]Java[/i] has failed to move me. The game works, and I can see its potential, but it hasn't yet clicked with me the way that [i][thing=54]Tikal[/thing][/i] has. This view might change if played with the right group, and I'd play if asked, but at the moment I have other titles that I would like to bring to the table.
item.conditiontext: English version by Rio Grande Games. Complete and in mint condition.

item.name: Jenga
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/9/09, Rated: 4[/i]
[i]Jenga[/i] was not yet developed when I was growing up, yet I had acquired a copy prior to my discovery of BGG. I believe it to be one of the first dexterity games I had tried, and I enjoyed it.
However, my knowledge of games has since expanded. After having played other dex games such as [i][thing=150]Carabande[/thing][/i], [i][thing=2596]Villa Paletti[/thing][/i], and [i][thing=903]Hamsterrolle[/thing][/i], I'm not as fond of [i]Jenga[/i] as I used to be. My sons now use its pieces as building blocks, or else as faux [i][thing=2394]Dominoes[/thing][/i] to topple.
I'd bump the rating an extra point for [i]Jenga[/i]'s versatility, but that would be outside the scope of the game itself. It keeps the "4."

item.name: Journey to the Center of the Earth
Jump Drive
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/17/17 Rated: 6[/i]
A lightweight version of [i][thing=28143][/thing][/i]. On the surface, that sounds great. However, [i]Jump Drive[/i] is really meant to be an introductory game to the whole [i]Race[/i] universe. If you've already fallen in love with [i][thing=28143]Race[/thing][/i] or it's younger (and better) brother, [i][thing=132531]Roll[/thing][/i], then you'll find [i]Jump Drive[/i] to be unsatisfying fare.
To say that is is in the same universe means there are a lot of the same names here: Artist Colony, Contact Specialist, Galactic Imperium, you name it. They all appear here, although in slightly different forms. If you're new to this setting, then great! You'll learn them for the first time. But if you're coming from having played the older games many, many times then you're relearning how to evaluate what sound like old friends.
Ultimately, [i]Jump Drive[/i] really becomes a game about card churn. It's possible and even probable that you will end up drawing 10+ cards per turn, when you're only allowed to keep 10 of them. Within those 10 cards, you hope to find synergies with the tableau you've laid out so far.
As each round has the same series of actions (and I will admit that "Explore" and "Survey Team" break the mold, here), the game ends up being considered in [i]rounds[/i]. It will be over in seven to eight [i]rounds[/i]. This isn't too far off from a game of [i]Race[/i], but for some reason the rounds aren't as pronounced. I think it's because in the latter title, you think more in terms of [i]role selections[/i], which depending upon your ability to read your opponents' strategies, can end up being more or less. That tension is not present in [i]Jump Drive[/i].
I wanted to like this game because I'm a huge fan of [i][thing=132531]Roll[/thing][/i] and rapidly becoming a bigger fan of [i][thing=28143]Race[/thing][/i] due to its iOS app. However, I find [i]Jump Drive[/i] to be a little too streamlined and homogenized to recommend it to veteran gamers. To novice ones, perhaps.
item.conditiontext: Complete and in pristine condition. Sleeved.

item.name: Just One
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 28 NOV 2022, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Just One[/i] is a party game with a simple idea: get one person to guess a word. Everyone else writes down a one-word clue, and any duplicates are removed. Not just the duplicate, but all instances of a repeated word. If the target word is "pyramid" and two people wrote "Egypt," then "Egypt" would not be shown to the person trying to guess "pyramid."
That one mechanic turns the game into a session of mass anxiety. Do I give the obvious clue? But if no one gives the obvious clue, then will the guesser be able to get it?
Here's a real life example: the clue word was "Caesar." I wanted to write "Julius," but I felt that was too easy. I decided to write "Augustus" instead. When the other clue-givers revealed their words, someone else had written "Augustus!" For the same reason! Fortunately, the other two clues were "salad" and "palace," and "Caesar" was guessed.
You're supposed to play until 13 words have been attempted, and then there's a table that tells you how well you did. Really, [i]Just One[/i] is more of an experience: keep playing until you're done. It's like [i][thing=147151][/thing][/i] in that respect. It's a good party game, but it only plays up to seven which is a bit low. Nothing says it couldn't go up to nine if you had more easels and pens.
I think I would rate it a "7" except for the fact that it has worked with every group of non-gamers with whom I have played it. That's definitely worth an extra point.

item.name: Justinian: Intrigue at the Emperor's Court
Kaivai Erweiterung: Die Perlentaucher und Kava-Brauer
Keltis
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2008[/b] [color=#959595][size=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 8th Place 2008[/size][/color]
[i]Posted: 1/5/09, Rated: 7[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: ???, 4P: 7}
What's more elusive than a leprechaun's pot o' gold? How about deciding which name to call a game? [i]Keltis[/i] won the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i], but the game's true lineage descends from [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i]. I collect the games which won the award, and thanks to a very generous [geekurl=/user/SteveK2]Secret Santa[/geekurl], I now own a copy of [i]Keltis[/i]. What does playing it feel like? [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i].
There are some differences, to be sure. First of all, the board has a variable set-up aspect to it: tiles are randomly placed on certain stepping stones along the five paths at the beginning of the game. This simple solution prevents the game from having a scripted feel. Second, and perhaps the hardest change for a veteran of [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i] to adopt is the playing of cards. In [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i], the numbers on your cards represent your score. In [i]Keltis[/i], playing a card allows you to move one stone forward along a given path; the value of the card means nothing other than establishing an ascending or descending sequence.
That leads us to our third difference: the cards in [i]Keltis[/i] can be played in either direction (ascending or descending). This ability removes much of the "starting angst" which is present in [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i]. If you have a "10" and a "9" in red, you don't have to hold on to them and hope for some lower support numbers before embarking in that color. This loss of tension removes some of the enjoyment from the game. It also makes discarding less prevalent. A cascading effect from having fewer discards is a reduced capacity to control the timing of the end of the game.
These changes result in a game that isn't as compelling as its progenitor. On the plus side, it looks great. It's pretty much guaranteed to be played at least once every year, on March 17th. I might just find that little rascal's gold, yet.
item.conditiontext: English translation of the rules printed out. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Keltis: Der Weg der Steine Mitbringspiel
Kemet: Skills and Black Power Tile For Ta-Seti
Key Flow
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/17/19, Rated: 6[/i]
I don't want to write this comment. I'm a fan of [person=134][/person] and especially of the [family=48][/family]. They're always a refreshing take on games, with wholesome themes and folksy artwork. Yet they deliver a tight, anxiety-ridden gaming experience with meaningful decisions at every turn. [i][thing=122515][/thing][/i] is the epitome of these attributes. [i]Key Flow[/i] may be the antithesis.
This game might as well be called [i]Key Wonders[/i] for how much it plays like [i][thing=68448][/thing][/i]. The same drafting mechanic is present, with a [i][thing=122515][/thing][/i] skin. I positively feel that this was the conceit which led to this game's development: "Let's make a version of [i][thing=68448][/thing][/i] set in the Key universe!" That is all well and good, and for the first three seasons [i]Key Flow[/i] invokes memories of its deeper brother in a fraction of the time. Then winter rears its ugly head, and the game turns super point salad-ey.
You start the game with five Winter "K-cards:" these are cards that are guaranteed to be in every game, regardless of the number of players. They are also all building cards, and you will be able to build one at the start of Winter. This means you can choose which strategy you want to pursue for one of the buildings. To put that statement into perspective, winning scores in a 5p and 6p game have been over 100 points, and a rough value estimate for a well-utilized Winter building is 20-25 points. That means you are planning for a quarter of your total points at best, and the rest will come from cards that are passed to you. The foundations of the early game are not meaningful enough.
In [i][thing=122515][/thing][/i], every auction bid is meaningful. Every keyple placement is meaningful as it generates the resources needed to bid in the next round. In [i]Key Flow[/i], I will draft a card each turn without having to do anything for it. I realize that's the nature of a drafting game. Perhaps the thematic cloning of [i][thing=122515][/thing][/i] creates a mental barrier that's tough to overcome. But I don't feel as though my choices are as important as they are in [i][thing=122515][/thing][/i], or even those in [i][thing=68448][/thing][/i]. [i]Key Flow[/i] won't see another play within my regular gaming group. It can still deliver some fun within the family, which is why I'm bumping its score up to a 6: "It could be a better game if played with the right group."

item.name: Key to the City: London
item.wishlistcomment:
Another Richard Breese "Key" title! I hear it's a streamlined version of [i]Keyflower[/i], which I already like quite a bit.
Looking for the Huch version, not the Quined Games master print version. The latter is very pretty, but the art of the former is more consistent with the rest of the Key series.

item.name: Keydom
item.wishlistcomment: This is a "grail" game for me. Although I already have a copy of [i][gameid=492][/i], it'd be nice to have this version to go along with [i][gameid=4099][/i] and [i][gameid=29839][/i]. Maybe I'll get it if I win the lottery some day.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/23/19, Rated: 9[/i]
I'm a fan of Richard Breese. His games require strategy and planning, often require meaningful player interaction, and do so with attractive artistic design and nonviolent themes. [i]Keyflower[/i] delivers all of the above in a reasonable time frame, and still invites agonizing moments of decision.
The heart of the game is an auction combined with worker placement. Keyples (meeples in Breese's [i]Key[/i] universe) can be set on a tile to use it, or else next to a tile if it is in the offer as your bid for it. There are four colors of keyples, and once one has been set on or next to a tile, that is the only color that may be played there. They behave like different currencies, a la [i]Alhambra[/i]. This means in some cases having a lot in a color is good so you can outbid someone else for a tile you really want, but then having some of all of the colors means you could play anywhere -- if you have enough of them. Managing that balance is important.
There is a potential for a cascading effect in these auctions, where one player outbids another for a tile, and the losing player takes her keyples, maybe adds to them, and outbids a third player on a different tile. These cascades can really mess with your goals which means your strategy needs to be flexible, or your keyple reserves need to be properly managed.
The auction/worker placement is the most enjoyable part of the game. Do I want to set the color of an auctioned tile early, so I can control it? Do I try to make a takedown bid out of the gate to discourage other players? Can I wait to bid on that tile so that I can use another tile now, while it is still cheap to use? All of these decisions happen quickly, which is a testament to the quality of the game design.
Tiles that are won in an auction are usually added to your town; the turn order tiles do not get added until the fourth and final round. And here is my one nitpick with the game: building the town means you have to match roads to roads like [i]Carcassonne[/i], and later you will be moving goods along those paths. It's a tad fiddly. I'd rather just add tiles to my town and then move goods between tiles without having to line up the roads. There's actually a tile that allows you to do just that, but obtaining may not be part of my strategy in a specific game.
When I eventually get down to culling my collection, [i]Keyflower[/i] will be one that stays on my shelf. I really would like to get it to the table more often. Successfully navigating the auctions, collecting resources, and implementing my strategies are all part of a very rewarding gaming session.

item.name: KeyForge: Call of the Archons
item.wishlistcomment: I'm intrigued by the concept of a "unique deck game" (UDG), but I also fear what it might incite. Don't worry about buying single cards to improve your chances of winning, now you buy a new [i]deck[/i]. I will definitely try this game at some point. The real question is, will I share it with my sons?

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/16/06, Rated: 9[/i]
[person=134]Mr. Breese[/person]: you sir, are a bit-head.
That term usually refers to programmers (and assembly ones at that), but I'm using it to describe your obsession for using lots of [i]bits[/i] in your games. The pile of counters, tiles, cubes, cylinders, squares, circles, and chimpanzees (okay, they're not really in the game) was a bit overwhelming at first glance. You are also very fond of player screens. That's neither here nor there, except for the fact that I [i]cringe[/i] when I actually have to bend the tabs.
[i]Keythedral[/i] is almost two separate games. When I examined the picutres, I was excited to think about building this board as the game progressed. If you haven't read the rules, then you should know this: the first "game" is to construct the board [i]in its entirety.[/i] If you "play" (build) poorly, then you will severely hurt your chances in the second "game" that is played upon it. However, a working knowledge of the second game is required to do well in the first.
The second (and the actual) game is a careful blend of resource management, and tactical optimization. Usually, you want to perform those actions that help you to purchase seats in the Keythedral, which are equivalent to victory points. The self-proclaimed "strategic" variant of the game allows you to see the resource costs of every seat in the Keythedral ahead of time. At the moment, I prefer the standard variant, and find that I still have to be strategic in my preparations.
However, there is also a considerable amount of confrontation: you can position your workers and fences such that another player may not be able to place her own workers. Not being able to place a worker means you won't be collecting as many resource cubes. Turn order can be a decisive factor. An auction is held to see who will [i]choose[/i] the starting player in the next round, which can foster a bit of a breakaway leader problem.
After having stated these observations, [i]Keythedral[/i] is marvelous. Playing it in some ways resembles a good computer Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game. There is plenty of confrontation, resource management, and climbing a "tech tree" (in this case, the tiers of seats to purchase, and how you "upgrade" your huts into houses) on your path to victory. I'm a big fan of RTS games, and also of [i]Keythedral.[/i]
[person=134]Mr. Breese[/person]: you sir, are also a genius.
item.conditiontext: Pro Ludo version © ???. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Keytown
item.wishlistcomment: Grail game. Maybe I'll get it if I win the lottery some day.

item.name: Khet: Eye of Horus Beam Splitter
Khet: The Laser Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 3/31/08, Rated: 7[/i]
There's no doubt about it: playing a board game with freakin' [i]lasers[/i] is cool! The idea is just so übergeeky that you have to love it. If you can't have aliens, orcs, or sharks, then pieces with mirrors which can deflect and redirect the beams are the next-best things.
The pieces themselves are not complicated. Learning how to "see" where the laser is going to travel shouldn't be difficult, either, yet my sons have trouble with this aspect of the game. The default layout is very enjoyable, and in my experience is the best of the suggested ones. The ancient Egyptian "theme" is implemented about as well as it could be for an anachronistic game with lasers.
The real shortcoming of [i]Khet[/i] is that while lasers are cool, the abstract game itself is only mediocre. Playing the game without lasers -- which admittedly doesn't make sense, although I suppose you could "draw" the path with your finger from piece to piece -- would be less fulfilling than any of the games in the [family=10]Project GIPF family[/family]. After several plays with overenthusiastic children, I'm starting to suspect either my lasers or my pieces aren't as well-aligned as they used to be. Multi-bounce shots aren't as precise.
In all fairness, [i]Khet[/i] probably deserves a rating of "6," but I'm going to give it a courtesy bump up to a "7" because my sons love playing the "laser battle game." And lasers [i]are[/i] wicked cool, after all.
item.conditiontext: Red & silver-piece version by Innovation Toys, LLC © 2005. Complete and in excellent condition. Box has a couple of wrinkles in the top, and I'm starting to have my suspicions about the alignment of the lasers.

item.name: King Arthur: The Card Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/8/09, Rated: 6[/i]
I wasn't even aware of the [i][thing=6368]King Arthur[/thing][/i] board game from which this card game was derived, although I am quite familiar with the recent trend of translating board games into card games. It's a quick way to earn some extra money from fans of the original. I didn't have any preconceptions for [i]King Arthur - The Card Game[/i]; how well would it fare?
The game itself is a basic two-stage resource-gathering exercise, executed almost entirely with cards. This time around the [person=2]good doctor[/person] has chosen an exciting theme to complement the game mechanics. The idea of knights sallying forth to vanquish adversaries, trying to complete heroic quests is always a good one. The card graphics greatly support these goals.
There is a subtlety to the end-game scoring, where completed quests (public information) plus the value of adversary cards remaining in each player's hand (private but theoretically trackable information) contributes to her score. A small nit-pick: the backs of the adversary cards should have been the same as the knight cards: doing so would have prevented other players from gaining any insight to the numbers of each you may be holding.
I originally said the game was executed "almost exclusively" with cards. The exceptions to this statement are the "seals," which are used in the advanced version of the game. These chits add a delaying mechanism to the game, with opportunities for players to pay double to obtain an immediate result. Further plays with these strategic options may increase the game's rating.
For some unknown reason, the box is grossly oversized for its contents. I expect a card game to be much smaller, like [i][thing=215]Tichu[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=5782]Coloretto[/thing][/i]. Its size is frustrating for storage or for travel. Resolved: [i]King Arthur - The Card Game[/i] uses tried and true mechanics, applies a fun theme, and is capable of varying depths of play. It isn't the Holy Grail of gaming, but it's a fun quest for a rainy day.
item.conditiontext: Box shows some signs of wear. Components complete and in excellent condition.

item.name: King of New York: Monster Idol
King of the Elves
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/2/13, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]King of the Elves[/i] is a faithful card game adaptation of [i][thing=10][/thing][/i] -- which is to say, it is still the same "traveling salesman" problem at heart. The main difference is that without a board, you're not quite sure where you'll have to go -- the villages within the player realms are placed during the course of play each round. That makes it difficult to plan for future rounds, unlike the board game where you can plan ahead based upon where your meeple will be.
The upside to the card version of the game is the delicious "starting reluctance" like [i][thing=50][/thing][/i]. You don't want to be the first person to place a village, because the other players can gain a tempo by blocking you, or else they get a leg up by budgeting their cards. Going first is [i]not[/i] an advantage, which means the game plays better with less than six players so that everyone is equally penalized.
Each round starts out more tense due to playing for tempos, but can die quickly if the villages that get played are not aligned with the cards in your hand. Other players can play villages in your "realm," destroying any synergy you were trying to meld. There is also an undercurrent of knowing when to "shoot the moon," and try to visit all of the villages. Gaining cards is an expensive but necessary investment, and you won't have enough of them to try every turn. Replayability can be found by exploring these nuances.
The end result is a game that is both better, and worse than its progenitor. I'll give it the same score, for now.

item.name: Kreta
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/4/2010, Rated: 8[/i]
"Area Control" is an interesting mechanism for me. I think I like it. I want to like it. However, it is usually implemented as "draw a random card to determine where you're allowed to move, and then decide how to maximize your scoring potential for that space." [i][thing=199]Manhattan[/thing][/i] followed that formula, as did [i][thing=1041]San Marco[/thing][/i], although in the latter case there was the schoolyard practice of "I divide, you choose" to distribute cards. It wasn't until I tried [i][thing=491]Web of Power[/thing][/i] where paired cards could be used as a wild card that I found the freedom I so desperately sought from an area control game.
Enter [i]Kreta[/i] with a different solution: Role selection determines which pieces you can move. You can place a piece almost anywhere on the board to bring it into play. After that, some pieces can be moved depending upon the role selected. This freedom of movement makes [i]Kreta[/i] a satisfying area control game.
The random deck element still rears its head, though: the regions to be scored are drawn from a deck. At any time before the final scoring round, the next two regions to be scored are known: this allows players to fight over the currently-contested region, and/or position themselves for the next one. One role in particular, the Commander, provides you with four "movement points" for your villagers. Remembering to use any surplus points to better position distant villagers for the [i]next[/i] contested region is an important consideration.
The game itself looks beautiful. I was originally enchanted by this picture:
[ImageID=82768]          [i]Picture by [geekurl=/user/GeoMan]GeoMan[/geekurl][/i]
The German role cards are easy enough to understand, but having English summary placards is nice to have. Fortunately [geekurl=/user/npetry]npetry's[/geekurl] translations ([filepage=25511]part 1[/filepage], [filepage=25512]part 2[/filepage]) are excellent, and look wonderful when mounted on to cardboard as his instructions suggest.
Some people complain that the random deck element still exists, but I feel that its effects can be mitigated to some extent, and that the freedom of movement provided by the role selection mechanic far outweighs this objection. [i]Kreta[/i] is a solid entry that for some unknown reason never benefitted from a wide release in the U.S. If you're a fan of the Area Control mechanic and you're willing to put out some effort to localize a German copy, then you should seek it out.

item.name: Kutná Hora: The City of Silver – Land Rights Compact Promo Card
Labyrinth: The Card Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/8/09, Rated: 4[/i]
There has been a recent trend in coverting established board games into smaller, card game versions. Maybe this trend has been going on for longer than I realize. Some of these conversions have been very good: [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] is in my opinion a better game than its progenitor, [i][thing=3076]Puerto Rico[/thing][/i]. [i][thing=27364]Caylus Magna Carta[/thing][/i] is a more accessible game for my family. [i][thing=437]Master Labyrinth[/thing][/i] is one of our favorites, so when I won this game in the [listitem=839664]Card Game Chain[/listitem], I was excited to bring it to the table.
Perhaps our expectations were too high for this title, for it failed to impress.
More importantly, it failed to be [i]fun[/i]. Here's the problem: the board in [i][thing=437]Master Labyrinth[/thing][/i] forces the tiles to retain a "center of mass." In that game, the addition of a tile makes other tiles move, creating new and (at least for my kids) unpredictable connections. In [i]Labyrinth Card Game[/i], adding a card is a singular change. Sure, you may then be able to remove one or more cards if you link treasures together, which can alter other routes. Superficially, it sounds like a decent translation of the board mechanics.
Realistically, the maze in [i]Labyrinth Card Game[/i] ends up spidering out in many directions. It gets very thin and elongated, rather than staying compact with many options. Instead of creating "compound" pathways by inserting and sliding a tile, you're forced into potentially undesirable situations of rebuilding internal infrastructure on your turn, which may end up benefitting your opponents more than yourself. Even worse is the situation where the link you forged gets broken before your turn comes around again.
I've perused the comments of people who have rated it higher, and I see that several of them have adopted house rules to improve the game play. That may well indeed improve the game, but when playing it by the rules as written, it is quite disappointing. I considered giving it an extra ratings point for a "5" due to its demure size and resultant portability, but the box design makes it difficult to keep the cards and the instructions in place when returning the tray. More thought needed to go into this game all around.

item.name: LCR
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/6/09, Rated: 4[/i]
There are a lot of users here at the 'Geek who malign [i]LCR[/i] as much as they do [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i]. I'm willing to defend the latter title to some extent. This one, not so much.
Here is a game that challenges a [geekurl=/user/Beowulf]rating scale[/geekurl]. Should it be rated as objectively as possible, considering only its mechanics? Should the gaming experience be considered as well? What about the cost of acquisition, or the time to play? I think all of these attributes factor into a rating.
As far as dice games go, [i]LCR[/i] is pathetically lacking in just about everything. [i][thing=10815]Craps[/thing][/i] without all of the side bets has more strategy to it. Components? You get three dice. You also get some chips, but who are we kidding? They won't be used because you'll be playing for money. Cost of acquisition? Virtually negligible, except for the additional money you'll be losing when you play. So far, this game sounds like the dud everyone claims it to be.
Now, let me tell you about this past New Year's Eve: we had eight people standing around a table, whooping and hollering as the dice were rolled, and money changed hands. At Thanksgiving we had nine. This game lends itself well to large groups. If you can allow yourself to have fun and not view every game with a critical eye, then [i]LCR[/i] does have its good moments. If you do give it a try, then I highly recommend you play with this [thread=61995]rule variant[/thread]. It increases the tension and group enjoyment of the game, as advertised.
It is for this reason that I'm going to give this game a generous rating of "4." I'd play it again at Thanksgiving, after any previous resentment has faded. Until then, I'd rather risk losing my money on a [thing=1115]game I think I can win with skill[/thing].
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 2[/i]
Special considerations aside (like having a lot to drink on New Year's Eve), this game is awful. Yes, it's fun for a few minutes before that crystal ball drops, but that's about it.

item.name: Leaders of Euphoria: Choose a Better Oppressor
Leapfrog
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/1/11, Rated: 5[/i]
I finally managed to track down a copy of [i][thing=13359]Leapfrog[/thing][/i], the inaugural title of [company=3013]Fragor Games[/company]. It's easy to see how it preceded [i][thing=18866]Shear Panic[/thing][/i]. First place in one direction starts in last place for the next race going the opposite way. Simultaneous blind bidding equals race options. Players' chips remain on the board, so each one will only be played once per race. This "dwindling options" mechanism feels very reminiscent of [i][thing=13308]Niagara[/thing][/i]. The fact that they all remain in view means that players will be able to see which chips have already been played; this information factors into your decisions.
The game scales up to six, although it becomes much more deterministic. At that point, the analysis paralysis starts to outweigh the fun factor. Perhaps the chips should be stacked à la [i][thing=13308]Niagara[/thing][/i] after all. I suspect that four will be the sweet spot, with two frogs adding enough of a random element to mess with the most carefully laid plans. "The best-laid schemes o' mice an' men / Gang aft agley" (not to confuse [i][thing=13359]Leapfrog[/thing][/i] with [i][thing=23848]Hameln[/thing][/i]!).

item.name: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game
Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/9/16, Rated: 7[/i]
I like being open with you, and telling you when I want to like a game. In the case of [i]Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game (LE:A)[/i], I'm a big fan of the source material. Not in the, "I could watch this every day for the rest of my life" sort of way, but in the, "It's been a couple of years since the last viewing and I'm craving me some [i]Alien[/i]" way. The first movie was hella scary back in the day although it has lost must of its punch: its effects don't hold up well to HDTV's. The second movie is just pure awesomeness. The third and fourth movies if they were to exist are terrible.
On top of all that, I've been listening to the folks over at the [url=http://www.dicetower.com/game/146652/legendary-encounters-an-alien-deck-building-game]Dice Tower raving about the game[/url]. When [company=517]Upper Deck[/company] released [i][thing=174570][/thing][/i] and it could be combined with [i]LE:A[/i], I was finally in for a copy. Alien vs. Predator is a concept that was best done in the original Dark Horse comic books, yielded two execrable films, and some fun video games. I'm rambling at this point. Let's get to the game.
[i]LE:A[/i] is the first cooperative deck-building game I've played. Right there, that's interesting. This isn't just "my engine is better than yours." It's "we're working together to beat these baddies." From helping each other buy better cards (the "Sergeant" card), to killing facehuggers before they turn into chestbursters inside of your teammates, to helping them kill bosses, this really feels like a team experience. The "Coordinate" action is the source of this synergy, and I really like it.
[i]LE:A[/i] does a great job of translating the menace and the fear of the movies into a board game. Those alien cards keep flowing into the Complex, and you won't know what's coming unless you spend combat points to "scan" that room, or until it shows up in the Combat Zone. It's easy to keep those places separate because the game includes a playmat -- finally! It makes managing the experience a breeze.
The artwork on the cards aren't movie stills, but rather comic-like pictures of scenes in the movies. And here is my first gripe: some of the cards do a great job of depicting Ripley or Captain Dallas, while others are barely recognizable. The pictures of Corporal Hicks and Private Hudson do not look anything like Michael Biehn or Bill Paxton. Since the movies were sci-fi horror films, some of the artwork is graphically violent. Also, there could have been a greater variety of artwork used. All "Facehugger" cards use the exact same graphic -- even the ones that go into the Strike Deck (how you determine damage taken from the aliens) or the Drone Deck (extra baddies that are shuffled in with the cards for each objective). I initially thought I was missing a card because I didn't know what to expect.
That leads me to the biggest gripe I have with this game: sorting it all out. I had heard how onerous sorting was, but I didn't believe it until I tried it on my own. [b]The instructions don't tell you how.[/b] They leave it up to you to realize that there are deck identifiers on the bottom of each card written in a smaller, faint font. If you're thinking about buying this game, then be sure to print out [filepage=107161]this card list[/filepage] by [user=gwarjuice]gwarjuice[/user]. It's a tremendous help to organizing the game. Upper Deck should have included this information in the instruction booklet.
[i]Legendary Encounters: Alien[/i] delivers a tense, highly thematic experience. Its tension and gruesome nature means I won't be playing this game all the time. I rather expect a few weeks or months will pass, and then I'll be craving me some [i]Alien.[/i]

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game Expansion

LEGO Creator
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/17/05, Rated: 6[/i]
More of the same on again, off again rain. My five year-old pulled this game out to play, and I don't know how I missed it during my previous inventory.
The board is [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i]-esque in its layout, with an assortment of Lego pieces in the middle instead of cards. It is worth mentioning that these are the "standard" size pieces, not Duplos. There are some good choking hazards for very young children. Also, while there is a picture of a mini-fig on the cover, none of those little guys are included with this game.
Each player starts by selecting a building plan that has the same color back as everyone else's. Four sets of building cards provide some replayability. Roll and move is the mechanic of the day, accumulating the pieces as you go. There are spaces which allow you take pieces from other players, so there is some confrontation in the game. My five year old still screams if he gets victimized by one of these spaces. Also, the rules recommend building your model as you go, but in practice it is harder to keep track of what you need if you are not laying out your existing pieces on your building card.
There is some minor strategy: players should focus on collecting "special pieces" (and try to pick the model of the set that requires the fewest of them). Players should also select their "regular" pieces in such a way as to maintain the usefulness of every space on the board for as long as possible. For example, don't take both of your yellow pieces in a row, which would then make all of the "take a yellow piece" spaces unusable.
This game is a simple one, that does provide an interesting variation of building with Legos. I'll willingly play it if my children ask for it, but I won't bring it out on my own.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1993[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 4th Place 1993[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 3/29/07, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Liar's Dice[/i] is a simple game that is easy to teach. Roll the dice by turning your cup upside-down, take a peek, and then try to guess how many dice display a certain number under [i]all[/i] of the cups. The game even made a celebrity appearance in the movie [i]Pirates of the Caribbean 2: Dead Man's Chest.[/i]
Instead of having 1 pip on one side of each die, the dice in the [company=562]Endless Games[/company] version have stars. These act as wild cards, raising the amount of any particular number. Wild stars can also be used as their own bid. As the stakes rise, bidding a number of stars feels like a cop out: three stars may seem easy, wihle a raise requires a minimum of six of any number (or four stars). A bid of four stars can only be raised by eight of something else (or five stars), etc.
For a long time, my family and I were playing incorrectly: each person that lost a challenge would only lose one die, as opposed to losing the number of dice by which his challenge was incorrect. This misunderstanding resulted in a more enjoyable game, in our experience, as it kept people from being eliminated too quickly.
The Endless Games version takes up a lot of [i]space;[/i] this game could be stored in a much smaller box, if the nearly-vestigial board could fold. As my collection grows, my sensitivity to wasted space increases as well.
[i]Liar's Dice[/i] is a decent party game, and can basically scale up to more players than are provided in the Endless Games version. There isn't a lot of downtime for the active players, which is a good thing. Still, if I'm looking for a quick, dice fest filler game, I'd rather break out [i][thing=15818]Pickomino[/thing][/i] instead.
item.conditiontext: Endless Games version © 2002. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Little Alchemists
item.wishlistcomment:
Let's talk for a moment. This whole "Little" thing takes a heavier game and creates a version for children, and generates some self-consciousness. Look, making a game that kids can play is great! But can we just make a simpler version of a game, lower the recommended starting age, and eschew the "little" title and imagery?
I'm interested in seeing how this simplified version of [i][thing=161970][/thing][/i] plays. And I read that [designer=75718][/designer] was making a version that he could play with his kids. Okay, fine.

item.name: Little Devils
item.comment:
Posted: 29 DEC 2022, Rated: 6
[i]Little Devils[/i] is an easy game to teach, and is fast to play.
It is a trick taking game without suits. Instead, it has cards numbered from 1 to 54. The starting player plays a card. The second player plays a card either above or below the starting card; this sets the "direction" of the trick. If the second card is higher than the first, then the other players must play cards higher than the [b]first[/b] card (not higher than every other card). The highest card played wins the trick, and that player takes all of the played cards.
If you can't follow the trend and have to play a lower card, then you will win the trick -- unless someone else can't follow either and plays an even lower card than yours.
All of the above is flipped if the second card played is lower than the first card.
Each card has zero to five imp faces on it, similar to the bull heads in [i][thing=432]6 Nimmt![/thing][/i] Each imp is worth one point. And just like that other (and better) game, you don't want points. Play until someone has accumulated a total of 100+ points, and then the player with the lowest score wins.
The game says it can be played with 3-6 players, but it doesn't really shine until you have at least five. Then things get more interesting as people are trying to squeeze in under a card that has already been played, or hoping that someone else cannot follow the trend.
It's a fine game and I have suggested it in some situations, like when playing with a group of friends who are unfamiliar with our expanded hobby. But given the opportunity, I would play [i][thing=432]6 Nimmt![/thing][/i] instead.

item.name: Looting London
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/20/09, Rated: 5[/i]
The [geekurl=/wiki/page/Glossary#toc135]classic criticism[/geekurl] of [person=2]Reiner Knizia[/person] unsurprisingly applies to [i]Looting London[/i] as well. A game with simple, elegant rules is often accused of having its theme "pasted on." Hogwash. I prefer games with streamlined rules which can be evaluated objectively. Theme is a subjective element: the richness of the game world can either increase or diminish the overall experience. Here, the theme is what it is: some interesting period pictures on some components. It doesn't really add to, or detract from the game.
Otherwise, [i]Looting London[/i] feels like the most mundane parts of [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i] without the board. The primary mechanic is set collection to claim [-]routes[/-] tiles, drawing from the four face-up cards you can see, or else drawing one blind from the top of the deck. This method of card selection has been used a seemingly endless number of times, including [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i], [i][thing=21790]Thurn & Taxis[/thing][/i], and [i][thing=25643]Arkadia[/thing][/i]. Continue to draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw until you can "buy" what you want, or until someone claims it out from under your nose.
There is an additional complication to claiming [-]routes[/-] tiles: it is possible to "destroy evidence" (remove a tile), if by so doing you can immediately claim the one above it. This is an important consideration, as you can improve your chance at scoring the most points in a given color, or keep other players from challenging you in the discarded color. There's a typical Knizia scoring twist here as well: of the five colors of tiles on the board, the last color to still have tiles on the board will not count towards the final score. Thus, discarding tiles can also help to ensure your preferred colors all count.
The end result is that there are times when you are going to continue drawing cards, even after you may have achieved your desired goal (or else your desired goal takes more cards than a single [-]route[/-] tile would require). You can both claim a tile and draw a card on the same turn, which reduces the pressure of making a decision as to which route to take. I believe the game is less interesting without this angst.
I'm starting to suspect that Knizia's entries in the [family=76]Gryphon Games bookshelf series[/family] are competent, yet unmoving combinations of familiar mechanics. Perhaps that generalization could be said of most games, but [i]Looting London[/i] feels like there wasn't a lot of effort spent in creating a compelling title. If you dislike the eternal card-drawing elements of [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i], then [i]Looting London[/i] is definitely not for you. If you like the angst of pushing your luck one more round to improve your future hand, and want something lighter/more portable than [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i], then [i]Looting London[/i] might be worth a quick investigation.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Special Award: Literary Game 2001[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 8/5/09, Rated: 10[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: 10, 4P: 10, 5P: ???}
[i]One game to rule them all...[/i]
Let me start by saying this: If you're not a fan of the books and/or the movies, then you are not going to like this game. If you do enjoy those other mediums, then you will enjoy this. And if you love the story as I do, then you will be amazed by this game.
[i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] is a cooperative game. That is to say, all of the players are working together to defeat "the game." My family enjoys these games as a welcome alternative: we've played [i][thing=15062]Shadows over Camelot[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i]. It was surprising for me to realize that [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] preceded both. In fact, it is quite apparent to me that its composition of having a main board and then separate scenario boards was heavily leveraged by [i][thing=15062]Shadows[/thing][/i]. Ditto the idea of having a draw deck of tiles that advances the game elements (what [i][thing=15062]Shadows[/thing][/i] would later refer to as "The Progression of Evil").
[person=2]Knizia[/person]-bashers love to say that his games consist of dry mechanics with [geekurl=/wiki/page/Glossary#toc135]pasted-on themes[/geekurl]. That objection goes sideways for me, as I think almost every game can be reduced to those ingredients. What makes this game so incredible is the richness and depth of the source material, and the effectiveness with which it has been distilled down to a 60-minute gaming experience. You feel the enormity of the evil that is arrayed against you. The Big Eye is an imposing figure as it marches down the corruption track towards your hobbits.
Each scenario has its own personality. Take "Helm's Deep" for example: if the players can rush to complete the "Friendship" line and establish an alliance with Rohan before the second event, then they're off to a good start. If they can then rush through the "Travelling" line so that the Riders of Rohan reinforce Helm's Deep before the third event, then they will be well-positioned to successfully complete the scenario. The sense of urgency and the sequencing of these plot lines map well to the literary events, which I appreciate.
This seemingly complex game structure is delivered with a spartan set of components. The artwork of the game is original and immersive. This is a game that is easy to teach, and perhaps even more importantly is easy to set up. It is difficult to win, and by including a scoring mechanism there is motivation to win [i]well[/i]. [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i] was a landmark achievement in 2000, and it still represents a triumph of game design nine years later.
[i]Updated: 7/18/10, Rated: 9[/i]
[i]Lord of the Rings[/i] is an amazing feat of literary adaptation. If I'm being objective then the one item that provides me with a tiny lingering doubt is how this it favors people who have read the books. A "10" should have near-universal appeal. A "9" is still a heavy hitter, and [i]LOTR[/i] will still have plenty of magic for enthusiasts.

Lost Cities
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/3/05, Rated: 8[/i]
A solid two-player game. It has been compared to [i][thing=15878]Rummy[/thing][/i], but I find that analogy to be misleading. [i]Lost Cities[/i] is its own beast.
The "theme" such as it is fits well enough: you are potentially embarking on up to five expeditions that are represented by card colors (or suits). The art on the cards is very appropriate, but the cards themselves are too big. They feel "floppy" when shuffling. The game wouldn't have suffered any had they been standard bridge-deck size.
The scoring calculations are slightly convoluted: starting an expedition automatically incurs a -20 point penalty. This value represents the initial cost to embark upon the adventure. The cards that you play afterwards defray that cost, and hopefully result in a net profit. There are "handshakes" (investor cards) that act as score multipliers, but they must be played first. They increase the risk and also the possible reward. All cards are played or discarded face-up, which is important since you and your opponent will probably be vying for the same cards in at least one suit.
The heart of the game is found in trying to maximize the returns from your own expeditions while inhibiting your opponent's efforts. You can only hold eight cards in your hand, and it is never enough. You will have to take risks by beginning an expedition before you have enough support for it, or by discarding something your opponent may be able to use. A particularly frustrating development occurs when you start an expedition for which you have several cards, none of which are handshakes. Sure enough, as soon as you play the first numeric card, your opponent will start to discard those handshakes.
My wife enjoys this game, and is rapidly becoming a shark at it. After ten plays or so, I'd be more likely to rate [i]Lost Cities[/i] a "7," but it does get a bonus point for sparking her interest in games.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=14]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: Löwenherz
item.comment:
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1997[/b]
[i]Posted: 10/24/05, Rated: 8[/i]
A game where the seemingly fiddly rules fall into place with unseen elegance. Very in-your-face confrontational, which is a bit unusual for the stereotypical euro game. What I'm trying to say is that this is not your typical euro game.
Just about every aspect of the game screams "conflict." From trying to get dibs on an action, to the fierce negotiation if people try to take the same one, to knight and boundary placement, to region expansion, every action fosters a sense of "I win, you lose." I love this type of game, but there are friends of mine with whom I cannot play it (minus one point). It is a brilliant diamond of a gem with four players, and the drop off is steep from there (minus another point).
[i]Löwenherz[/i] is a great game that I will try to play whenever I can get the right people together. Highly recommended if your group enjoys this much adversity.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 7[/i]
The blush is off the rose for [i]Löwenherz[/i]. It's still a good game, but there not quite in the same echelon as my "8"-rated games. When I want to get my nasty gaming on, then it will still fit the bill, but my old group of gamers with whom I used to play it have since moved on. Their willingness to play had inflated my previous rating.

Macao
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/5/11, Rated: 7[/i]
After a few questionable entries in their [family=58]Big Box series[/family], [company=9]alea[/company] has enjoyed a return to their former glory, due in large part to the design efforts of [person=4958]Stefan Feld[/person]. [i]Macao[/i] utilizes dice in a novel way to allocate future resources. Combine that with the now ubiquitous deck of special power cards, and you have an interesting game.
I have a nagging suspicion that there might be a general solution to [i]Macao[/i], such as going for 5's and 6's, and then selecting your cards to match the colors you've already collected. Then again, if everyone does the same thing, then only a few cards will be successfully activated, and everyone else will start taking penalties. [i]Macao[/i] was pleasant enough, and I do look forward to seeing if it is hiding more depth.

item.name: Machine of Death: The Game of Creative Assassination
Mad Libs Card Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/13/07, Rated: 2[/i]
Some ideas just don't transfer well into games. [i]Mad Libs[/i] is one of those. You know, a pad of paper that had short stories into which you would insert wacky words to make them funny. That idea works. It doesn't work so well as a card game, where you create entire sentences from the words on your cards.
I can appreciate the aspects of hand management that are present. Trying to keep a balanced number of nouns, adjectives, verbs, and adverbs is important if you're going to score each round. And to some extent, the potential exists for children to grasp a semblance of proper sentence structure in the process.
For these reasons, I'm giving [i]Mad Libs Card Game[/i] a "2," instead of the "1" it would otherwise have earned. My sons would probably rate it lower. They do not enjoy playing this game, which is a telling fact: at ages eight and six, they are the audience at which a game like this is targeted.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/15/06, Rated: 9[/i]
I love this game. I fear this game.
Over ten years ago, I was really into [i]M:tG,[/i] at least by my own standards. I loved collecting the cards. I obsessed over tuning my decks. I never played in tournaments, but I held my own in pick-up games. I constantly found ways to spend more money. Collectible Card Games (CCG's) are universally evil in this regard.
Looking past its insidious nature, the game itself is awesome. The mechanics are clean, the objectives simple. I love the artwork on the cards, and they have withstood the test of time well. I am sure that it would be a blast to go back and revisit this game.
Yet I am concerned about sharing it with my two sons. The last thing I need to do is foster another CCG addiction. I am already trying to rein in their collecting of [i][thing=2165]Pokémon[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=4154]Yu-Gi-Oh![/thing][/i] cards, when they don't even know how to [i]play[/i] those games.
Ultimately, I will share [i]M:tG[/i] with them, without regard to which cards are currently legal, or how many can be included in a deck, etc. After kicking the habit once, hopefully I can spike that vein again without succumbing to the temptation of buying more.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1994[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 1994[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 11/27/05, Rated: 7[/i]
BGG may call it a "city building" game, but I call it an area control game with a vertical component. Call it 3DAC.
The first aspect of the game to grasp is that of building "element" selection. Elements may be one to four stories in height. If you add an element of your color to an existing building, the total number of stories in your color must be at least equal to the number of stories of any other single player who also has elements in that building. Having the taller elements allows you to "overpower" other colors easily, and take ownership of a particular building. You only have a small number of three- and four-story elements, so you must ration them carefully during the course of the game. I love this part of the game.
You can build in any one of six "cities" (3x3 grids), but the cells in which you can build are randomly determined by cards. Often I will think, "I can take over this building without crushing my opposition, and save a four-story piece. If someone takes it back, I can always add more." This second line is a complete lie. You might not draw the card that allows you to build in that particular spot on the city grids. If you can achieve a five-story lead over another player, then that player won't be able to play again on that particular building. The players in my gaming group call this supremacy move "the drive for five."
You could find yourself gambling with a one-story building that allows you to have a majority within a particular city, hoping that an opponent can't build in that same spot. Solid play and good element selection can still be undone by the cards. I strongly dislike this aspect of the game. It has a healthy helping of "gang up on the leader," but that is true of any game that is played on a common board.
I think that I like area control games in general, but they can also be frustrating to play when luck plays a significant factor. Overall, [i]Manhattan[/i] is a fun game. It is a perfect example of the German game: simple enough to teach to non-gamers, streamlined rules, and surprising depth. It is an excellent introduction to the area control mechanic. Had I played it a year ago, I would have rated it an 8 or a 9. It still may work its way up a notch or two with repeated playings.
item.conditiontext: 1994 Hans im Glück German edition (I like this one better than the Mayfair version). Has standard shelf wear. One ripped corner on the "inserted" box has been repaired. All components and cards are complete and in excellent condition.

item.name: Manila
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 6/27/07, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Manila[/i] is a delightful repackaging of [i][thing=10815]Craps[/thing][/i]. Perhaps that isn't the most accurate analogy, but there are definitely some similarities. Imagine you are walking around a tropically-themed [i][thing=10815]Craps[/thing][/i] table: there are pass line bets (placing your associates on board the punts), come bets (placing your apprentices on board the punts in subsequent rounds), don't pass bets (the shipyard spaces), don't come bets (Pirate spots), and hard ways (dock spaces). The odds are different in [i]Manila,[/i] and you have three different games being played simultaneously, each using only one die.
Okay, I admit that I'm reaching. However, [i][thing=10815]Craps[/thing][/i] is a fun game, and [i]Manila[/i] is too, for many of the same reasons. You can bet on long shots. You can play the odds. There is even an auction which does a good job of balancing the wealth. Side note: in my opinion auction mechanisms are too easily bolted on to games in an effort to compensate for a lack of balance elsewhere. In [i]Manila[/i], the auction does more than normalize resources: it is the only available mechanism to obtain more shares. A stock market determines the value of each trade good, and also acts as the end-game timer.
All of these components, combined with a colorful presentation and pleasing artwork result in a solid game. I'm docking one point for rules which feel unpolished. In at least one instance an attempt to streamline them created an inconsistency: the rules as written allow players to "bet" on a ship that has already come in. Yet that was not the author's original intent according to [article=505355]this post[/article]. Similar ambiguities exist with regard to mortgaged shares, and even what constitutes a successful journey. I'm docking it another point because I'm not sure this game is going to have staying power: if I had a choice of playing [i]Manila,[/i] or one of the games which I have rated a "9," there's no contest: the "9" will win out.
[i]Manila[/i] is a game that my family likes playing. It also allows me to enjoy a [i][thing=10815]Craps[/thing][/i]-like experience without feeling guilty that I'm teaching my sons Vegas-style gambling. They have plenty of time to acquire that appetite on their own.

item.name: Maracaibo
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/25/20, Rated: 6[/i]
This game. I want to like it. I'm [i]trying[/i] to like it. I'm sure I will like it some day, won't I?
I'm a fan of [person=11767][/person]. I adore [i][thing=193738][/thing][/i]. I think it is a sublime example of mechanics, theme, and most importantly, [i]editing[/i]. Everything fits together beautifully, creating a firm foundation for game strategy. That's the bar that has been set.
My first play of [i]Maracaibo[/i] was a laborious affair at BGG.con '19. We were crammed into the Hot Games Room, and had to learn by reading the instructions. We finished our 4P game after four hours of effort, and we had a runaway leader that could have been predicted after the first two rounds. That turns out to be true for the next two games: the winner could be accurately predicted after two rounds. But I'm getting ahead of myself.
After the first play, I was annoyed at the racing aspect of the game. I chafed at having to return to Havana if someone else reached the end of the "trail" first. In [i]GWT[/i], no one else returns to the start when a player reaches Kansas City. I didn't like this mechanic in [i]Maracaibo[/i] especially when, in a 4P game, there was always at least one person who was interested in rushing to the end each round. My plans always got disrupted, except for the one round when I was the person who wanted to rush to the end.
The next two games I played were 2P games, and the "rushed round" mechanism wasn't as pronounced. We could be more deliberate. And what I discovered was that there is a lot of chaos in this game in the form of project cards, quests, and to a lesser extent, combat. At the moment, this is my biggest problem with [i]Maracaibo[/i]: I am unable to effectively plan ahead because I don't know which cards I will have. I don't know for sure if I will be able to satisfy a quest, or deliver a good. I don't know which cards I might have later in the game.
Compare this to [i][thing=193738][/thing][/i] where the layout of neutral buildings is fixed, and the personal buildings that are available are known from the outset. You can (and should!) craft a strategy before you make your first move. In [i]Maracaibo[/i] you can have a desired strategy but still get thwarted based on your project card draws. The end result feels far more tactical and unfulfilling in comparison.
Last night we played 2P games of [i]Maracaibo[/i] and [i][thing=193738][/thing][/i] back-to-back, which ended up providing a stark contrast between the two. [i][thing=193738][/thing][/i] feels like it was edited down to its essentials, while [i]Maracaibo[/i] feels like it has many more layers of complexity and chaos just for their own sake. I might eventually rate this game a "5," but for now I am still hopeful that I will like it more some day.

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment:
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1991[/b]
[i]Posted: 10/26/05, Rated: 8[/i]
Each time that I play this game, I cannot help but think about the moving staircases in the Harry Potter books. In fact, I would not be surprised to learn that this game provided J.K. Rowling with the inspriation for those mischievous banisters.
The game itself has a magical theme, which is appropriate: I get mesmerized watching the board transform. Old passages disappear, and new ones materialize in front of my eyes. The game includes a "wrapping" mechanism: if, by inserting a new maze tile, you push a player's piece or ingredient token off of the board, then that item is placed at the other side of the row, on top of the tile that you just placed. This simple idea results in very interesting scoring and opponent-prevention opportunities.
[i]Master Labyrinth[/i] has the trappings of a confrontational game, but unless you are thinking several possible moves ahead, your opponents may just be able to turn your own spite against you. It's an amazing game (go ahead, give me your obligatory groan), and one that works well with the family.

item.name: Merlin
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/16/17, Rated: 4[/i]
According to my own scale: "4 - Not so good. I would rather not play it, but I could be talked into it on occasion if I have repressed the previous memories." That pretty much sums up my feelings after my first play of [i]Merlin[/i], and it hurts. I really wanted to like this game! [i]Merlin[/i]'s lineage has some serious chops. [designer=4958][/designer] is reaching god-tier status in my mind, and then there's [designer=142][/designer], the designer of [i][thing=24480][/thing][/i]! How could they have gone so very wrong?
Let's begin with a positive: the production values are great. The art, color saturation, the chunky henchman cylinders, and all of the other bits are fantastic. You know that this is a Feld design going in because of all the ingredients being tossed together in the point salad. And dice! I love the tactile feel of rolling dice! I was very eager to learn how these two giants incorporated dice into their design.
Not very well, I'm afraid. I'm about to make an association here that fans of this game are not going to like: it's hard not to make a mental association between the game board in [i]Merlin[/i] and the one from [i][thing=2952][/thing][/i]. There's a ring divided into sextants, with different-colored capstones at the intersections. These are like the "pie spaces" in [i][thing=2952][/thing][/i], only they're four spaces apart rather than seven. There are also no "roll again" spaces, which as it turns out would have been a welcome touch.
There are lots of different actions filling in all of those spaces, and they allow you to interact with the different resource collection and scoring mechanisms. And there are a lot. Again, this is standard Feldian fare, but in [i]Merlin[/i] you really have to have a finger in all of the pies. It isn't like [i][thing=102680][/thing][/i], where you can focus in only two or three areas and still be competitive. And that's the problem: there are so many things to do, the timing of which can be important, and the dice simply don't let you get there. Even if you have the resources and the positioning, you ultimately may not be able to land on the little target space you need.
The end result is a game where many of my turns -- and there aren't very many, four turns per round as you place your dice one at a time, and six total rounds -- were on rails. There wasn't a real decision to be made. [i]Merlin[/i] isn't meant to be a roll and move game, but sometimes it felt like one. Let's just say that the magic is gone. Or rather, that it was never there to begin with.

Mississippi Queen
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1997[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 4th Place 1997[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 10/18/05, Rated: 6[/i]
The first [i]Spiel des Jahres[/i] (SdJ) winner that I just wasn't crazy about after playing. The riverboats are cool little game pieces, and I can see them being the "gimmick" that helped this game to win the SdJ.
Planning ahead is hard to do, especially if you are the front runner. The first person to reach the farthest tile gets to place the next one, but only [i]after[/i] she has finished moving. Often the tile placement will require a sharp turn, or introduce an obstacle directly in front of you. This uncertainty means the person in the lead should cross a new tile at a speed of "3" or "4," or else she will be running out of coal fast as she slams on the brakes. Laggards can be much more efficient. This is a natural mechanism that keeps the players relatively close together, but at the same time it is in conflict with the "racing" nature of the game.
The extreme sensitivity to coal levels wouldn't be so bad if it were possible to fill your bunkers at a station. Perhaps a house rule (or an out of print expansion) will remedy this oversight.
[i]Mississippi Queen[/i] is a simple enough game that looks great and has some innovative pieces. Still, after having played it a few times now, I am left with a feeling of "is that all?" Old Man River may just keep rolling...alone.
[i]Updated: 10/20/05, Rated: 7[/i]
Okay, I have a few more games at the helm. Turn order determination of the full game (with passengers) fosters a breakaway leader problem. I still have some concerns, but it is an enjoyable experience.
Time for me to shorten these comments by writing a full-fledged review.

item.name: Money
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/20/09, Rated: 6[/i]
My first reaction when opening the box was "Is that all there is? A single deck of cards?" Then I got into the rules: bidding to collect sets, using your potentially-scoring cards as the currency, if you will. Very reminiscent of [i][thing=46]Medici[/thing][/i], a [person=2]Knizia[/person] classic.
More scoring quirks with "triplets:" each currency has three cards of denomination "20," and three of denomination "30." If a player has all three cards of the same denomination, of the same currency type, then she scores an extra 100 points. This complication does a nice job of adding value to the lower-denomination cards. The coins make for good fodder for being able to exchange some cards, without offering anything up of real value...until the end, when a coin could be worth more than a regular card, if you don't have at least 100 points in that card's currency.
Because the game's rules are so streamlined, it's easy to teach and to play. It also feels overly light. There's nothing wrong with that, but again there's nothing overly compelling about it, either. If I had my choice of Knizia auction titles, I'd rather play [i][thing=46]Medici[/thing][/i], or [i][thing=12]Ra[/thing][/i]. Perhaps if I made one of [geekurl=/user/Verkisto]Verkisto's[/geekurl] [filepage=38793]tuck boxes[/filepage], the enhanced portability of the game could make it a "situational seven." Even so, it would then compete with the superior [i][thing=12589]Razzia![/thing][/i]
[i]Money[/i] is a great example of a single, well-executed mechanic. I believe this is a recurring trademark of the games in the [family=76]Gryphon Games bookshelf series[/family] -- see my comments for [i][thing=37615]Looting London[/thing][/i]. [i]Money[/i] is a better offering than that other entry, but it isn't compelling enough on its own to join the list of Knizia greats.

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/20/04, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Monopoly[/i] is the classic game that everyone loves to hate. I think that it has a great advantage over many others: everyone has played it at least once. The objections that I often hear against playing it are concerned with how long it takes to play, and the extreme randomness required to obtain a "natural" monopoly.
The misconception about game length arises from the numerous house rules that people have been conditioned to accept as genuine. Common themes include placing fines and income tax fees in the middle of the board, allowing the next person who lands on "Free Parking" to collect the bounty. Removing the "building assessment" cards from the Chance and Community Chest decks. Not charging a ten percent interest fee to unmortgage property. [i]Monopoly[/i] is about forcing the other players to go bankrupt, so these changes lengthen the game.
Similarly, most groups don't auction properties that have been landed upon, but for which the player either did not have enough money to buy at its listed price, or wanted to try to acquire more inexpensively. If your group of players refuses to make deals, and expects to whittle away the competition by charging standard rents, then the game will take forever. When played by the written rules, games can be resolved in less than two hours. If you don't have that much time, then there is a variation for a fast game.
[i]Monopoly[/i] is a game with which everyone is familiar, and can usually be persuaded to play. The universal response that I have received after finishing a game has been "that was much more fun than I remembered!" Does that sentiment mean my friends are less sophisticated in their gaming tastes? Possibly. But I also recognize the value in getting non-hard core gamers to come back to the table and enjoy the experience. In that vein, [i]Monopoly's[/i] familiarity is a welcome asset.
[i]Updated: 9/20/05, Rated: 6[/i]
I still enjoy the occasional game of [i]Monopoly[/i], but I need some more room in the upper scores to be able to differentiate between titles. Slide on down.
[i]Updated: 11/21/10, Rated: 5[/i]
Five years later, board gaming has become a more cultured experience for me. A game can stand out by having a combination of elegant rules, a unique and intriguing mechanism, or striking artwork. A basic game of [i]Monopoly[/i] offers none of these.
What [i]Monopoly[/i] has going for it are the nostalgic memories from my youth. Rolling the dice, moving around the board, and planning my investments can still be pleasing activities from that perspective. They do get repetitive and dull unless the production values are sufficiently high to provide a good tactile experience. A "stock" copy of [i]Monopoly[/i] fails to engage at that level, and so it descends one more notch. Nostalgia will likely buoy the score at this level for the foreseeable future.

item.name: Monopoly: Star Wars Limited Collector's Edition
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/21/05, Rated: 7[/i]
If ever there was a time for a 0.5-point upgrade, this would be it. Style counts for something, and this game has lots of it. The pewter figures have some nice detail, but they're also soft, which means this set isn't appropriate for children.
It's still [i][thing=1406]Monopoly[/thing][/i], for better or for worse. I know that this game gets a lot of abuse here at BGG, but I still enjoy playing it by the rules -- which means jettisoning all of the house rules that have evolved over the years that serve no other purpose than to prolong the game.
At the time of its purchase, this game was a collector's edition, with a numbered board. Since Parker Brothers saw fit to release an "Original Trilogy Edition," I don't know if this version has any real value.

item.name: Mouse Trap
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/12/08, Rated: 4[/i]
[i]Mouse Trap[/i] is another one of those "everyone has played it as a child" kind of games which invokes a weird nostalgia. It really isn't an enjoyable game, but watching the trap "spring" was a wondrous event. How does one reconcile these opposing forces of memory? Perhaps by setting them aside for a moment.
It's almost impossible to think of [i]Mouse Trap[/i] as an adult, and not think "[url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rube_Goldberg_machine]Rube Goldberg machine[/url]:" an extremely complicated apparatus that performs a simple task in an indirect and convoluted way. Here is a very cool example of a Rube Goldberg machine for "dropping" a tea bag into a cup:
[youtube=ZUjK2s7zsSQ] What I didn't know before writing this comment is that [i]Mouse Trap[/i] was actually based on Goldberg's drawings!
Beyond this piece of trivia, the game itself used to be awful. After building the "trap," players would roll, and roll, and roll, and roll until one player was on the "cheese" space, and another was on "turn the crank." If the trap didn't "spring" properly (a distinct possibility, especially when the diver back flips into the pool but doesn't jiggle the cage enough to drop), then more rolling would ensue until the planets were aligned properly once again.
[i]Ugh.[/i]
The new version we acquired to play with our sons (what do you mean, inflicting childhood trauma upon the next generation in the name of tradition is not a good idea?) has tried to alleviate this excruciating end-game with "cheese pieces:" basically, extra rolls during your turn to get an opponent under your trap. I will say that this one addition makes the game slightly more palatable. I enjoyed one session where I was able to trap both of my sons' mice in the same turn.
Even with this improvement, I've had my fill of this game. At least until it's time to unleash it upon the next generation.
