item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/1/11, Rated: 7[/i]
Initially, I was underwhelmed by the contents of this toy-sized box. There isn't a lot of wasted space, but it was difficult to divine how these meager components would approximate the luxurious, tense game play of the [thing=21763]full-sized version[/thing]. Yet when the game got going, I quickly saw how alike the two versions were! True, [i][thing=72287]Pocket[/thing][/i] doesn't provide the same anguish over controlling a board with multiple threat vectors (lights, manholes, and barricades). Yet it still provides tense moments as you try to limit your opponent's options.
As Jack, I found it harder to grow accustomed the winning conditions in the smaller game. In [i][thing=21763]Mr. Jack[/thing][/i], not being caught by the end of the eighth round equals a victory for The Ripper: playing a "delayed game" makes intuitive sense, especially if the Inspector player is doing a good job of preventing your escape. In [i][thing=72287]Pocket[/thing][/i], there is no direct analogy to "escape;" the closest matching condition is Jack collecting six hourglasses. Hourglasses are printed on some alibi cards, and also on the turn tiles; if there is no witness at the end of a turn, then Mr. Jack captures that turn tile and its hourglass.
Thus, it was hard for me to accept "many witnesses" as a viable tactic on a turn, because I didn't want to forfeit the opportunity to earn an hourglass. Once the different paths to victory melded in my brain, the game really opened up. [i][thing=72287]Mr. Jack Pocket[/thing][/i] delivers much of the same flavor as its progenitor, in a surprisingly compact box.

item.name: My Father's Work
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9 DEC 22, Rated: 9[/i]
Let's dispense with the formalities: this game requires an app to play. If that's not your bag, then you can stop reading now. On with the show.
[i]My Father's Work[/i] is an individual tableau-building, worker placement game. A seriously overproduced version that feels like Renegade tried to push every element to eleven. Normally, this is a bad omen as so much chrome attempts to hide mediocre content. [i]MFW[/i] is the delightful exception to this rule.
The basics are familiar and well-worn: use your workers to gather resources and complete buildings and projects. You can use the same public space as another player if you pay an extra fee. You have private spaces on your player board, and you can build more. Some workers are limited by what they can do. You're probably thinking of [thing=31260]several[/thing] [thing=102794]other[/thing] [thing=144733]games[/thing] by now.
What sets [i]MFW[/i] apart is that the theme is integrated [i]everywhere[/i]. It's not just in the sculpted, sundrop-shaded miniatures, the silk-screened wooden resources, or the wonderfully empty and begging to be filled reagent jars. It's in the board artwork, the cards, the background music provided by the app, the narration, and more. Again, I say that the game is overproduced but if that's what it takes to get the theme so intrinsically linked then I'm all for it. It's a long game, but time simply disappears because I get so immersed in the theme.
The game is long because it resurrects a mechanism from [i][thing=5404][/thing][/i]: interim scoring that resets your abilities while leaving what has been built on the board. In [i]MFW[/i] these are the generations of your family, hence the title. There are ways to persist research across generations, and then usually you will be resetting your resources and workers. These gaps also advance the story of the scenario you are playing, with the app narrating and specifying the changes in the town.
These changes are managed by a spiral-bound notebook that you flip to the appropriate page. I love this construct as opposed to adding stickers to the board. I know it spoils the personalizing legacy aspect of a game, but on the other hand it allows you to reset the game without having to buy a pack of replacement stickers.
I'm really excited to play this game some more, even returning to previously-played scenarios to see if I can reach a different ending. The only reason I have docked it a point is that it is a long game. Theoretically the game state can be easily saved and returned to later, but I prefer to settle in for a long afternoon and savor the entire experience.

Niagara
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2005[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 10/11/05, Rated: 9[/i]
I got this game as a gift recently. I requested it because I want to try the various [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i] and [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Deutscher_Spiele_Preis]Deutscher Spiele Preis[/geekurl][/i] winners. The concept and box art are a bit cartoony, and there appears to be a fair amount of backlash towards this title here at BGG.
After a couple of incomplete games played with my family, I am definitely in the honeymoon phase with it. The river mechanism is wonderfully novel. The rules aren't written very concisely, but in practice they are clean and elegant. Gem stealing can be ruthless, but it can also be left out.
The real challenge is in trying to guess which tiles my opponents will be playing, so that I can plan my moves accordingly. Often I have to plan three or four rounds in advance, trying to figure out how I can ride out the river until the tiles are refreshed. Then I can play a five or six to return to shore. I like games that allow for advance planning, and the limited turn options available in [i]Niagara[/i] allow me to do just that.
A game with a novel mechanic, that plays well with the family, that can be as confrontational as you care to make it, and allows a player to plan several moves in advance. A very enjoyable combination!
[i]Updated: 3/31/06, Rated: 8[/i]
PROS: All the same as mentioned above. Still a great game for getting people back into board gaming.
CONS: Even with moderately-experienced players, [i]Niagara[/i] feels like a very scripted experience. Rush for the purple and white gems. If everyone [i]doesn't[/i] do this, then one person is highly likely to win the game by getting four gems of one color. Perhaps fewer gems should be used when playing with less than five people.

item.name: Oh My Goods!
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 29 Nov 2020, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Oh My Goods![/i] has all the right ingredients to be an epic game for me, in a very portable form factor. It is designed by Alexander Pfister whom I love, has action selection, a dash of push your luck, and my favorite mechanism of all, multi-use cards. With those elements it could be a contender for my favorite game of all time, a title held by [i]San Juan[/i].
I own the German/English version of the game. Even though it is perfectly playable, I enjoy it enough that I am considering trying to find an English-only copy which is saying something: I would buy this game twice! I like having to plan your actions using the partial information of the sunrise display. Do I go for an efficient build and hope that the sunset cards complete my required goods? It’s such a simple idea implemented in an elegant way.
I would enjoy the game more if I knew all of the manufacturing chains ahead of time, so I could try to plan for a specific sequence. I’m sure there are forum posts or player-made aids to help with this. The one drawback to this is the apparent dearth of critical cards. For example, let’s say that I want to make shoes because I have a Shoemaker card in my hand (there are three of them in the game). I build a Cattle Ranch of which there are six in the game. The next building I need is a Tannery, of which there are only three. On the surface that is fine, because hides from the Tannery are only used by the Shoemaker. But the rub here has to do with the economy, and how cards are used to represent goods.
Just like [i]San Juan[/i], cards are placed face-down on production buildings to represent goods. The difference between the games is that in [i]Oh My Goods![/i] you can place multiple cards on a building. They only get discarded to generate income, or to activate a production chain (cattle into hides in the example above). This means a card could be out of the game for a while, waiting to be spent. If those cards are the Tanneries, then you’ll never see them until they are spent, and then only when the discard pile gets shuffled back into the draw pile. The more players and thus buildings there are being activated, the more pronounced this unintentional “card exile” effect becomes.
The net result is that you might end up ditching the attempt to make shoes at all, but now you have a Cattle Ranch that you need to repurpose. That’s fine because there is another building that can use cattle, but what if you have a Tannery and the Shoemakers are exiled? You won’t be able to produce that satisfying third level of good. That means the game boils down to more of a race to eight buildings to trigger the end game.
My guess is that this dynamic means [i]Oh My Goods![/i] is best when played with two, so you have more access to the cards you want. It’s still a fun game and I’m looking forward to exploring it more, but for now it does not dethrone [i]San Juan[/i]. The more transient nature of goods in [i]San Juan[/i] means that cards are not removed from the game for long, unless you decide to bury them under a Chapel. It’s an intentional choice, which means the decision space in [i]San Juan[/i] is deeper and more rewarding.

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/4/17, Rated: 9[/i]
I've been playing [i]Werewolf[/i] on the forums here at BGG since 2004. It is an amazing game of social deduction and deception, and I made many friends whom I have met in real life at BGG.con as a result. Still, the most memorable games are the ones which come down to a final three, or some other form of "must win" for the village. [i]One Night Ultimate Werewolf[/i] basically distills that experience down to a six-minute affair, ending in one vote, winning team takes all.
The idea of having an app be the moderator is a brilliant one, and also one of those "why didn't I think of that?" kind of moments. The narration by Eric Summerer of Dice Tower fame is perfect (side note: newer versions of the app have added a woman narrator's voice as well, but we still prefer Eric's). There are plenty of roles to include, and not a whole lot of direction; I suppose the real idea is to just try different things because each game only lasts a few minutes.
Since the game is so quick and balance is left up to the players, I would lean towards giving [i]ONUWW[/i] a rating of "8." However, it has been a hit with every group to which I have introduced it, to the point where family friends of ours have purchased their own copy, and my son wanted his own to take to college. A game that approachable deserves an extra point.

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf: Daybreak
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/4/17, Rated: 5[/i]
This one will require more playings, if I can stomach the attempts. "More variety" sounds like a good thing, but the two roles which add new mechanics (Sentinel, Curator) are not a lot of fun. Both of them prove their existence or else their being exiled to the center with the presence of their unique tokens. Evil players will have to jump on the claim if they're looking to hide, but then you're narrowing down the voting pool to one of two claimants.
Don't get me started on the Village Idiot. That's a role that basically shouldn't exist. [i]Ever[/i].
The additional wolf powers are interesting, in particular the Alpha Wolf. Perhaps some of these roles start to make more sense with higher player counts; we rarely have a chance to play with more than six. Basically, I don't see this set as being a required addition when the original is already so good on its own -- unless you've already played that one to death!

item.wishlistcomment: I play One Night a lot with my sons. Here's a chance to expand the relatively limited role set included with the original. Even if they are a bit broken, the games don't last very long.

item.name: Onitama
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/14/20, Rated: 9[/i]
Now [i]this[/i] is what an abstract with variability should be! Yes, I'm talking to you, [i][thing=257601]Duke[/thing][/i].
Such a simple premise: the movement abilities of your pieces are going to change from game to game. Each time you sit down to play, you will draw five movement cards that will rotate between the two players and which [i]will never change[/i]. Boom! Instant replayability, but each game is going to be a fixed experience.
All of that delicious planning that is found in abstract games is still here, only now there is an added dimension: influencing how your opponent will be able to move. Many times holding on to a highly mobile card and the threat it represents is enough of a reason not to use it. Finally a situation arises where the payoff is too great to ignore and you play it, but you know your opponent will soon be holding that same threat over your head. Maybe you even engineer that payoff in order to pry that card out of your opponent's hand, and so on.
Awesome!
Production quality is great. I think the use of a neoprene mat as the board enhances the "travelability" of [i]Onitama[/i], but it still doesn't match [i][thing=2655][/thing][/i] or [i][thing=154597][/thing][/i] for durability. I might look into sleeving the cards to extend their longevity, but it's not like they're constantly being shuffled like a deck builder.
[i]Onitama[/i] is a great variation on the classic abstract model. Simple rules that are easy to understand that reveal surprising depth, with an injection of setup randomness. Highly recommended!

Orléans Stories
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/17/20, Rated: 4[/i]
This is the poster child for my definition of a 4: “Not so good. I would rather not play it, but I could be talked into it on occasion if I have repressed the previous memories.” I [i]so[/i] wanted to like this game when we sat down to play it because I love [i]Orléans[/i]. Somehow we ended up playing the second scenario (the long game), and it sucked all of the fun right out of the air.
Imagine if you played a game of [i]Phase 10[/i], where every hand was a full game of [i]Orléans[/i]. That’s what the long game of [i]Stories[/i] is like. Players try to advance through “ages,” with each age having its own requirements to fulfill. Like [i]Orléans[/i], players will take multiple turns drawing worker tokens from their bags and then placing them. The round ends when players have drawn their allotment of workers. If at the end of a round you have not fulfilled your age’s requirements, then you will try again in the following round while other players might move on.
We decided to stop playing after six hours and the end still wasn’t in sight. One player had managed to get a couple of ages ahead, so we were fine conceding the game to him so we could go try something else.
I hope there is a compelling experience in here. My attempt to play it was very disappointing, and at that game length there are many other surefire hits that I’d rather play.

item.name: The Palace of Mad King Ludwig
Palazzo
item.comment:
Alea Medium-Box #2
[i]Posted: 2/24/08, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Palazzo[/i] is the second title in the [family=59]Alea Medium Box series[/family]. The first game, [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] is a surprisingly meaty entry from [person=381]Rüdiger Dorn[/person] which offers a very robust experience for such demure packaging. The series is off to a very good start when the second entry has been designed by the [person=2]Good Doctor[/person] himself. Thus, I had high expectations for [i]Palazzo[/i].
What did I find? Let's see here...players are builders and master architects in the city of Florence, in the 15th century. Wow, that's new and interesting. I'm glad for this period of time, simply because we would be missing out on so many games without it. This overused theme no longer inbues me with excitement and anticipation, and I have to say it prevented this game from making it to the table for a while.
Unsurprisingly, [i]Palazzo[/i] turns out to be a well-constructed game. The stutter-step nature of placing tiles in the quarries based on the location of the "Master Architect" piece was interesting. Controlling when and how many pieces are auctioned is an important consideration. Earlier in the game you can risk carrying an extra piece in your inventory because you should be able to choose the "reconstruction" option before the game ends. Later in the game, you'll want to play more conservatively so you don't get caught with a single-story building, which incurs a penalty. Hand management plays a part as well, as you look for sets of cards for a bonus, or else several cards of a particular "currency" (suit) in order to be successful in the auctions.
These tactical considerations are enjoyable, but they aren't as important as getting lucky with good options in the material supply. Being able to purchase a tile you need, when you need it, without competition turns out to be a huge advantage. The staged tiles lend structure to the game, so that you're usually bidding on top-tiered tiles (the "level 5's") at the end of the game. Also, the game's end is triggered randomly, so you can't be assured of having enough time to reduce your exposure to penalties. I enjoyed this added tension.
[i]Palazzo[/i] is a good game, if not a particularly memorable one. It doesn't surprise with depth like [i][gameid=13642][/i]. If I wasn't collecting Alea games, then I would probably have passed on this one.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment:
[color=#959595][size=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2009[/size][/color] [color=#959595][size=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 2009[/size][/color]
[i]Posted: 4/6/10, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: 9, 3P: 10, 4: 8}
[i]Pandemic[/i] is one of those games that gets a tremendous amount of "buzz" here on the Geek. It is a cooperative title, which means players are working together to beat the game instead of each other. In this case, it means they are trying to find cures to four globally-threatening diseases. The subject matter of global epidemics isn't sexy in the slightest, but it very quickly grows on you all the same.
The amazing feature of [i]Pandemic[/i] is how refined it is. It embodies Albert Einstein's quote, "Make things as simple as possible, but not simpler." Each player gets four action points per turn, and can choose from a list of basic and advanced actions. Reference cards are provided, which is always a nice touch. She can also use her role's special power; there are five roles provided in the game. You would think that this recipe is bland enough for the game to feel "solved," but that's not the case. After having played over 50 games online and in person, I am still surprised by the creativity of some players.
The method of spreading disease has been perfectly implemented. Reshuffling the discard pile onto the top of the Infection Deck after an epidemic does a wonderful job of making sick places...sicker. You dread the "Draw 2 Player Cards" phase of your turn as you feel an epidemic lurking around the corner. There is a sense of urgency to do as much as you can to knock down the "hot spots" before the next one strikes. Two epidemics in rapid succession can be fatal.
The difficulty of the game can easily scale by adjusting the number of "Epidemic" cards in the Infection Deck. Player-wise, the game doesn't scale as well: the 2 player game is almost too easy (even at "Hard" difficulty), the 3 player game is perfection, and the 4 player game is very difficult. Hand management is the differentiator: in a 2p game, it is easier for one player to find a "cure" by collecting five cards of the same color, only four cards if you have the "Researcher" role. In a 4p game the cards are spread out, and players have to use turns trying to pass cards between each other instead of treating infected cities. Minus one point for this lack of scalability. Interestingly, [thing=40849]the expansion's[/thing] introduction of a "Legendary" difficulty provides a solution.
Cooperative games resonate with me, because they offer me a chance to teach a game, and also try to win at the same time. [i]Pandemic[/i] has a theme which allows for a streamlined rule set which also provides a compelling challenge. You can even [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/Spiele/Pandemie/]play it online for free[/url]. Don't be inoculated by all of the hype: [i]Pandemic[/i] really is a game you should try.
item.conditiontext: Complete and in pristine condition. [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/user/carl67lp]carl67lp's[/url] [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/file/info/31311]tuck boxes[/url] made. Sleeved.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/7/10, Rated: 10[/i]
[i]Pandemic: On the Brink[/i] satisfies the simplest requirement of an expansion: it improves the play of the [thing=30549]original game[/thing]. In this case, that's saying a lot. [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] is already a fantastic game in my opinion. It wasn't perfect, though: there were some scalability issues that were intertwined with the game's difficulty. [i]On the Brink[/i] solves these problems, and then adds a little bit more.
The one drawback to [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] was that it was too easy with two players, just right with three, and too hard with four. Two players have an easier time finding cures by collecting sets of cards, because the cards are narrowly distributed. The players don't have to arrange meet-ups to pass cards, leaving more opportunities to treat diseases and to prevent outbreaks. Cards are widely distributed amongst four players, which means those players must spend more actions trying to pass cards in order to create sets. Thus, the 2p game was too easy, even when played on "Hard" difficulty (6 epidemics). The 4p game was harder, even when played on "Easy" (4 epidemics).
[i]On the Brink[/i] provides two answers. The first is simple: the introduction of "Legendary" difficulty, which adds an extra "epidemic" card for a total of seven. The second is the inclusion of more roles. These new roles enhance replayability. Some, like the Containment Specialist, help to automatically knock down "hot spots," while others improve player mobility. The "Operations Expert" has been updated to include a very useful ability: while at a city with a research center, spend a card to charter a flight anywhere (the card doesn't have to match your city). What this really means is that the Ops Expert can drop a center at his feet, and then travel anywhere on the board. Very handy.
These two additions fix the main objection I had with [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i]. If [i]On the Brink[/i] did nothing else, it would still be great. However, it does a lot more. It adds new event cards. There's the mutation variant, and the non-PC but still interesting bio-terrorist option. The inclusion of petri dishes to use as storage containers for the blocks is brilliant, and increases my immersion with this game.
Now, some people will argue that some of these items such as the added roles and the petri dishes should be included in the base game. "Pshaw," I say! [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] is still a great game on its own. However, if you're looking for a bit more, then [i]On the Brink[/i] is definitely a worthwhile purchase. Quoting [i][url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088258/]Nigel Tufnel[/url][/i], "this one goes to eleven."

item.name: Patrician
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/17/17 Rated: 6[/i]
Mechanically speaking, [i]Patrician[/i] is a sound game. I can feel the maths at play: each city can support an odd numbered amount of floors being placed within it, which guarantees one tower will be higher than the other. The deck of cards represents all of the floors that can be built across the entire board, and no more. Choosing to place a card in one city may be done simply to capture the building card it offers for use on a subsequent turn.
All of that clever design work is present. In total, [i]Patrician[/i] feels like a very solvable puzzle. You can plan ahead for when you are going to place a floor in a given city, knowing your current representation vs. your opponents', and how many opportunities are still left. The whole idea of building "patrician towers" doesn't resonate, though; you're still battling known quantities and calculating the numbers for majorities.
The art on the cover is quite nice. I find the art of the board and cards to be very apropos of the "noughties:" bland earth tones with subdued color highlights. It's not the gaudy, primary colorfest of games from the nineties, nor is it the overblown, highly artistic expressions we've come to expect form current games. It's good and serviceable for its time, but it shows its age.
As an introduction to the "area control" mechanic, I find [i]Patrician[/i] to be perfectly serviceable. Beyond that, I suppose it is relatively quick and the finite amount of information to be juggled makes it feel less random in its outcomes. There's a definite hint of that "initiation angst" that I so dearly love in [i][thing=50][/thing][/i]. I doubt that [i]Patrician[/i] has the same kind of staying power.

item.name: Penguin Pat's Fishy Business
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/13/06, Rated: 4[/i]
Yes, I actually own this game. Yes, I am bothering to rate it. This game is obviously one to be played with children. It becomes tolerable if you make a habit of talking to Pat as he "waddles" around his track:
Pat: "You look like you could use a fish. Go ahead and take..."
Beowulf, a.k.a. "Daddy:" "Two fish, please!"
Pat: "...[i]two[/i] fish!"
Endless mirth ensues as progeny politley petition Pat the Penguin Engine to parse out his plastic pisces.
Downright enjoyable if everyone flaps their [-]chicken[/-] penguin wings to the tune of Pat's victory song.

item.name: Penny Papers Adventures: The Temple of Apikhabou – Santa's Secret Lair
Petrichor: Honeybee – The Swarming Promo Card
Phase 10
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/19/07, Rated: 4[/i]
My definition of a "4" is "Not so good. Would rather not play it, but I could be talked into it on occasion if I have repressed the previous memories." For more scintillating descriptions of my thoughts on ratings, please check out [geekurl=/user/Beowulf]my profile[/geekurl]. But I digress: My introduction to this game was in an Irish bar in San Francisco. No, this is not the opening line of a joke, although I wish it was.
As it turns out, [i]Phase 10[/i] (like any other [i][thing=15878]Rummy[/thing][/i] game) punishes poor play with a huge distancing penalty in its "phases:" the requirements for you to be able to meld. If you complete the first phase, then you move on to the second. If you haven't completed your phase by the time another player goes out, then you attempt that same phase in the following hand. This setback happened to me repeatedly in San Francisco: one player didn't pay attention to the person who followed her, and she kept feeding him the cards that he needed. I missed completing several Phases as a result, for an excruciating experience.
This past weekend I found myself wanting to bring a game to a beach campout. I reluctantly decided to buy [i]Phase 10.[/i] This time around the players were paying attention, and I was surprised to find that I actually enjoyed it. It was inexpensive, quick to teach, and I definitely wasn't going to be upset if the game got totalled. We had a good time playing in the glow of a Coleman lantern.
I could be talked into playing it again. I don't even have to repress the previous memories; I just need to be on a campout where I'm not willing to ruin games that I actually care about.
[i]Updated: 11/29/10, Rated: 3[/i]
Actually, I do have to repress the memories. I played this game again over the Thanksgiving holiday, and it was horrendous. It took us seventeen hands over two hours to complete the game. That's too long of an investment for this experience. [i]And I won.[/i]
Phases 4, 5, and 6 are "a run of 7," "a run of 8," and "a run of 9." Unless you get extremely lucky on the draw, you're sitting there waiting forever for the right middle number to show up. If someone goes out before you're ready, then start over!
Phases 8, 9, and 10 are variations of "collect sets:" two sets of four, a set of five and a set of two, and then a set of five and a set of three. There are only eight cards of any given value, so you're hoping for wild cards, or else that you've picked a number that isn't being collected by another player. It's possible to realize that you are competing, and then be unable to switch numbers. Start over.
[i][thing=22664]Phase 10 Masters Edition[/thing][/i] is an improvement because it does allow you to select the phase for which you're trying: if you are dealt a great hand for a run, then knock one of those out. The original game devolves to bunch of turn-and-discard without much thought. No, thank you.
item.conditiontext: © 2004 Fundex Games. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/15/06, Rated: 6[/i]
A [i]very[/i] light game. Light enough that I'm considering moving all of my previously-weighed "light" games up to "light medium." For the most part a "push your luck" game, trying to get the higher numbers, or later in the game trying to roll an exact number so you can steal a tile from an opponent.
There is some strategy involved. Take a lower number after grabbing a high one, to protect the latter. The game really becomes evil if all of the low numbers are exhausted early, and people fail to earn the higher tiles in the later rounds. Tactically speaking, it does require some simple addition, as you try to figure out the best way to roll a particular number. Obviously, luck plays an extremely large factor.
A fun, end of the evening game. I'll gladly play if someone suggests (and brings) it, but I'm not sure that it is compelling enough for me to purchase.
[i]Updated: 12/22/06, Rated: 7[/i]
I've changed my mind about this game. Oh, it can still be brutal, and it almost always fosters a runaway leader. Those issues aside, it has been a great title for non-gamers. I created a home-made copy while staying at a cousin's house, and suddenly we were playing it every night. I've taken it on campouts with scouts, and it received a ton of interest. This is a must-have for any collection, even if the game play isn't perfect.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
Pirate's Cove
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 9th Place 2002[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 2/4/06, Rated: 7[/i]
On the surface, [i]Pirate's Cove[/i] is a fine looking ship. Unfortunately, she's taking on water faster than her bilge pumps can bail out.
Production values abound in this swashbuckling game. I really like the idea of improving the various sections of the ship, and balancing your "resources" such as money, treasure, fame points, and Tavern Cards. There is a definite undercurrent of [i][thing=3076]Puerto Rico[/thing][/i] in which the earlier part of the game should be spent maximizing money, and then there is a shift to [-]Victory Points[/-] Fame Points toward the end.
Then Combat rears its ugly head. Initiative is determined, and the attacking player rolls a number of dice set by her ship's characteristics. At this point, the game devolves to [i][thing=2243]Yahtzee[/thing][/i], or [i][thing=8689]Bunco[/thing][/i]. All of that early money that you pumped into your ship can be quickly undone by a lucky roll of the dice. You don't even get a chance to defend like you can in [i][thing=181]Risk[/thing][/i].
As a result, players' moves are often telegraphed. Lose all of your crew points? You'll be headed to Crew Island, Matey. Take a big hit to your hull? Then it's off to Hull Island for you! Unless a lucrative Treasure Card is waiting on Hull Island, in which case you may have to slink away to some other location while a healthier ship plunders it.
The game ends up feeling very scripted, without a lot of real choices. Ganging up on the leader is easy enough to do. It is fun to take two or more damaged ships and defeat a healthy one. Table talk makes this kind of coordination easy, and my group is considering disallowing any -- other than the obligatory cries of "Scallywag!" as battle is enjoined.
Theme counts for something, and in this case it counts for a full point added to an otherwise middling score of "6." [i]Pirate's Cove[/i] may have a fresh coat of paint, but any semblance of long-term strategy has been pillaged from it.
[i]Updated: 7/13/10, Rated: 6[/i]
With the advent of other, more enjoyable pirate-themed games (Ahoy, [i][thing=28023]Jamaica[/thing][/i]!), [i]Pirate's Cove[/i] is no longer compelling. The play is a "5" at best, but I'll still give it an extra point for its lavish production values.

item.name: Poker
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/12/08, Rated: 9[/i]
Saying I "own" [i]Poker[/i] is silly, since I'm basically stating that I own a deck of cards. And some chips. And a willingness to risk my own money when playing. And that's the real catch when it comes to [i]Poker:[/i]
It just isn't as much fun if you're not playing for cash. Even playing for chips-only without a buy-in isn't as much fun. Minus one point for this limitation.
Beyond that one drawback, [i]Poker[/i] is an amazingly fun and absorbing game. Especially so if you have a regular group of friends with whom you play. Learning to read each other, or at least altering your play to accommodate their unexpected plays. Yes, you know who you are: you folks who stay in with a pair of sevens against my strong bluff of a flush. [i]Poker[/i] can definitely be a whirlwind of emotion from hand-to-hand, with the need to hide those same emotions.
There's one last item worth mentioning, for those of you who haven't played much before: watching the [i]World Series of Poker[/i] on TV is nothing like playing the real game. You (usually!) won't see so much drama in a half-hour of play as you will while watching that show. Please keep in mind that you're only watching those players play their good hands!
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=32]BGWS Review (Poker Chips)[/url]

item.name: Port Royal: The Dice Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 27 JUN 2024, Rated: 6[/i]
I'm a huge fan of [person=11767][/person]'s. I also enjoy [i][thing=156009][/thing][/i]. Picking up this game was a no-brainer, and I wanted to like it.
It's okay.
I'll make the explanation simple: there's a reason why card decks are situationally better randomizers than dice, and it has to do with dependent vs. independent events. Each card draw affects the probability of the next card draw because you are not replacing the card into the deck. That means that if the game lasts long enough, you'll see every card, and enjoy the full breadth of possibility.
When you roll a die, each roll is independent of the previous rolls. In this game, you could roll the same failing results on multiple consecutive turns. Variety in your abilities comes from the islands you reach and cross out, and the separation of them on the map dictates a strategy.
For example, in Chapter 1 you might choose to go with a "repel" strategy trying to collect cutlasses and orange wheels. Those are in a different direction from "Passengers" which earns a lot of points. Perhaps you could try to repel your way to an instant-win condition like only having 11 points and then placing a total of 7 ships and/or ship wheels on the board during your turn.
There's also the weird decision to allow other players to draft ships or wheels from your results -- even if you fail. Sharing the dice results was well executed in [i][thing=111148][/thing][/i], but it adds a negative incentive to push my luck here. It's not just that I might fail, but that more opponents will benefit if I go farther before I do. That's not as much fun.
In the end I love rolling dice and pirates, and I like the sequence of "chapters." It's fine, but it doesn't stand out.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Recommendation 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 9/26/05, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: ?, 3P: ?, 4P: 9, 5P: ?, 6P: ?}
I tried several times to read through the rules, but just couldn't make heads or tails out of them. Deciding to forge ahead, I got a couple of games in with some friends of mine, and experienced that "aha!" moment as the rules fell into place.
I sat in wonder as I watched the commodity markets rise and fall. I struggled to find the "perfect bid" to either buy a power plant, or to make its cost of acquisition dear enough to an opponent to preclude him from trumping my bid and also being able to connect to another city. Hoarding resources in an unused power plant just to suck money away from my competition by forcing them to buy at a higher cost. Using city placement as a weapon for map control.
[i]Power Grid[/i] is a lot of fun to play. I'll dock it one point for the constant need to recalculate connection and resource costs that really bogs down the auction phase. I am eagerly awaiting my next opportunity to play!
[i]Refreshed: 5/19/15, Rated: 9[/i]
Perhaps I should have waited the full ten years before revisiting this score, but I recently played [thing=155873]the deluxe version[/thing] and wanted to update my comments here while the memory is fresh.
The formula still works after all this time. I think the greatest testament to the game is that the theme just works: when I look at the board after completing a game, a critical eye wonders if this is some sort of area control game like [i][thing=491][/thing][/i]/[i][thing=18100][/thing][/i] (it isn't), or else a "chain game" like [i][thing=475][/thing][/i] (it isn't that, either). The theme is so well integrated that I can't deconstruct it into various mechanics: I feel like I just managed a power company and enjoyed every minute of it.
Calculating acceptable auction prices gets easier with practice. I still agree with a rating of "9," although my reason for withholding that final point has changed. The interaction between the power plant market and the "steps" in the game is fiddly. When the game is cruising it is seamless, but then there's this jarring aspect of trying to remember what to do when advancing to the next step. It is easy to forget things, and I don't like game results with asterisks due to misplayed rules.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=35]BGWS Review[/url]
item.conditiontext: Second edition by Rio Grande Games with the corrected "29 Plant" card.

item.name: Power Grid Deluxe: Europe/North America
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/28/15, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: ?, 3P: ?, 4P: 9, 5P: ?, 6P: ?}
It's a bit odd posting a separate comment for the [thing=2651]same game[/thing]. Thus, I will focus on what is unique to this version.
First of all, there is a map of North America including Canada and Mexico! I know the original game had a U.S. map on one side. The map here is larger, and has more cities including "double cities" for New York and Mexico City (players may place two generators in each). The connection costs have changed slightly. There is more open space on the map, which I like; the first game's map feels claustrophobic in comparison. The coloring is much more subdued, with the oceans being light beige. The coloring of the new power plant cards is also more subdued, and I like it.
The "resourceeples" in this version are custom wooden shapes that make sense: coal looks like lumps of coal, natural gas (the replacement for "garbage") looks like a blue flame, oil looks like an oil drop, and nuclear fuel is a cool-looking, red radioactive trefoil. The coins are serviceable plastic ones that will withstand many playings. They are a definite improvement over the paper money from the original.
What really holds up though is the theme. It just [i]works[/i], even ten years later. It is so well integrated that I can't deconstruct [i]Power Grid[/i] into discrete mechanics; I feel like I just managed a power company and enjoyed every minute of it. These new components help me to get immersed.
I am withholding one point for the rules. Specifically, the interaction between the power plant market and the "steps" in the game is fiddly. When the game is cruising it is seamless, but then there are these jarring moments when I have to remember what to do when advancing to the next step. It is easy to forget things, and I don't like game results with asterisks due to misplayed rules.
[i]Power Grid[/i] is still an incredible game, and this version is a wonderful tribute that enhances my enjoyment of the original in almost every way.

item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2002[/SIZE][/COLOR] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2002[/b] Alea Big-Box #7
[i]Posted: 10/3/05, Rated: 8[/i]
After four or five games of [i]Puerto Rico[/i], I can say that I really like it. From the stutter-step turn order of the Governor placard, to the seemingly myriads of tactical uses for the different roles (offensive captaining is so much fun!), there are a lot of nuances to absorb.
I have not yet tried the online version of this game on BSW, for the simple reason that I don't want to be ridiculed for being a newbie. I know I am. My skill level is proportionate to my gaming group, and we enjoy playing this game.
However, it is a bit more complicated, and takes longer to play than [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i]. Right now, [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] gets more table time, simply because it is easier to approach and to learn. For that reason, [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] gets the "9," and [i]Puerto Rico[/i] the "8." Perhaps in a few months time as the group's abilities improve, these positions will be reversed.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 06 FEB 2024, Rated: 8[/i]
My original plays of this game were logged six years ago. I found it to be a serviceable deckbuilder, although one that was on the lean side as far as the number of purchases to be made. You can only purchase one card on your turn, and the key decision isn't when to "green" your deck by buying point-scoring cards like it is in [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i], but rather when to stop adding cards and making a run for the finish line.
Deckbuilding has been added to a lot of new games since then, and I've become accustomed to the "buy well, buy few" concept. Returning to [i]Quest[/i] felt like a breath of fresh air. In typical Knizia fashion, there are different mechanics for the same resources depending on their actions. When you're moving, you must be able to satisfy the target space's requirements with a single card; you may not combine cards to pay for movement. But when your buying a card, you can combine the purchasing power of multiple cards. Simple yet brilliant!
The result is a game that shines. It's not without its quirks. I've seen blowout wins, especially when one player misses out on an opportunity to buy an early Photographer. There are ways to recover, sure, but you have to pursue them quickly. I think the Cartographer is the most overpowered card in the game. Allowing one player to get a majority of them (or worse, [i]all[/i] of them) is a recipe for disaster.
I'm now enjoying [i]The Quest for El Dorado[/i] much more than I originally did, and I'm looking forward to exploring the expansions.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 06 FEB 2024, Rated: 9[/i]
My original plays of this game were logged six years ago. I found it to be a serviceable deckbuilder, although one that was on the lean side as far as the number of purchases to be made. You can only purchase one card on your turn, and the key decision isn't when to "green" your deck by buying point-scoring cards like it is in [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i], but rather when to stop adding cards and making a run for the finish line.
Deckbuilding has been added to a lot of new games since then, and I've become accustomed to the "buy well, buy few" concept. Returning to [i]Quest[/i] felt like a breath of fresh air. In typical Knizia fashion, there are different mechanics for the same resources depending on their actions. When you're moving, you must be able to satisfy the target space's requirements with a single card; you may not combine cards to pay for movement. But when your buying a card, you can combine the purchasing power of multiple cards. Simple yet brilliant!
The result is a game that shines. It's not without its quirks. I've seen blowout wins, especially when one player misses out on an opportunity to buy an early Photographer. There are ways to recover, sure, but you have to pursue them quickly. I think the Cartographer is the most overpowered card in the game. Allowing one player to get a majority of them (or worse, [i]all[/i] of them) is a recipe for disaster.
I'm now enjoying [i]The Quest for El Dorado[/i] much more than I originally did, and I'm looking forward to exploring the expansions. I'm giving the [version=515452]Nordic edition[/version] with artwork by [boardgameartist=12130][/boardgameartist] an extra star. The cover art alone has intrigued my family into wanting to play this game more. That extra star is well earned.

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
[b][media=486616]Replayable Episode 6[/media][/b]
[i]Posted: 27 JUL 2009, Rated: 9[/i]
"Life is like a sewer: What you get out of it, depends upon what you put into it." - Tom Lehrer
That's about as metaphysical of a statement as I can think of to try to describe [i]Ra[/i]. It is a classic Knizia design: very solid auction mechanics, an intricate scoring schedule, and an Egyptian theme.
I'm not the kind of player to complain about themes being "pasted on," by the way. A game that is overly thematic tends to have fiddly rules in order to support that theme. A game with simple, elegant rules is often accused of having its theme "pasted on." Hogwash. I prefer games with streamlined rules which can be evaluated objectively. Theme is a subjective element: the richness of the game world can either increase or diminish the overall experience. [i]Ra[/i] has a set of well-defined rules which are easy to understand. The artwork and production value of my copy -- in other words, the execution of the Egyptian "theme" -- greatly enhances my enjoyment of this game.
The foundation of this game is "pushing your luck." You can try to get more tiles, or you can try to purchase the ones that are already displayed. You can go too far, though, and end up with nothing. Such brinksmanship is a solid start to any game.
The challenge of an auction mechanism is found in learning how to value the items up for bid. In fact, I contend that the longer it takes to acquire this skill, the more enjoyment can be squeezed from a game like [i]Ra[/i]. Once that learning curve has been surmounted, an auction game becomes more deterministic. And it is here that [i]Ra's[/i] convoluted scoring schedule is both a benefit and a curse: it can take a long time to learn how to value all of the different types of tiles. Five games would be just a start. With my family, it's hard to get a game of this weight to the table that many times if they're not "getting it." By the same token, it is this complexity which gives [i]Ra[/i] longer gaming legs. It's a paradox.
What does help is the fixed bid mechanism: you can only bid one of your "sun tiles," and there is only one round of bidding. [i]Ra[/i] pulls this off with far more aplomb than the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i]-winning [i][thing=110]Auf Achse[/thing][/i]. Their fixed amounts also relax the need to precisely calculate the value of an auction lot. The interplay between value and purchasing power, flowing on a river of chance is where the beauty of [i]Ra[/i] truly resides.
If I had to pare my collection down to a small number of titles, then [i]Ra[/i] would definitely make the cut. As it stands today, it's a beautifully-produced game with strong mechanics that doesn't drive enough demand. We haven't been willing to invest the necessary time to get our full measure of enjoyment from it.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 10/23/12, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Race for the Galaxy[/i] shares the same progenitor in [i][thing=3076][/thing][/i] as [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i]. The two are often discussed in the same breath, which is sometimes accompanied by a mention of [i][thing=19857][/thing][/i]. All of them are great games, and they do feel similar.
[i]RFTG[/i] is the only one with the futuristic theme. Its art quality and point limitation (a feature from [i][thing=3076][/thing][/i] that is missing from [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i]) set it apart from the other two titles. It has a rich iconography to describe card abilities, which translates to a learning curve. If you're not playing this game with any real frequency, then you will have to re-familiarize yourself with these symbols. This information also serves as a learning barrier to new players; -1 point.
Each turn, players choose the role that they want to play. [i]RFTG[/i] differentiates itself in this phase as well. In Puerto Rico, only one player can choose a role placard and utilize its special benefit each round. In [i]RFTG[/i], players may end up choosing the same role. This key point means that you are not saddled with a "least worst" decision if the role you really wanted has already been taken.
[i]Race for the Galaxy[/i] thus contains many of the similar mechanics, but ends up feeling like its own game. I do appreciate the theme, but I believe the streamlined, more approachable nature of [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i] gives that title the edge.

item.name: Rail Baron
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/24/05, Rated: 7[/i]
At its core, [i]Rail Baron[/i] is about rolling the dice, and moving your train to the next, randomly-selected destination. Trains go where the rails lead, and in this game you travel along pre-printed rail lines to get there. These game mechanics are simple, and are easy to learn: you don't have to worry about matching shipping manifests with cities that have a high demand for certain goods.
The choices you do have to make are concerned with which rail lines will you purchase? It is common to see certain cities "locked out" by having all of their available routes purchased by other players. Luck factors heavily into the game at this point, as several unfortunate destination rolls may cause you to pay exorbitant fees to ride on someone else's lines.
A couple of drawbacks include the payoff system, which requires frequent lookups on a table to determine the money earned for completing a trip. Another irritation is trying to determine the most cost-effective route between two points, and then making sure you pay the appropriate owners of any line segments you may have used along the way.
Still, [i]Rail Baron[/i] is fun to play, if a tad on the long side for its simplicity.

item.name: Railroad Ink Challenge: Shining Yellow Edition
Railroad Tycoon: The Boardgame
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/8/07, Rated: 9[/i]
The verdict is in: I love train games. No, that's not an invitation to exhume the worn-out debate over the definition of a train game. Trains have universal appeal. I like the theme. My family enjoys it, and my friends enjoy it. That's good enough for me.
[i]Railroad Tycoon[/i] was the next logical step after [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=94]Union Pacific[/thing][/i]. [i]Railroad Tycoon[/i] provides additional layers of complexity by allowing players to lay out their tracks, instead of providing pre-printed segments. Set collection isn't a part of [i]Railroad Tycoon.[/i] Segments, or "links" as they're called, are not exclusive: it is possible for other players to use your rails, to your benefit.
Efficiently building your infrastructure, managing your debt, and delivering the desired goods to each city is the core of this game. Each one of those items sounds like it is complicated, but Wallace pulls it all off with aplomb. The rules feel very streamlined, and are easy to understand. Once a few example turns have been provided, most new players are ready to jump in with both feet.
Production values abound, almost to the point of being ostentatious. The box is [i]huge,[/i] and heavy with components. Players use various hex counters to lay out their tracks. Obviously that is not a problem for veteran gamers, but the eyes of new gamers can gloss over when faced with their first hex map. The map itself is gargantuan, having three, tri-fold sections which are laid together on the table. I think that I have a fairly large dining room table, and the full game board does fit, although there isn't a lot of extra room along the sides. Side note: four small (3/4") binder clips work very well to hold the board together during play.
[i]Railroad Tycoon[/i] is a superbly produced, engaging strategy game with streamlined rules, and a romantic theme. It does appeal, but its sheer size can be intimidating. I admit to loving train games. Despite my enthusiasm, [i]Railroad Tycoon[/i] hasn't been as well received as [i][thing=9209]Ticket to Ride[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=94]Union Pacific[/thing][/i]. A game that receives a "10" should be perfection, so [i]Railroad Tycoon[/i] earns a well-deserved and respectable "9."

item.name: Rattle, Battle, Grab the Loot: Angry Ocean
Razzia!
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/7/09, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Razzia![/i] had crept onto my wishlist a long time ago, but trying to get a copy shipped over from Germany was never a priority. When the opportunity arrived to acquire a copy in trade, I jumped at it.
Now, I had played its progenitor [i][thing=12]Ra[/thing][/i], both on BSW and in person. I loved the Egyptian theme of that bigger title, as well as the terror of a disaster tile. However, the drawback to those considerations was a higher level of analysis paralysis for what was a pretty straightforward auction and set collection game. [i]Razzia![/i] solves this dilemma by doing away with disasters.
The mobster theme of [i]Razzia![/i] works, which I think is quite clever since it harkens back to the older title. Trying to explain to my two sons why the moll is smiling without mentioning prostitution is a little tricky. I was also impressed by the compactness of this game: instead of tiles there is one big deck of cards. Its demure size made [i]Razzia![/i] the better travel companion over the summer.
A simplified version of a good game, readily accessible to the entire family, and highly portable to take on trips? That's a solid contender all the way around.

I think I would really like this game.
I'm not sure it has enough newness for me to buy it for myself. In fact, I am going to say that I am resolved to [i]not[/i] buying it for myself. But I would love to have it. Shameless shilling over.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/16/06, Rated: 8[/i]
A gorgeous game with lots of [i]bits[/i] -- a common trait among Richard Breese games (along with player screens). The shrimps alone are almost legendary.
The theme is interesting and educational. The components look great, in my opinion. The [i]rules...[/i] frankly the rules [i]stink[/i]. This is not to say that it is a bad game. Quite the contrary: I really enjoy [i]Reef Encounter[/i]. But if you don't have the benefit of learning the game from someone who has played it before, then trying to learn from scratch really hurts. Minus one point for the rules.
[i]Reef Encounter[/i] introduced me to the unique mechanism of sharing a number of common boards. It is a tile laying game, that plays out like a series of small area control games. You use your shrimps to defend your territory.
If that was all there was to the game, then it would be good. A little average, but still good. The variable color-dominance pushes [i]Reef Encounter[/i] towards being a great game. Just like rock-paper-scissors, certain color tiles can "eat" (overbuild) some colors, while being weak to others. However, as the game progresses, you have the ability to change the relationships. You can make a particular color very strong, able to "eat" more colors than it could at the start of the game. This mechanic also influences the scoring at the end of the game, and so it is doubly-important.
The tactical challenges of a tile-laying game combined with an overarching strategic element make for an exciting game. Add an interesting, eye-catching theme, and [i]Reef Encounter[/i] is a hit.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=76]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: Return of the Heroes
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/7/08, Rated: 7[/i]
I picked up a copy of [i][gameid=13751][/i] during a spell of binge-buying on Tanga. Even though it is supposed to be playable as a standalone game, it is also an expansion to [i]Return of the Heroes.[/i] Well, I just had to get the base game, didn't I? After a well-negotiated trade, I found myself with a copy. Now, I knew that [i]Return of the Heroes[/i] provided an RPG-like experience in the form of a board game. That was okay with me, because I really enjoy playing [i][gameid=17223][/i]. The obvious question I should have asked myself (but didn't) was this: did I need both of them? Apparently so, thanks to Tanga. Now the question you should be asking yourself is "Which one should I play?" As always, the answer is "that depends upon you."
[i]Return of the Heroes[/i] takes all of the fantasy stereotypes and blanches them even further to provide an extremely generic experience. All of the right trappings are there: five different character classes, heroic quests, experience building, random encounters, loot, a market system, and an unspeakable evil entity that needs to be eradicated. Mmmm, good stuff. It also has a distinctly Eurogame feel, using wooden cubes to track the progression of skills in three different areas: melee fighting, ranged fighting, and magic ability. The rotating counter system used for random encounters and also for timing of game events is novel and effective. The modular board provides a feel of enhanced replayability. The selection of heroic quests which must be completed and multiple über baddies to defeat (only one per game) give [i]Return of the Heroes[/i] some longer legs.
Still, the game has some halfling-sized shortcomings. The most glaring of these is the rulebook: I can tell that writing it was a labor of love for Lutz Stepponat. He is trying to tell an epic story through a board game, so a narrative style sets a great tone. Unfortunately, it's a poor medium for explaining the rules. There are several little gotchas as well as printing errors in this game, and these unnecessarily inflate the learning curve of a very simple game system.
The other item that really stands out is the lack of game material. There are only twenty-one side quests. Eighteen items which can be purchased from the market. Five artifacts. These are sufficient for any one game, but it is likely that you will see most if not all of them in a single playing. In comparison, [i][gameid=17223][/i] is a luxurious Fantasy Flight Games production, with entire decks devoted to these items. The sheer number and varied qualities of loot and market items is fantastic.
[i][gameid=17223][/i] has style in abundance. While it has many of the same archetypal character classes, it does an excellent job of differentiating between them. You believe that your talent and spell choices are shaping your character. [i]Return of the Heroes[/i] feels very flat in this regard: okay, I have a mage. I will probably use my magical ability for every combat situation unless I am prohibited from doing so, in which case I will likely lose a hit point. I will focus on blue cubes instead of the orange ones. Other than that, the Mage feels exactly like the Warrior, without spell choices or the ability to shape its development.
[i]Return of the Heroes[/i] scratches that RPG itch, and it does so in a very efficient manner. It is a good game, even if it is a bland one. I call it "RPG light." You can set it up and play it in a fraction of the time required for the more robust entry in this genre. If you want a quick solution, then go with [i]Return of the Heroes[/i]. If you want a truly epic, highly stylized experience, then [i][gameid=17223][/i] is your answer. Or, you could go the same route I did, and get both.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 6[/i]
Going through and updating my ratings, and I realize that [i]Return of the Heroes[/i] had an extra point tacked on for that rosy honeymoon flush. It's above average, but not much more than that.

item.name: Risk
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/20/04, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Risk[/i] is another example of the type of game that everyone loves to hate. I think that it can be an enjoyable game to play, in spite of its warts. When the original rules are followed, the pacing is adequate, and good strategy definitely plays a role.
House rules that enhance the redeployment of armies, or the abuse of the admittedly weak card component of the game result in the massive forty-versus-forty (army) dice fest battles that many people hate. Cards may be turned in, in sets of three for an escalating number of armies. Often the mid-game turns into a grind of "capture one territory, earn a card, and hold on as long as possible to earn the most armies." Such large forces encourage long offensives, which are great if you're the attacking player, but extremely dull if you're not.
I think that [i]Risk[/i] is often given short shrift because combat is very prone to luck in its resolution, the card component can unbalance the game, and the game's overall simplicity. Yet for these very reasons, it is a fun game to re-introduce people to board gaming.
[i]Updated: 9/20/05, Rated: 6[/i]
I prefer to play [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] than this version, and I need some more room in the upper scores to be able to differentiate between titles. Slide on down.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 5[/i]
With the plethora of themed versions of [i]Risk[/i] available, there is less incentive to revisit the original. Its method of battle resolution and its map will always be timeless. I can see myself playing [i]Risk[/i] for its nostalgic value, but that fact alone doesn't make it stand out.

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D.
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/16/04, Rated: 8[/i]
The first re-themed version of [i][gameid=181][/i] that I have tried. Introduces new layers of complexity including Commanders: super units that situationally allow you to roll d8's instead of d6's. Space stations are earth-based structures that increase the defensive capabilities in a territory, allowing all defending units to roll d8's.
There are five commanders, and each has a corresponding deck of "Command Cards." These cards allow for special powers and effects. Commanders, stations, cards -- including their activation costs, and even turn order are all paid for with energy. Energy is the equivalent of currency in the game.
[i]Risk 2210 A.D.[/i] also allows players to fight on the moon. It can be invaded from space stations on Earth, provided that your Space Commander is already in play. A convenient score card/turn indicator is included as a separate board.
Game duration is artificially managed by imposing a five turn limit. The added depth of [i]Risk 2210 A.D.[/i] provides interesting decisions outside of the combat-only focus of the original game. It is easily my favorive variant of [i][gameid=181][/i] that I have tried thus far.
Please [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/22295]see my review[/url] for more details!
item.conditiontext: Master Series style box (large rectangular). Excellent condition.

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D. Frontline: Season Three – Factions
Risk 2210 A.D. Frontline: Season Two – Tech Commander
Risk: Godstorm
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/6/2007, Rated: 7[/i]
The short version: despite all of its bells and whistles, there is no escaping the fact that this game is still [i][thing=181]Risk[/thing][/i]. If you have worked yourself up into a frenzy decrying its dicefest battles, then you can stop reading now. You won't like [i]Risk: Godstorm.[/i]
The long version: [i]Risk: Godstorm[/i] feels like Avalon Hill's attempt to create an "inba" (in between) title that fits between [i][thing=181]Risk[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] The idea of ancient cultures and mythological gods clashing is an enticing one.
The map on the main board is of Europe, the Mediterranean, and North Africa. It lacks the ocean colonies of [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] The separate playing board for the moon has become the Underworld. Spaces in the Underworld aren't counted when allocating armies and faith points (the currency of [i]Risk: Godstorm[/i]). Therefore, there are fewer territories overall.
The space stations in [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] are now Temples. A slight change here is that at the beginning of your turn, each Temple that you control provides one army [i]and[/i] one faith point. Space stations yielded a single army. Conquering three territories in [i]Risk: Godstorm[/i] earns a card, as opposed to a card and a unit of energy as in [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] Purchasing cards costs two faith points instead of one energy. These seemingly small variations result in a game that feels very cash-strapped in comparison.
Commanders have become Gods, and their numbers have been reduced from five to four. Their corresponding card decks are absolutely [i]brutal![/i] One card allows you to sink an entire continent! Their viciousness means players will have to be spending money to resummon their Gods quite often. It also means that a game of [i]Risk: Godstorm[/i] can have wild fluctuations. A minor quibble: the scoreboard from [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] is missing in [i]Risk: Godstorm[/i]. It was a nice touch in the heavier game.
[i]Risk: Godstorm[/i] succeeds as the "inba" game it was designed to be. It has great flavor, proven mechanics that were introduced in [i][thing=1829]Risk 2210 A.D.[/thing][/i] and a reduction in overall complexity. My enjoyment and my rating fall in between the other two games as well.
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 6[/i]
[i]Risk: Godstorm[/i] is still an improvement over its progenitor, [i][thing=181]Risk[/thing][/i]. Like its subject material, it hasn't been able to withstand the test of time and the rise of new ideas.

item.name: The Royal Limited: Murder On Board
Royal Turf
item.comment:
Alea Small-Box #2
[i]Posted: 10/16/05, Rated: 8[/i]
Apparently it was zoo day today, as we played with camels and horses. After exploring the desert, we decided to relax a bit and bet on the ponies.
The horses are randomly placed on the board, with an opportunity to examine their movement cards prior to betting like a post parade. Players take turns placing betting markers, allowing them to go for long shots by taking unwanted horses. I prefer open betting as opposed to the variant which allows for hidden values. The open betting feels closer to the parimutuel system used at the track.
I am repeatedly surprised to discover that beneath the seemingly simple rules of a Knizia game lies quite a bit of strategy. The movement of the horses is a lot of fun as you try to help your mounts while hobbling those of the competition. I do wish that an eight- or ten-sided die were used, so that the distribution of symbols could be more interesting, such as 3-2-2-1 (instead of 3-1-1-1 on a six-sided die).
[i]Royal Turf[/i] is a lighter game that still retains some nice depth, and that captures the thrill of horse racing. We'll definitely play it again, and it's another good candidate for non-gamers.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 6/3/08, Rated: 7[/i]
[i][gameid=2453][/i] was such a hit with my family (especially my wife) that picking up a copy of [i]Rumis[/i] was almost a "no-brainer" decision. The puzzle-solving nature of the game appears to be very similar, only now it's in three dimensions!
Unfortunately, that is an unfair comparison. Yes, the pieces do look the same. Yes, you are placing them on the same board as your opponents. However, there is where the similarity ends. In [i]Rumis,[/i] your goal is to have as many block-faces of your color visible when looking down on the puzzle from above. Height restrictions prevent you from freely stacking your pieces on top of the others. Each piece you place has to touch face-to-face with another piece of yours, as opposed to [i][gameid=2453][/i] where your pieces may only touch at the corners. The playing field is sharply defined by the pattern on the card upon which you choose to play.
These differences result in a game that is much less forgiving than [i][gameid=2453][/i]. It is much easier to "box out" an opponent from being able to reach open spaces on the board. This added aggravation potential knocks an additional point off of my rating, as an early misstep can result in a doomed position. On the plus side, games usually don't last very long even when played competently, so it won't be long before a doomed player can start again. It is also very cool to see 3D shapes like the Pyramid rise from the board!
If you like [i]Tetris[/i]-stlye games, then [i]Rumis[/i] is one which you should consider. It will feel familiar to start, but you will quickly be disabused of that nostalgia, and then realize that it is a building game in its own right.
item.conditiontext: Educational Insights © 2006. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1980[/b]
[i]Posted: 1/18/08, Rated: 6[/i] {2P: 7, 3P: 6, 4P: 6}
[i]Rummikub[/i] could have been named "Rummy Tiles," or "Rummy-Jong." It is a tile-laying game with many of the same concepts as -- you guessed it! -- [i][gameid=15878]![/i] You must meld before you can lay off, and you are trying to create sets and runs of tiles.
In order to meld, you lay down a combination of tiles the sum of which must equal thirty points or more. A run is three or more tiles of the same color whose values are sequential, i.e. r{3}r-r{4}r-r{5}r. A set is three or four tiles whose values are the same, but each one must be of a different color: r{7}r-b{7}b-[color=orange]7[/color]. If you can't meld, then you draw a tile, and your turn is over. The first part of the game can be frustrating as you draw, and draw, and draw, and draw until you have enough points to meld.
Once you have done so, then you can lay off by playing tiles onto other sets and runs. Here things get interesting because you can "deconstruct" already-played sequences in order to rearrange them, split them, and ultimately augment them with your own tiles. This portion of the game can lead to extreme analysis paralysis. It's easy to think "I can play just one more tile if I rearrange all of the others!" [i]You must play with a timer![/i] Otherwise the game can take forever. If you run out of time then you need to return all of the sets and runs to their original configurations. Sometimes doing so is nearly impossible.
The game itself isn't very social, as you will want everyone else to be quiet when it's your turn. It's only fair that you extend the same courtesy when it's not your turn. You can try to plan your moves ahead of time, but with three or more players you can be certain the tiles you need will already have been used before your turn comes around again. With two players, it's only [i]extremely likely[/i] to happen.
When a player places her last tile, the round is over and scoring commences. In theory, players decide at the beginning of the game how many points must be scored in order to win, but in reality we've never played beyond one round. [i]Rummikub[/i] is a creative approach to [i][gameid=15878][/i]. If you're a fan of the card game and its variants, then you'll probably have fun with [i]Rummikub[/i].

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2004[/b]
[i]Posted: 4/9/06, Rated: 9[/i]
Point of reference: the first five times that I played this game were on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BSW[/url]. The game flowed easily, and shared some characteristics with [i][GAMEID=8217][/i] -- another game that I adore. The goal in [i]St. Petersburg[/i] is similar: namely, to score the most victory points. Points are earned by purchasing cards, which in turn implies that money management is also a key consideration. The trick is in understanding the fine balance between developing your money-earning potential versus investing in point-earning cards. I loved this tension in [i][GAMEID=8217][/i] and its progenitor [i][GAMEID=3076],[/i] so it comes as no surprise that I dig it here as well.
Unlike [i][GAMEID=8217][/i], there are four different decks in [i]St. Petersburg[/i]: Worker, Building, Aristocrat, and Trade (Upgrades). Cards from each deck are made available during separate phases of each round. New cards are placed in one of eight positions, [i]if[/i] there is an opening. Do you take a building card that you don't want, so that you have the possibility of acquiring a noble in the next phase? I'm not sure if these decisions are part of "Card Drafting," since I can't find a concise definition of that game mechanic. Whatever it is called, it works well.
When any one deck is exhausted during its particular [i]phase,[/i] then the game will end at the end of the [i]round.[/i] Therefore deck management is important as well, so you can bring the game to a close on your terms. I've seen a similar mechanic in [i][GAMEID=491][/i], and I really like it.
Finally, I was able to bring this game to the table. And it turns out that it is a bit of an administrative quagmire. What BSW makes so easy is actually quite a hassle. Making change all of the time. Trying to remember all of the cost-reducing effects. [i]Keeping track of the number of remaining cards in each deck.[/i] The paper money looks [i]fantastic[/i], but substituting poker chips makes the process more manageable. These details become easier with practice, but they are still responsible for a deduction of a full point from my rating.
[i]St. Petersburg[/i] is a deceptively simple-looking game with surprising depth. It has many mechanics that blend together very well. The two, three, and four player games all have different flavors, but do a nice job of maintaining the same level of tension (unlike [i][GAMEID=8217][/i], which in my opinion is best played with only two or three players). That's two games named after saints that are winners. If a game entitled [i]Sao Paolo[/i] is ever created, hopefully it will live up to the standard.

item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR] Alea Small-Box #5

Please see my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/77965]review[/url] for more details!
Opening statistics shamelessly ripped from Fawkes.

After several playings, from two players to four, I absolutely love this game. It is light enough to teach to new players, yet deep enough to have effective variations on strategy. True, the cards do add quite a bit of luck to the game, but that can be mitigated somewhat with the right buildings and proper role selection. The four player game doesn't have as much anxiety over role selection each round, since only one role will not be picked.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 7th Place 2001[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 10/30/05, Rated: 7[/i]
A fun game, which feels a bit like "area control lite." The available actions are determined by cards, and the mechanism for distributing cards is very cool. It's like the old "I cut, you choose" method of sharing food when you were a kid, only this time one person divides up action cards and the "limit" cards. If you accumulate 10 points' worth of limit cards, then you are out of the current "passage." A game is three passages (phases?) long.
What ends up happening is that the player dividing the cards takes into account your position on the board as well as your current number of limit points. Do you go for the quick score and risk going over the limit? It's a great idea.
I do have a few gripes with the game. The deck of action cards gets reshuffled after every passage. This requirement means the scoring opportunities as well as aristocrat (cube) placement locations are going to be [i]very[/i] random. The "banishment" action allows a player to choose a district, roll one six-sided die, and remove that number of her opponents' aristocrats from that region. There is a bonus banishment at the end of each passage. This action can easily thwart otherwise solid play. There's also a large helping of "gang up on the leader," so the game doesn't come off as strategic in scope as I had hoped.
[i]San Marco[/i] is a good game to introduce the area control mechanic to new players. The colors on the board and the cards are fantastic. It is fun to play, but just hasn't shown enough of the "it" factor in order to be rated any higher.

item.name: Santa Maria
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/14/18, Rated: 6[/i]
Played at BGG.con 2017. Almost feels like a Feld in colonial clothing. I know some people are bothered by games with colonial themes. If that's you, then please avoid this title. Beyond the theme, there is a puzzle here is that is interesting but not compelling.
Roll dice, and then draft them into either a row or column on your playmat to determine the actions you will take. You can only use a row or column once until the dice pool is empty, and the dice are re-rolled. Use these actions to add paths to pre-printed locations and connect them back to your "hub."
The burn comes from identifying which actions you'd like to take, figuring out the best way to draft them using the rolled dice values, and then gauging which actions your opponents might take. I liked it, but it's not a puzzle that I need to play over and over again. I prefer actual Feld games with more rewarding brain burn.
item.wishlistcomment: Six years after my single play of this, I would like to try it again. I will probably pick this game up on a clearance sale somewhere, if I don't have an opportunity to play someone else's copy.
