item.name: Scene It? Disney
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/8/08, Rated: 5[/i]
This line of games breaks a cardinal rule: playing board games means turning off the television. Injured consciences set aside, the base game is a roll-and-move experience with a healthy dose of [i][gameid=2952][/i].
The gimmick that makes it work, then, is the television component. And to make [-]more money[/-] the game more accessible, Mattel has provided themed versions to play. Disney was a good choice due to their highly prolific portfolio.
The problem this version has is that it is dated. I grew up 20 minutes from Disneyland, and my mother bought every Disney video when it was released ("available only for a limited time!"). My sons haven't seen most of the movies referenced in this game. Like [i][gameid=11628][/i] before it, the age of the source material makes the game more difficult for today's children. I could pick up a version at which they would fare better ([i][gameid=25986][/i] comes to mind), but it would be equally as lopsided of an experience.
I'd prefer to keep the TV turned off, and play something else. "There must be more to this provincial life!"

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/18/07 Rated: 8[/i]
[i]Schotten Totten[/i] was on my radar after doing a GeekBuddy Analysis, and I was able to pick up a copy with a recent order from Germany. Being a Knizia game, it is easy to start trying to draw parallels to [i][gameid=50][/i]. What I have found is that this game has a greater level of complexity. Nine boundary stones lie in between the two players. To win the game, a player must control any three adjacent stones, or else five total. Players alternate placing one card each turn on their own side of the board. Up to three cards are played next to each stone. The best three-card hand controls the stone.
[i]Schotten Totten[/i] doesn't have the same "starting reluctance" as [i][gameid=50][/i]. You must play a card, and your opponent cannot pick up a discard (there aren't any discards). However, you must be cautious that you don't play haphazardly: there is a special rule that lends importance to every card played. If you already have three cards next to a stone at the start of your turn, and you can prove your hand will beat anything your opponent can play, then you can claim that stone. This is a key component of the game: you must be careful not to telegraph a weak hand, and allow your opponent to scoop up a stone with an easy proof.
The victory conditions with respect to the stones means you must also strategize about where to play your cards. You can try to win three adjacent stones, or you could hold onto one of your better hands for use defensively. Thus "board" position is an important consideration.
[i]Schotten Totten[/i] may have a whimsical theme, but its mechanics are very solid. It was a great stepping stone from [i][gameid=50][/i] for my wife. When she was comfortable with that other game and ready for a little more complexity, [i]Schotten Totten[/i] fit the bill perfectly.
[i]Updated: 7/27/09 Rated: 10[/i]
After two years of owning and playing [i]Schotten Totten[/i], I still look forward to being able to bring it to the table. My usual opponent is now my eight year-old son, who is quite good at it! My initial impression was wrong: there is the same level of "starting reluctance" as there is in [i][gameid=50][/i]. I do not always know when I start a row if I'll be able to complete it with a better three-card set.
The "proof" aspect is also exquisite in its agony. Careful observation of the board can result in elaborate proofs, and my son is quite adept at finding them. I love the critical thinking skills he is developing. All around, this is a sure-fire winner, and a go-to game for two players.

item.name: SCOUT
item.wishlistcomment:
Here we have another [-]trick-taking[/-] ladder climbing game. Only this time, the number of cards per suit is variable. Since the cards are double-indexed and their orientation is supposed to be randomized as part of shuffling, you don't know how many there will be in each suit. You can't count into the suits the same way you can in [thing=215]that other game[/thing].
Now add a [i][thing=11][/thing][/i]-like mechanic of not being able to rearrange your cards (but you can still play adjacent cards from anywhere in your hand). Now it's getting interesting.
I'd love to play this game, and it's small enough that it'd worth the purchase price to explore it. My only question now is this: has it already been replaced by [i][thing=345972]Cat in the Box[/thing][/i]?

Sequence
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/15/05, Rated: 7[/i]
[i]Sequence[/i] may be the best pre-crossover game to an acknowledged crossover game like [i][thing=50]Lost Cities[/thing][/i]. Its mechanics are very simple: draw a card, and find its two pictures on the board where it appears. Place a chip on the card's portrait of your choice. Each player or team continues this process until you have created a "sequence" of five chips.
The only cards whose pictures are not on the board are the jacks. Two-eyed jacks are treated as wild cards, while one-eyed jacks allow you to remove a chip of an opposing color. The deck in Sequence is comprised of two standard decks, so you have eight jacks in total, or four of each type.
The corner spaces on the board are also wild, and can be used by any color as part of a sequence -- meaning a team only has to have four of their chips in a row, leading into a corner.
My wife and her friends who would normally be resistant to board games love to play [i]Sequence[/i]. We usually play with a house rule that each player or team needs to complete two sequences in order to win (in a three player/team game, the rules state that only one sequence is required). Drawing cards, and managing board position at the same time? Sounds like the first baby step towards better games!
[i]Updated: 8/29/10, Rated: 6[/i]
What a difference perspective makes. I was fond of this game when I first learned it over five years ago. Its ability to bring non-gamers was, and still is a strength. However, I define a "6" as "Above average. Offers some fun or challenge. I will play if I'm in the right mood. It could be a better game if played with the right group." That last line particularly applies to [i]Sequence:[/i] it still is quite enjoyable when played with our friends who taught it to us. Otherwise it's okay, but not great.
item.conditiontext: Standard game, but have hand-painted one side of every chip to resemble the deluxe version. Otherwise complete and in mint condition.

item.name: SETI: Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence – Pluto Promo Card
The Settlers of Catan
item.comment:
Per TDT #394 1:02:00 (ish): play with [i][thing=325][/thing][/i], the Fishermen from [i][thing=27760][/thing][/i], and the Harbormaster from [i][thing=27760][/thing][/i].
Al loves [i][thing=926][/thing][/i].
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1995[/b] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1995[/b]
[i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 9[/i]
[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] focuses on colony building and trading. There is no combat element to be found anywhere in this game, although a player can be a bit ruthless with the placement of the "bandit" piece. This lack of simulated armed conflict makes [i]Settlers[/i] an easy game to recommend for children.
The game board can be randomly created, which definitely adds to the game's replayability. Interaction between players is essential to winning this game -- another plus. Lastly, the resources are represented by cards, so there aren't any complex money transactions that would require a calculator to compute.
[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] offers innovative gameplay, is easy to understand, does not attempt to model violent conflicts, and above all is fun to play. I am looking forward to introducing many of my friends to this great game.
[i]Updated: 4/22/06, Rated: 8[/i]
[i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] was one of the first "Eurogames" that I played. Since that time, I've developed a bit more perspective. I still really like it, but it has lost some of its luster. On your turn, a bad roll can benefit your opponents more than yourself. Enough of those rolls, and the other players can prevent you from developing (with 3 or four players). Trading in desperation just makes matters worse. If this scenario happens to you, you're effectively removed from contention, sometimes very early in the game.
[i]Updated: 1/2/10, Rated: 9[/i]
Here we are in 2010, and I now own the 4th edition of [i]Settlers of Catan[/i]. I traded away my copy of the 3rd edition so that my set could be compatible with the version of [i][gameid=325][/i] which is currently available. And I forgot how good this game really is.
Yes, I still get upset about poor rolls. However, that frustration is due in part to poor planning: if I can branch out quickly enough, then I can settle on enough numbers to generate resources. The social aspect of the game is also blossoming as my sons get older and more astute. The game deserves a "9."
In fact, it might be a 10 if it weren't for the components. The tiles in the 4th Ed. are thicker, but they need to be twice as thick as they are now to have an appropriate amount of "heft." The frame is a great idea, but the "puzzle tabs" don't fit perfectly well together, and they feel as though they would fray over time.
I think a perfect version of the game would require two copies. On every hex tile in one copy, cut/punch/route a hole for the roll marker. Also take out little edges for half of a road. Now, glue the tile onto it's matching (unmodified) mate from the second set. You will now have tiles twice as thick, with the ability to "inset" the rolling markers and the roads. Coming up with a shape that could accommodate both a settlement and a city at the corners would be difficult: the best shape I can think of would be a rectangle, but distributing its shape amongst the three corners of adjacent hex pieces would be difficult.
The cards are thinner stock than those found in the 3rd Ed.; this is the one place where the game falls short. The cards aren't a size for which I have found a readily-available sleeve, either. The four player colors are red, white. blue, and [i]orange[/i], which is surprising when green or yellow should have been readily available. The robber is now grey instead of black. The cards and colors were better in the 3rd Ed.
The 4th Ed. is still a better version overall, and the gameplay still shines. Still, if a game is going to get the magical "10" then it needs to be perfect in every way. [i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] just barely misses the mark.
[i]Updated: 6/23/17, Rated: 6[/i]
Wow, where has the time gone? Almost seven and a half years since I last updated this rating. And the real reason for the three-point drop is that the base game by itself is...well, I guess the best way to say it is that it's showing its age.
I still enjoy the engine-building aspect of the game. I can even accept capricious resource gathering via dice rolling. Being able to negotiate with the currently-active player every turn reduces down time. The combination of those factors can create a game with doldrums if the other players unite against you.
[i]Catan[/i] with expansion(s) is a better experience, but the base game on its own has dropped down in comparison to more modern offerings.

item.name: Shadowrun: Crossfire – Character Expansion Pack 2: Street Legends
Shadows over Camelot
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 7th Place 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 7/11/06, Rated: 8[/i]
At first glance, [i]Shadows Over Camelot[/i] presents an impressively daunting façade. King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table sally forth to triumph over the forces of darkness. With such lavish production values and so many [i]parts[/i], it was a bit difficult to sell this game as being easy to learn. Our perseverance was ultimately rewarded.
[i]Shadows[/i] is essentially a set collecting game, one where players work together to build sets one card at a time. Sometimes these sets are like [i][gameid=1115][/i] hands: build two pairs, or a full house. These familiar analogies made it easier for me to explain the game to new players.
If that was all there was to the game, then it would be average at best. Of course, there is more to it. [i]Shadows[/i] was the first cooperative game I had ever played, where players were trying to beat "the game." When that goal started to lose its steam after a few plays, we introduced the "traitor" role: each player draws a "Loyalty card" and keeps it in secret. There are more of these cards than players, and one of them says "Traitor." One player [i]might[/i] be a traitor trying to thwart the success of the other Knights, but there is no guarantee that the role is actually in the game! This simple wrinkle adds a healthy dose of paranoia, and can induce some incredible mood swings -- usually from elation to utter despair.
The richly-colored game boards, and the molded pieces help to foster a sense of wonder and adventure. I can definitely see the allure of painting the game pieces, like the ones seen here:
[ImageID=93329] I decided to pick up a copy of [i][gameid=20229][/i], and the painted figures do enhance the game experience. It becomes easier for players to associate with their characters. Role-playing can be cheesy, but it also adds to the game.
Combine a novel idea for most players (a cooperative game) with superlative production values and a fantastic theme, and [i]Shadows of Camelot[/i] is a grail of a game.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/18/10, Rated: 9[/i]
Let's talk about Batmen, shall we? Or Flying Ratmen, if you prefer. Somewhere between [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096895/]Tim Burton[/url] and [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/]Christopher Nolan[/url] lies the creatively twisted mind that brought us [i]Small World[/i]. Sure, it reimplements [i][thing=60]Vinci[/thing][/i]. I never played that game, but I seriously doubt that it had anything close to the level of whimsy as [i]Small World[/i].
The game play itself is quite simple: this is an engine management game, masquerading as a war game. Yes, you have a bunch of cardboard chits. Yes, you can attack each other with them. However, the results are usually predictable: the number of chits needed to win a battle is easily determined. Only the last attack of each player's turn can utilize a custom die to see how many "reinforcements" are available. This structure rewards solid play, while still allowing for the occasional oddball result. I really like that mix, as opposed to the alternative of randomly determining the result of every conflict.
The results are predictable unless your race has the "Berserk" attribute, in which case you roll the reinforcements die on every attack. Here is where the game gets [i]ka-razy.[/i] There are a plethora of special powers, which augment a race that has its own ability. The two tiles fit together in a tongue-and-groove fashion to create a "some type of something" relationship. There are some obvious synergies: Berserk Orcs. Seafaring Tritons. Hill Giants. And then there are the screwball combos like the Diplomatic Ghouls: "Sorry about eating your mum's brains, old chap. Let's let bygones be bygones, shall we?" With fourteen races, and twenty special powers, the possibilities are endless.
Well, okay, not endless. There are 280 of them. The immense variability and unpredictability make you want to sit down with both stacks of tiles, and explore every combination. It would take a literal day (24 hours), if you spent five minutes on each combo, and allowed yourself an additional 40 minutes for food and bio breaks. Theoretically, of course. No one would really do that. Ahem.
As if that weren't enough, you'll see 15-20 such combinations during the course of a game, playing 4-5 of them yourself. The number of different games you could play as a result would be...a lot. Games with unpredictable swings, wild power couplings, all done with humor and style. The quality of the artwork, and the selection of powers and races lend a narrative quality to the game. It's as if there's a story lurking beneath the board, waiting to be told. I love that feeling of transportation when playing a game, and it's worth a full point upgrade in my rating.
Just watch out for those Flying Ratmen. Ratmen have no special abilities of their own (eerie, isn't it? I mean Bruce Wayne isn't a "super" through genetics), but there are a [i]ton[/i] of them. And when they're Flying, they could show up anywhere. They're Batmen.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
Small World: Leaders of Small World
Small World: Necromancer Island
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/5/11, Rated: 8[/i]
So, I have this gift: each time that I am introduced to a new group of players and we decide to play a game with a "traitor" element, I end up being the traitor. Last month when I went to my first Orange County Board Gamer's event, we sat down to play [i][thing=10547]Betrayal at House on the Hill[/thing][/i]. I immediately rolled an event card which made me the evil player. Our next game was [i][thing=37111]Battlestar Galactica[/thing][/i], and who do you think was a Cylon? You guessed it. It should not have been a surprise when I showed up to another event, and five people were sitting down to play [i][thing=40692]Small World[/thing][/i] with this expansion. "It's so nice to meet you, won't you please join us, Mr. Necromancer?"
I like [i][thing=40692]Small World[/thing][/i] to start with. This expansion adds an asymmetrical victory condition for a universally-threatening player. I was impressed at how the generation of ghosts automatically increased the cost of purchasing new powers or units; the necromancer role is cleverly woven into this shroud. Some people don't like having such a jarring element, but I think that it adds flavor and ultimately extends the life of the base game.
There is one thing that I don't like about this expansion: as the game draws to a close, the escalating power of the necromancer generates an obligation for players to sacrifice their own chance at success to stop the evil from winning. The whole, "Are [i]you[/i] going to do something about him?" sensation feels very similiar to [i][thing=8051]Attika[/thing][/i] when played with more than two players.

item.name: Sorry! Sliders
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/27/08, Rated: 8[/i]
I realize that a lot of people think that rating "kids' games" is uncool. Well, tough. The original [i][gameid=2407][/i] game is well-named. Therefore, my gut reaction to a similarly-themed game was not very positive.
Then I saw raving comments about it: "I don't know why it works, but it is so much [i]fun![/i]" That didn't sound like the [i]Sorry![/i] I despise. After an enthusiastic family reception for [i][gameid=37296][/i], I decided to give another Ameritrash-themed game a try.
And am I ever glad I did.
[i]Sorry! Sliders[/i] [u]works[/u]. There are no fidgety rules, no ambiguities. Think of it as mini-shuffleboard, with players lagging from different directions. The pawn-moving aspect is interesting, requiring you to try for specific values as you near the "home" space on your scorecard.
My family is rabid about this game, but I doubt it has the legs to be an eternal favorite. Minus one point for this "one trick pony" feel. One of my sons loves to play the role of spoiler: he doesn't care if he wins, so long as he kamikazes other players' tokens into the corners (the [i]Sorry![/i] move for this game). Minus another point for encouraging this type of play.
Still, an "8" is a more than respectable score. When all is slid and done, [i]Sorry! Sliders[/i] is an easy, fun filler game that has yet to miss the mark.

item.name: Space Hulk (Third Edition)
item.comment:
[i]Edited: 1/16/10, Rated: 9[/i]
What to do with this game? The simple truth is that [i]Space Hulk[/i] is a fantastic experience for two players. It's also an investment of money and of time. The "versions" you've seen in the fancy pictures have been painted by talented people. I'm not so talented, nor do I have the time to try. I'm convinced games with miniatures are sold only to generate the more profitable secondary market for paint supplies. But even without painting, a copy of [i]Space Hulk[/i] is an expensive proposition for a game that doesn't scale beyond two players.
Layered on top of that conundrum is the poor attitude displayed by the game publisher, Games Workshop. You may have heard of the uproar they caused in November '09 when they [article=4256396]demanded that BGG remove user-generated content related to this, and other games of theirs[/article]. I don't explore a game fully when I first acquire it. Instead, I prefer to spread my game time amongst multiple titles, and then later revisit the gems. The action by Games Workshop threatens my enjoyment of this game: the materials which could enhance my experience are being removed and discouraged. That leaves me less desirous of spending more time with it.
Does that make [i]Space Hulk[/i] a "1?" No, not really. More like an "8." At the end of the day, it's still a fun game to play.
The pacing is perfect. I love the idea that the human player is time-limited due to human reflexes being [i]slow,[/i] while the Genestealer player can take as long as she likes. There's an important subtext to that ability, though: the longer the Genestealer player takes, the more time the Marine player has to think about his moves before the sand starts running. The asymmetric nature of the two sides makes them play, and more importantly feel, very different. The tension of watching opponents close with one another, always fearing (or hoping for) a jam is sublime.
So, if it's an "8," then why give it a rating that is a point higher? Because playing [i]Space Hulk[/i] provides a memorable narrative that lasts long after the box has been put away. My sons and my friends don't say things like, [thing=3076]"Remember that time I offensive captained you, and then shipped from my own harbor?"[/thing] or [thing=31260]"How about that time when I grew a carrot?"[/thing] They [i]do[/i] say things like "Remember that last-ditch stand by my Marine who gunned down five aliens in a row?" or "What about that one alien of mine who dodged all of that fire and killed both of your guys for the win?" A game that has that kind of emotional impact is great, period.
Do I advocate rewarding a company who treats its own customers with little regard? Absolutely not. Is [i]Space Hulk[/i] a game you should try if you have the opportunity? Unequivocally, yes.

StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/2/13, Rated: 9[/i]
Originally released in 1998 (!!!), [i][thing=70722][/thing][/i] has arguably become one of the most recognizable, and the most successful video games ever. It was the perfect blend of sci-fi geekdom: [i]Aliens[/i], [i]Predator[/i], and [i]Starship Troopers[/i] all rolled into one cohesive experience. Nine years later, a board game version of this classic was released. This development is not surprising: there was the [thing=7479]mildly disappointing board game adaptation[/thing] of [i][thing=68458]Warcraft III[/thing][/i], and [thing=17223]the surprisingly good adaptation[/thing] of [i][thing=69309][/thing][/i]. How would Fantasy Flight fare this time around?
A disclaimer before I continue: I heart all things Blizzard. My friends and I played the hell out of [i][thing=70722][/thing][/i]. If you calculate "enjoyment" of a game by dividing its purchase price by the number of times you play it, then the per-play cost of [i][thing=70722][/thing][/i] can be measured in pennies. Maybe even in fractions of a penny. And I purchased multiple copies of the game. I tell you all of this to let you know that I wanted to like this board game.
The packaging alone is epic. It is the classic [family=9983]Fantasy Flight tombstone size[/family]. These boxes have to be seen to be believed. They portend endless amounts of chits and figurines, with playing times to match. One minor nitpick that I have with these games is that there is so much material inside of the box, that it is nearly impossible to keep everything inside without discarding the insert. Don't worry, dear reader: my OCD was and is equal to this task, but it takes time to carefully repack the box after each play.
You should be careful with this game, anyway. [i]StarCraft: The Board Game[/i] ([i]SCTBG[/i]) comes with exquisitely molded figurines for each of the three races in the video game: Terrans, Protoss, and Zerg. Flying units are mounted on clear plastic bases. These acrylic bases can snap at the joint where the unit figurine is mounted. A couple of my units were broken in this fashion when I first unboxed them. Fantasy Flight sent replacements, but care needs to be taken when returning them to the box.
The map in [i]SCTBG[/i] works well. Planets are placed on the board and then connected via linking routes. Players will only be able to move (attack) along these routes. [i]SCTBG[/i] takes an interesting diversion from the video game with the inclusion of "Z-routes:" in an attempt to model three-dimensional space, there are links which allow planets on opposite sides of the map to be connected by a single link. In other words, players should try to imagine this map folding on top of itself to establish these extra routes. I like this addition, as it makes it more difficult for a player to "turtle" in the corner of a map. Not that turtling is a desired tactic in this game...
For the real goal is to secure and retain control points. To do this usually requires you to attack other planets, and then to defend your gains. You will also have to harvest Crystals and Vespene Gas. It is possible through force mining to deplete the available resources on a planet, so you will need more. Attacking and expanding require the use of Command Counters, which are the heart of this game.
In an attempt to model a Real Time Strategy game, [i]SCTBG[/i] provides each player with Command Counters: chits which allow the player to perform standard tasks like attacking, moving, research, etc. In turn order, players place one of their command counters on the map, either on a planet they control, or on a planet connected to one they control (connected by one of those links). Once all of these command counters have been placed, they are resolved in turn order provided a counter of the current player is visible. This means that the sequence of these counters is vitally important to executing your plans. If you want to attack and then occupy a planet, then you must place the "occupy" counter first. Some time later, you will place the "attack" token on the same planet. When those counters are evaluated from the top down, then "attack" will be handled first, and "occupy" second.
This mechanic takes a few attempts to appreciate. Once you have grasped its significance, it is divine. You can try to interrupt other players' plans by placing your own tokens to impede their progress. You can place a token as a diversion. You can mobilize your troops and summon overwhelming forces. These nuances do a great job of replicating the tension found in the video game when making decisions surrounded by the fog of war.
Beyond this core mechanic, [i]SCTBG[/i] has all of the high production value chrome that you would expect from Fantasy Flight. Every faction has its own deck of cards, which are used for upgrades and higher-level units. There is definitely a "tech tree" represented by the building upgrades which are tracked on player sheets. Battles feel epic with front line and supporting units. All of these items will feel nostalgically welcome to players of the video game.
[i]StarCraft: The Board Game[/i] does an excellent job of capturing the core decision making and resource management of its progenitor. The game feels epic in scale. As a bonus, it doesn't take as long to play as other members in the series of Fantasy Flight tombstone boxes -- if you don't count the amount of time spent packing all of these components back in the box.

StarCraft: Typhon Promotion
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/1/11, Rated: 6[/i]
This promotion can be included at the start of a game, but it may not get picked. Typhon is a dead-end dive of a planet, which nonetheless can be very attractive for its command point, and for its contribution to the special victory conditions for Arcturus Mengsk and the Overmind.
It makes me think of this segment from the awesome, Star Wars-themed "COPS" parody, "TROOPS:"
[youtube=bocmVZXXY8w&start=101]
Like many promotions, it doesn't add much to the game. Part of me wants to rate it lower for just this reason. However, we really enjoy the [thing=22827]base game[/thing], and this promotion doesn't make it worse. Thus, this rating is somewhere in the middle.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2008[/SIZE][/COLOR] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2008[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 3/17/09, Rated: 9[/i]
Despite its Cro-Magnon theme, [i]Stone Age[/i] is a perfect example of the modern-day Euro game. All of the trappings are there: a richly-saturated board, individual player mats, wooden bits galore, tiles, cards, coins, and dice. Wait, strike that last item. Dice aren't very [i]chic[/i] in Euro games, but they are present in [i]Stone Age[/i], along with a natural leather dice cup.
All of these components (except the dice) are used in a very familiar fashion. Like [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=24480]The Pillars of the Earth[/thing][/i] before it, [i]Stone Age[/i] requires you to place workers to gather different resources. These resources are then used to acquire victory points. These mechanics should feel ancient by now, but [i]Stone Age[/i] manages to evolve towards simplicity. There is no "ownership" of spaces like there is in [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i]: you can place your workers in an open spot without agonizing about helping an opponent, too. There is some contention for the best places (a fiddly rule that works), but overall the options are more balanced than the choices in [i][thing=24480]The Pillars of the Earth[/thing][/i].
There are a few different ways to score points. The set-collection nature of the cards combined with the multiplying factor of upgrades requires forward planning, but so does resource collection when purchasing the different buildings.
Where do the dice come into play? When collecting resources. Here is the unique mechanic of [i]Stone Age[/i], which will be very catalytic. Each worker figure placed at a specific resource location enables the owning player to roll one die. The total number of "pips" rolled determines how many resources are collected. It is possible to soften the blow of a bad roll by purchasing upgrades, but you can't completely mitigate the luck in this game. Either you're okay with this quality, or you'll hate it.
In an ironical fashion, [i]Stone Age[/i] represents an evolution of the worker placement mechanic, even though its theme is from a more ancient time.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 9/7/05, Rated: 5[/i]
[i]Stratego[/i] feels like a mix between [i][gameid=6798][/i] and [i][gameid=2083][/i]. It's fun enough to play. The two pools of water (and the boxes that they block) turn out to create a very predictable board. I've been using minor variations of the same layout for thirty years or so now, to great success. I might rate this game higher if there were more variations in how it plays out, but why change my layout when it works so well?
A better version of this game was [i][gameid=2728][/i], which had a completely open board, and a "resolution computer" that would decide the outcome of a fight between two pieces, without revealing their identities.
[i]Updated: 12/2/07, Rated: 4[/i]
If I'm going to play [i]Stratego,[/i] then I'd prefer to use a re-themed variant that offers some additional challenge. [i][gameid=30000][/i] is the better game. Plus, I miss the older sets that had the unit outlines painted in silver on heftier castle pieces, instead of the new, "labor intensive to assemble, but cheaper to produce" version that is available today.

item.name: Stratego: Transformers
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/2/07, Rated: 5[/i]
[i]Transformers[/i] were childhood favorites of mine, and my sons love them, too. Now ages nine and seven (as of the date of this comment), my sons don't play with those toys as much as they used to. However, all of the hype surrounding the [i]Transformers[/i] movie got them fired up again, and we wound up with a copy of [i]Stratego: Transformers[/i] as a birthday gift.
On the surface, this re-themed version is still classic [i][gameid=1917]:[/i] the board has the same two "forbidden zones" through which pieces cannot move, bombs lie in wait for careless opponents, and flags cannot move. The plastic pieces have a futuristic shape for this version, and the picture on the battlefield has also changed. Otherwise the composition of each army is the same. [i]Unless[/i] you're playing with the advanced rules.
For instead of having a Marshall, the Decepticons have Megatron; the Autobots have Optimus Prime. Instead of a General, there is Starscream or Ironhide. When playing with the advanced rules, these Transformers have special powers that can be used. "Speed" allows a piece to move two spaces instead of one. "Distance Strike" allows a piece to attack another two spaces away (and avoid being killed if outmatched!). "Sneak Attack" allows a piece to jump in a straight line over any number of adjacent pieces [i]or the forbidden zones[/i] to the next empty space, and then attack on the same turn. This last power is amazingly effective, and brings new mobility options to an otherwise stagnant game.
The problem with [i]Stratego: Transformers[/i] is that the two sides are not equal. The top three Decepticons (Megatron at rank 10, Starscream at rank 9, and Blackout at strength 8) all have "Sneak Attack" as one of their powers. This incredible agility combined with high strength values make the Decepticons very lethal. The Autobots also have three pieces with Sneak Attack: Optimus Prime at rank 10, and then two jet Fighters each at rank 7. Plainly stated, the Decepticons can bring more inertia to a fight.
As a result, the Decepticon player can be wildly aggressive, jumping in and out of combat at will. The Autobot player must play more cautiously, and be willing to sacrifice his high-ranking pieces as needed. The established disposition of the two sides has been kept intact for this game. That's great from a thematic point of view, but it feels unbalanced.
[i]Stratego: Transformers[/i] does breathe some fresh air to a stale classic. If you're going to play [i][gameid=1917][/i] at all then this is a decent version, especially if you bring some childhood nostalgia along for the ride.
item.conditiontext: The special powers sheets are currently missing. Descriptive text found online, and temporary replacements made until the originals are hopefully found. Otherwise complete and in excellent condition.

item.name: Sushi Go Party!: Pickled Ginger Promo
Sushizock im Gockelwok
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/27/09, Rated: 6[/i]
Finally a sequel for [i][gameid=15818][/i] that was three years in the making. Fewer dice are back, the number of domino-like tiles has increased, and there is a veneer of deeper strategy in [i]Sushizock im Gockelwok[/i].
Side note: I love saying this name. It's a jumbled mouthful of chunky syllables. It makes me wish I had the German version of its predecessor, [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/15818]Heckmeck am Bratwurmeck[/url][/i].
With only five dice and two types of tiles, [i]Sushizock im Gockelwok[/i] appears to have less randomness, and more depth. And at first, that impression seems to be confirmed: for every positively-scoring tile you have, you must have a matching negatively-scoring one in order to count it. For example, if you only have a +6 tile, your current score is 0. If you take a -2 tile, your score is now 4. Note, this "even distribution" scheme does not apply in reverse: if you take a -4 tile on your next turn, your score is back to 0, although you are now able to take a second positive tile in the future to score it, too.
In reality, though, some of the fun is lost. Stealing tiles is easier which makes this a more interactive game than its predecessor, but you're only allowed three rolls of the dice during your turn. You can't push your luck as far as you can in [i][gameid=15818][/i], and that saps some of the excitement.
[i]Sushizock im Gockelwok[/i] is a fun game, and it is easy to teach. It's not as wild as its predecessor, nor does it accommodate as many players (only 5 as compared to 7). The end result is a game that doesn't score as highly.

item.name: Tactics II
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/10/06, Rated: 5[/i]
The once-upon-a-time gateway to wargames. Heck, [i]Tactics II[/i] might even be the progenitor of the modern wargame. It is fun to play, but there are some caveats to keep in mind.
First, the map does [i]not[/i] use hexes; it uses squares. As far as movement goes, [i]Tactics II[/i] does not prepare a new wargame player for a more modern title. There are three basic units on each side: infantry, armor (tanks), and headquarters. These lack any real variety, although there are a few specialized infantry units (paratroopers, mountaineers, and amphibious) which add some temporary interest when using the advanced rules. As you'd expect, tanks have greater mobility and more firepower than infantry. The headquarters units cannot attack, but do defend like an infantry unit. They turn out to be good for defensive purposes, and for containing units attempting to retreat. Both sides are identical.
The basic game is surprisingly fun. Massed armor is overpowering, so I recommend using the army distribution from the advanced game. This prevents players from starting with an entire corps of tanks. Lines form, flanks attempt to be turned, reinforcements arrive, fronts contract or else weaken, bulges are created...all good stuff! I have a slight complaint with combat resolution. The outcome of a battle is determined by rolling a six-sided die and then consulting a "Combat Results Table" (CRT). The relative strengths of the attacking units versus the defending ones are taken into account. Anything less than a 3:1 ratio in the attacker's favor will be a gamble. The problem is finding those 3:1 (or better!) opportunities. Hence the need for massed armor. The rules are also a bit unclear on the possible outcomes. I am still a bit uncertain as to when a unit should be eliminated if it is forced to retreat.
With the advanced rules, it gets even tougher. Terran makes a difference. Mobility is enhanced. Weather can be simulated. More good stuff! However, finding those opportunities for extremely favorable power ratios is more difficult. The advanced game takes longer to complete, and sometimes it is hard to stay committed. Since it does not model a historical conflict, the victory conditions are a bit droll, and interest can wane.
[i]Tactics II[/i] was probably a revolutionary game when it was first introduced. It is still an enjoyable experience, even if you lack fond, nostalgic memories. It can be used as a gateway to wargames if you keep it simple. Choose a few optional rules if you'd like, and then set a time limit. In this manner you can teach some solid principles, and then move on to a more modern game that will be more likely to hold your interest.
item.conditiontext: Avalon Hill © 1961. However, this copy must have been printed later: the rule booklet has an "2/82" on the back page. Tear in one corner of inside box, obvious signs of wear. Complete and in good condition.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment:
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2000[/b]
[i]Posted: 3/30/2009, Rated: 9[/i] {3P: ???, 4P: 10, 5P: 9}
The [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamedesigner/2]good Doctor[/url] has designed so many games, that it's difficult to keep track of them all. With such megahits as [i][thing=42]Tigris & Euphrates[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=12]Ra[/thing][/i], [i]Taj Mahal[/i] had slipped through the cracks of my consciousness. Ironically, I had picked up a copy over three years ago as part of the [family=58]Alea Big Box series[/family]. Only after a concerted effort to explore this game did it finally make it to the table.
Was I ever wrong to wait. [i]Taj Mahal[/i] belongs in the pantheon of Knizia greats.
The auction mechanism is both agonizing and efficient. On top of that core mechanic, the game is about "chain scoring:" linking your provinces together, or collecting commodities. With four players, there is a perfect balance between the ability to extend an auction at the risk of losing premium temple placement within a province.
Recognizing potential chains then leads to hand management, so that you have the necessary cards to compete in those provinces. The long term strategy merges beautifully with the tactical considerations of each auction.
[i]Taj Mahal[/i] is an amazing game. I'm tempted to rate it a "10" out of the gate, but I don't want to be too hasty before trying it with three, and with five players.
[i]Updated 4/3/12, Rated: 9[/i]
I finally had the chance to play this game with five. It was a learning/re-introduction game, so we weren't playing anywhere near optimally. The one thing that stands out is that the auction can be brutal if you have that many players: if someone chooses to go long with you on a particular province, you can be left with nothing after having spent a lot of cards. I think the risk/reward ratio is better with four players, which is why I'm rating the 5p game a "9" while the 4p game is a "10." Overall score: still a "9."

item.name: Taluva
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 12/2/07, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: 8, 3P: 8, 4P: ???}
[i]Taluva[/i] is a new game that manages to be nostalgic. I know that description sounds like a paradox, but when I play [i]Taluva[/i] I am reminded of other games. The presence of volcanos and spending resources to climb higher are reminiscent of [i][gameid=54][/i]. The shape of the pieces themselves, stacking and aligning land types feels like [i][gameid=855][/i]. Growing the play area organically without a formal game board has been lifted from Merkle's own excellent game, [i][gameid=8051][/i].
The production value of this game is beyond [i][gameid=855][/i]-esque. The tiles in [i]Taluva[/i] are [i]thicker,[/i] something I would not have thought possible. The rules are simple if you're learning them from someone who already knows the game, otherwise they are missing a couple of small but critical clarifications. A few pointers: any time you want to expand a settlement to a higher level, you [i]must[/i] have the prerequisite number of huts for that new level. You can never have a single hut on a level two space, for example. You can place a Temple (or a Tower) as the linking piece between two settlements, even if one of them already has a Temple (or a Tower, if you're placing a Tower) in it: select the [i]other[/i] Settlement as the one for which you are placing the Temple, and ignore all others. Minus one point for these oversights, as they unnecessarily increase the learning curve.
With enough patience, the game comes together beautifully. The artwork is attractive, and a completed game looks fantastic on the table. After a couple of learning sessions to familiarize myself with the rules, I had an "aha!" moment where they all came together. I realized how simple the game really is. There are plenty of opportunities for players to interfere with each other, especially since there is no penalty for playing in a different area of the board -- unlike [i][gameid=8051][/i], where a new settlement requires extra investment. The two-player game is more strategic simply because there are fewer players to get in the way. The three-player game requires a more defensive mindset, and there can be [i][gameid=8051][/i]-like experiences where one player is forced to stop the opponent to her left. I haven't played with four players, but I imagine that the game becomes even more chaotic.
[i]Taluva[/i] is a strong game in its own right even though you might feel as though you've played it before. Some portions of it are recycled, but they haven't all been brought together this elegantly. I'm looking forward to my next game.

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/21/09, Rated: 6[/i]
I'm a fan of the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/project_GIPF]Project GIPF[/url] games. After falling in love with [i][gameid=7854][/i] and then appreciating [i][gameid=528][/i], I had to try the rest. This impulse happened before [i]TAMSK[/i] had been replaced by [i][gameid=31999][/i].
In a fit of irony, the potential of [i]TAMSK[/i] exceeds its reality. Here is this intriguing game, which uses hourglasses as its pieces. I marveled at the concept of having pieces which were capable of keeping their own time, and which could expire. Envisioned strategies of "letting your clock run" during your turn to strand your opponent's pieces were exciting.
The actual game turns out to be quite hectic. In a manner similar to [i][gameid=2346][/i], you want to keep your options open. Many times, you can see the available moves along certain routes, while others will be dead-ends. I haven't played enough times to develop the skill to effectively manage my sand to "let it run," but I can see the desire to sacrifice pieces to limit your opponent's mobility.
Perhaps even more interesting is that the sand timers are not all equally filled. Whether this is done by design or through manufacturing, they are not all equal. This would be fine if both sides had even numbers, but in fact the sides aren't equal. I don't know if this fact affects the playing of the game, but it does affect my enjoyment of it: I'd prefer to have precisely-filled timers across the board.
This residual doubt combined with a game that requires the development of a new mental muscle, make me reluctant to reach for [i]TAMSK[/i] instead of the other entries in this series. My perceptions might change if only I spent more time with it.

item.name: Tantrix
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/7/09, Rated: 5[/i] {1P: 6, 2P: 5, 3P: 4, 4P: ???}
[i]Tantrix[/i] sounds like something from the [i][url=http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Kama-Sutra-Unabridged-Translation/dp/0892814926]Kama Sutra[/url][/i]. Such a connection may have made the game more interesting. I guess the best comparison I could make is to suggest that you think of it as an abstract, hexagonal version of [i][gameid=822][/i].
Each tile will have three lines on it, each one of a different color. These lines will be straight, will bend 120°, or will be a corner of 60°. When placing a tile into the puzzle, each of these lines has to match up with the lines from other tiles. A finished game ends up looking more like a black plate of multi-colored spaghetti.
As a solitaire challenge, [i]Tantrix[/i] is decent. Each tile has a number on the back. The "Discovery Challenge" starts with the first three colors, each of which has a yellow number on its back. Since the "3" is yellow, you must create a single loop of that color. After completing this easy puzzle, you add the next tile, which has a red "4." And so on. As the number of tiles gets higher, the puzzles get more challenging. It can be very frustrating to have found a candidate loop of the desired color, and then not be able to swap tiles so that all of the other colored lines are contiguous.
As a head-to-head game, [i]Tantrix[/i] is still very abstract. Here, there are additional rules which must be followed in order to give the game the highest chance for completion. The same color cannot lead into a hole from three different sides. This rule makes sense because no single tile would be able to make all three connections. You cannot create a hole which has four tiles on its borders. This one is more insidious, as it allows one player to create "forced move" situations for her opponent. With two players these rules are okay. With three, they start becoming cumbersome.
[i]Tantrix[/i] is definitely a clever game, but ultimately it doesn't move me. That result is slightly ironic, because it is very portable. There are other challenges I have yet to explore, and apparently there's even an [url=http://www.tantrix.com/]online community[/url]. Perhaps these other resources can wriggle a better score for this game in the future.

item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 10th Place 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 4/15/06, Rated: 5[/i] [i]Verflixxt![/i] is one of those games that actually plays better on BSW than it does on the table. The long, snaking tiles are a bit cumbersome to compress. And if you have just a little bit of O.C.D. (or in my case, more than a little), you'll feel the constant need to readjust the tiles so they fit together tightly after someone accidentally bumps them.
My little idiosyncracies aside, the game itself is an exercise in prolonged agony. I truly mean that in a good way: how long can you afford to keep one of your markers on a good (positive-scoring) marker, before you've been forced to take enough negative ones to offset the benefit? Can you postpone having to move a marker off the end of the board until someone else has had the opportunity to land on your tile and save you from eating its negative score?
Those types of decisions exist in plentiful supply, but your ability to deal with them is tempered by the random element of a die roll. With luck playing a significant role in the game, [i]Verflixxt![/i] makes for nice filler on either end of something meatier. The setup and constant adjustment of the table version knocks a point off of what would otherwise have been a "6." Play it on BSW first, if you can.

item.name: That's Pretty Clever!
item.wishlistcomment: I've played the heck out of this. How do I not own a copy?

item.name: Thebes
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2007[/SIZE][/COLOR] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 9th Place 2007[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 1/18/08, Rated: 6[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: ???, 4P: 6}
[i]Thebes.[/i] What a paradox. On the surface, [i]Thebes[/i] is wonderfully rich and lustrous. Mining below this façade can leave you feeling frustrated, empty, and unfulfilled. How does one rate such an experience?
The time-track method of determining player order is novel and effective. Imagine a long scale of action points, and every action you take from moving on the board, to drawing a card, to commencing an excavation requires points. The person who is "last" on the timeline (farthest from the end of the game) is the next player to take her turn -- even if she just completed her previous move. I really enjoyed this aspect of the game, and I hope to see it revisited in the future.
The game components are lavishly produced, and support the archaeology theme very well. Players move between "modern" cities for research and exhibitions, and ancient sites in order to perform excavations. Conducting research is accomplished by collecting sets of cards, choosing from four face-up cards. That mechanic is growing tired. I understand that it helps to mitigate the risk in a game, but it has been done to death. Plus, there's an element of risk in this game which can't be mitigated.
That element is the bags which are used for excavations. There are five archaeological sites, represented by five locations on the board. Each site corresponds to a bag, inside of which are treasure tokens and "dirt" tokens. Collecting larger sets of cards in a particular color allows you to draw more counters from a bag when you perform an excavation. Allocating more action points to the excavation can also increase this number. Yet despite collecting a large body of knowledge and devoting a lot of time to the excavation, you can come up empty. In one game, I drew 10 counters from an excavation, 9 of which were useless. It was phenomenally bad luck to be sure, but it killed my enthusiasm for the game. In that same game, an opponent dedicated fewer resources to her excavation, and went 4-for-4 in finding treasures. Argh!
There are other ways to score points, and I'd like to try an "excavation-less" strategy to see if that is viable. Still, there's no getting around the uncertainty of the counter-drawing mechanism. The exhibition "system" further rewards those players who were lucky with their excavations, fostering a situation where the rich get richer. This game was wonderfully strategic and light, earning a solid "8" right up to those darned excavation bags. Now I find myself wondering when I'll feel up to facing the potential heartbreak of future excavations.
An above average game, which I will play if I'm in the right mood? That's the definition of a "6" on [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/profile.php?user=Beowulf]my scale[/url]. I might be able to dig up another ratings point after more explorations.
[i]Updated: 1/21/08, Rated: 7[/i] {2P: 7, 3P: 8, 4P: 6}
It turns out that [i]Thebes[/i] doesn't scale very well. My initial rating was based on a handful of games with four players. The shortened timeline as well as increased competition for treasures made the luck of the "dig draw" an overwhelming component.
The game shines with three players, balancing multiple dig opportunities with competition for cards. Sure, lucky draws still make a difference, but one or two bad draws aren't condemning. The time factor feels about right with three players.
The game feels a little long when played with only two players, but it is still a better experience than when played with four.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 4th Place 1998[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 10/16/05, Rated: 7[/i]
It's a cloudy, drizzly day today, so I thought I would introduce my family to another recent acquisition. The sunny colors of the game board along with the five flavors of candy pastel camels provided a great contrast to the dreary skies outside.
Three games are behind us now, played with four people, then three, then two. [i]Through the Desert[/i] is a fun little game. The most lucrative scoring mechanism is to enclose a portion of the board with your own camels, that are also of the same color. This mechanism feels a bit like [i][GAMEID=188].[/i] There are ancillary scoring opportunities such as capturing "water holes," linking to oases, and having the longest caravan of a particular color. In a tightly-contested game, these other scoring options can make or break you.
Initial placement of your "caravan leaders" is absolutely vital to winning the game. I cannot emphasize this point enough. It also means that a player with poor leader placement is probably doomed from the outset, even if she doesn't know it yet. This dynamic is so severe that it limits the fun people have while playing if they realize their own predicament.
[i]Through the Desert[/i] is a lot of fun, and the family is already asking for more. It definitely earns a solid score of "7." Maybe its score will creep up when we all become more proficient at it.

item.name: Thunderstone: Dragonspire
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/30/11, Rated: 8[/i]
As a first time BGG.con attendee, I'll let those of you who have not yet attended in on a little secret:
[i]Don't wait to start playing on Sunday.[/i]
Rolling in from Saturday night gaming at 4:00 AM meant an 11:00 AM start later that morning. Left to grab "breakfast" with friends, and it was already 12:30 by the time I was ready to sit down and play.
Uh-oh. The library was closing up. The Funagain store was closed. And since I don't check bags when I fly, I had already shipped my purchases and prizes home the day before. That left my friend Greg and me desperately looking for games to play. We decided to try a demo of [i]Thunderstone: Dragonspire[/i] at the [company=396]AEG[/company] tables.
Had I played [i][thing=53953][/thing][/i] before? Nope. I had played [thing=36218]that "other" game[/thing]. Was fond of it, even though it was a shuffle-fest. About the only thing I knew about [i][thing=53953][/thing][/i] was that it was a deck-building clone, capitalizing upon the success of the original (and therefore, better) game.
Drop your torches and pitchforks, [i][thing=53953][/thing][/i] fans. By the end of the game I was a convert. I guess that means that fans of [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i] can pick those items up off of the ground.
I liked the fact that money and "estate" cards weren't one-dimensional: if I couldn't mount a successful quest during my turn, then those same equipment and hero cards doubled up as currency to improve my raiding party. Earning experience points to level up my heroes was exciting. It turns out that [i]Dragonspire[/i] includes a board to track monsters and Darkness, along with experience counters: plastic versions of the iconic Thunderstone.
These differences provided my quests through [i]Dragonspire[/i] with more flavor than a standard game of [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i]. I could feel myself becoming more invested in my heroes, wanting them to succeed. In comparison, [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i] feels dry and mechanical.
Don't get me wrong: [i][thing=36218][/thing][/i] still has a place in my heart, and on my shelves. I will still return to it as being the title which won both the [i]Spiel des Jahres[/i] and the [i]Deutscher Spiele Preis[/i] -- [geekurl=/tag/sdj-winner+dsp-winner/user/Beowulf]a feat only six games have accomplished[/geekurl] -- in 2009. But before BGG.con, I would have said that there was no reason to own both games. Now, I can't wait to receive my copy of [url=http://www.coolstuffinc.com/p/Board%20Games/Thunderstone%3A+Complete+Set+Bundle/Acc-AEGThunderstoneBundle/#Thunderstone%3A+Complete+Set+Bundle]the entire set[/url].

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2006[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2006[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 12/23/07, Rated: 10[/i]
I've got a ticket to ride the Pony Express.
I have to admit that I suffered from a bit of [i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] backlash last year: there had been so much written about it, and my first attempts to learn it on BSW were less than stellar. The theme of creating postal routes felt forced and uninteresting. Role selection has become a common component of Euro games, so it didn't feel novel this time around. Still, I collect games which have won the [i]Spiel des Jarhes.[/i] I dutifully picked up a copy.
[i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] finally made it to the table. And WOW! Giddyup, horsies! It really is an awesome game.
First, I think the board is gorgeous. The color palette is wonderfully subdued, the artwork exquisite with pictures of actual historical buildings. A page naming each building is included, and it is a nice touch. I probably butcher the names of most of the towns while playing since they're all German, but the combination of these names plus the board really captures an "old world" feel. The cards are small like those found in [i][gameid=9209][/i], well drawn and richly colored.
[i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] bears more than a passing resemblance to [i][gameid=9209][/i] in other areas as well. You are attempting to complete a route by collecting a set of cards. There are face-up cards on the table from which you can select, or you can draw "blind" from the deck. Unlike [i][gameid=9209][/i], the routes aren't laid out for you. There are roads between towns, but the route you are trying to construct can meander however you see fit within certain limitations. The method of laying out your cards is a novel concept. Each round, you must add to the "route" you are creating, by placing a card on either end of the set of cards you already have in play. In this manner, you extend your route -- but you are also limited in which cities you can use to do so. If you don't have any cards which represent cities connected to the cards on the end of your route, then you have to scrap your route and start over. This can be a severe setback. You have to adjust your route selection and card draws as appropriate.
Since you can't be locked out of a particular link, some of the "push your luck" from [i][gameid=9209][/i] is missing: you're never stuck waiting for your turn to come around, hoping that no one steals the link from Las Vegas to Los Angeles. This removes some of the tension of [i][gameid=9209][/i], and resulted in a more social experience at the table. There are also several different ways to accumulate points in [i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] which ultimately means different ways to win. I feel as though [i][gameid=9209][/i] has been "solved" as a game: get your big east-west track laid, connect to several cities in the East, then raid the Destinations deck towards the end of the game. Scores in [i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] end up being closer together, so this feeling of being "solved" has yet to set in for me.
The implementation of roles isn't new, and the "powers" these roles impart are pretty straightforward. They essentially grant you an extra action each turn: you can draw an extra card, you can play an extra card, you can refresh all of the face-up cards (an excellent option if you're looking at the possibility of discarding your current route), or else "closing" and scoring a route with some help to make it an appropriate length. These roles take what would normally be a boring set collection game, and effectively add that "wish you could do just one more thing" angst. You can take two cards, but then you'll only be able to play one. You could only take one card and then play two, but then you'll still be one short before you'll be able to score the route. These considerations also provide an extra layer of strategy: how quickly can you gain the cards for a route, play them in sequence, and yet carry the maximum number of cards (three) into your next turn? Careful role selection can help you to find the proper balance.
[i]Thurn & Taxis[/i] is a more open route creation game, removing some of the tension and conflict from [i][gameid=9209][/i], while also providing multiple paths to victory. Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night stays this game from swiftly being a triumph.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=34]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: Thurn and Taxis: All Roads Lead to Rome
Thurn and Taxis: Power and Glory
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/26/08, Rated: 8[/i]
In an ideal world an expansion improves upon the original game. [i]Power and Glory[/i] provides the proof that we do not live in an ideal world. The good news is that [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i] is so fantastic that even though [i]Power and Glory[/i] loses a couple of ratings points, it is still a solid game.
The new map is great, presenting a new challenge to discover an optimal approach. The same old-world coloring which I loved from the first map has been continued here. There are new cards to support the new map. New counters for the new provinces...okay. The colors are the same, but I guess the words on the back need to be changed. And a single, double-sided page to explain the changes to the rules. If you're keeping score, then the only components which are missing are the houses, and it is the houses which are the only shared items from the original game. All in all, this is either a pricey expansion, or else a short-changed standalone game. But if you love your [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i], then this is a small concern at worst.
The big concern is what has been done to the rules. I consider [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i] to be a near-perfect game. The pace of building routes feels just right. Balancing the tension of building longer routes versus the risk of having to abandon one if you cannot play a card is exquisite. Racing for the "7" carriage at the potential risk of still having unused houses is an important consideration. The four special roles offer meaningful abilities. Each of these aspects of the original game are altered or omitted in [i]Power and Glory[/i].
The timing of routes has been prolonged by the introduction of horse teams: you can play a city card face-down next to your carriage to increase the number of horses which are pulling it. You must have an equal or greater number of horses as you have cities in your route. This extra consideration increases the number of turns needed before you can successfully close your route, which I don't think is an improvement.
Being able to play a card in this fashion also reduces the effectiveness of the Administrator: if you cannot extend your route, then you do not have to exchange the cards on display. Instead, you can simply bury a card next to your carriage which removes some of the tension from the original title. The race to the "7 carriage" has been removed, and so has the Cartwright. Combined with the diminished need for the Administrator, there are really only two viable roles between which you will be choosing each round.
[i]Power and Glory[/i] is still a fun game, it just doesn't improve upon the original. It's almost a standalone game which comes up short component-wise. Alternatively, you [i]can[/i] play with the original rules on the new map which is very good, but also pricey just for a new map and cards. If you're a fan of [i][thing=21790]Thurn and Taxis[/thing][/i] then neither of these concerns should stay you from swiftly picking up a copy.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2004[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 6th Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 9/20/05, Rated: 10[/i]
I love this game! Its theme is wonderfully romantic, its concepts are easy to learn, and it looks great while playing. It can be confrontational or not, depending on your preference. My seven year-old son won convincingly in his second game.
But perhaps the most telling is this comment from my wife "I would definitely play that game again!" Any title that has that effect on her should be rated an eleven.
[i]Updated: 12/24/09, Rated: 9[/i]
[i]Ticket to Ride[/i] is still a fantastic gateway game. However, it has reached a point where it feels "solved:" strategically place a couple of key routes (I'll leave the discovery of them up to the reader), and then raid the "tickets" deck. It also ends up being a game where you draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, and draw, trying to push your luck one more turn before finally buying a segment. My wife and her friends still like to play, so this will remain a "9" due to its mass appeal.

Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment:
[b][media=474937]Replayable Episode 1[/media][/b]
[i]Updated: 27 JUN 2024, Rated: 8[/i]
Enough time has gone by without playing this game that returning to it now is jarring. The level of extreme conflict now feels alien, and the idea of bringing this game to the table is both thrilling and anxiety-inducing. Back down to an 8.
[i]Updated: 07 FEB 2009, Rated: 9[/i] {2P: 10, 3P: 9, 4P: 8}
Like a fine wine, [i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i] has gotten better with age and experience. Side note: the analogy [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_wine#Early_history]appears to be appropriate[/url]. After acquiring some perspective on game mechanics by playing many other titles, I was surprised by how refreshingly elegant these rules really are. My old "complaint" about lacking Temple tiles can be mitigated somewhat through strategic development: provide more support for your leaders while limiting the "attach points" for your opponents.
An external conflict provides more of a challenge to defend against, since you typically can't be evenly strong in all four colors. Even if you are building evenly, your opponent can load up in one color to gain an advantage. Tile draws can still make the difference in any conflict, but that fact adds tension to the game.
I'm now a solid fan of [i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i]. The only reason it doesn't deserve a "10" is that I believe the quality of the gameplay tapers off as more players are added. Still, I will play this game at every opportunity.
[i]Posted: 31 JAN 2006, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: 8, 3P: 9, 4P: 7}
I feel like I'm committing some form of BGG heresy by not giving this game a rating of "10." The reputation that this game enjoys makes learning it seem daunting. I strongly recommend playing a game or two online, with people that will take the time to explain the basic moves. After your first game, rules that once seemed fidgety melt away, leaving streamlined elegance.
And for the most part, this game is extremely enjoyable. Somehow the classic Knizia trademark of "too many things to do, too little time to do them" is ever-present, while only having two actions per turn. It's delightfully agonizing, as I keep wishing for [i]just one more action[/i], that I can never have. Position play factors in heavily, so playing the board also is important.
However, the luck of the draw also plays a significant factor, and can undo the strongest play. I've had a virtually impenetrable location undone by someone who drew five tiles of the same color (red), and was able to displace a leader in a crucial position. The old adage about losing the war for want of a nail could be said about [i]Tigris & Euphrates,[/i] only for the want of a Temple.
[i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i] plays decently with two, shines with three, and is a nerve-wracking madhouse with four. The starting positions may as well be marked on the board. It is a wonderful game, and I do enjoy playing it, even if my enthusiasm can be doused by lucky draws.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1999[/b] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1999[/b]
[i]Posted: 9/20/05, Rated: 7[/i] {2P: 7, 3P: 7, 4P: ???}
Since I am a new inductee to "Euro" games, I am always interested to discover a mechanic in a game that is new to me. With [i]Tikal,[/i] that mechanic is found in the way that the tiles are shuffled together. This is the first time that I have seen such a method for adding some structure to a random deck.
I am still learning when it comes to tile placement: sometimes I want the jungle to be very fluid, connecting to as many different spaces as possible so that I can take advantage of my opponents' activities. At other times, I want to make movement very costly, or even block off a portion of the jungle altogether so that my opponents can't benefit from my own efforts. These thoughts can seriously slow down tile placement.
There are four scoring opportunities during the game. When one occurs, each player gets ten "action points" to move her units around the table, capturing treasures or uncovering temples to maximize her score. This process really grinds the game to a halt, as each player attempts to find the optimal actions that score the most points.
Tikal is a very enjoyable game with a great theme. It also offers occasional turns of crushing analysis paralysis (AP), and for this reason I do not think it has been as well received by my family as [i][gameid=9209][/i].

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/12/08, Rated: 7[/i]
How do you add more depth to a game like [i][gameid=2243]?[/i] Change the rolling mechanism and add special roles. Just to be safe, throw in a rotating starting player element, and you have plenty of Eurogame trappings. The end result might not be kingly, but it is fit for a lesser noble. Let's call it "baron-ly."
Reduced to its simplest form, [i]To Court the King[/i] uses dice values to approximate [i][gameid=1115][/i] hands, hence the near universal opinion that it is similar to [i][gameid=2243][/i]. When it's your turn, you roll the dice, and you must keep at least one of them. Not all the dice of a single value, as in [i][gameid=15818][/i], but just one die. Then, reroll the rest until you've either accomplished the goal you've set, or you haven't but you're out of "free dice" to roll.
In either event, you will receive a role placard, from a selection of 8,192 roles. Okay, there really aren't that many roles from which to choose. There are only twenty of them, and they are not created equally. Some roles allow you to roll more dice, while others allow you to "shape" your results by changing the values of your last roll. There is a small learning curve to finding the ones which are more worthwhile. Here's a tip: the game might as well have been called [i]To Court the General[/i]. These roles are present in limited quantities: the ones you like might not be available when its finally your turn. The rotating turn order does reward the last person with two consecutive turns, but sometimes that's a small consolation. The first person to roll 7 of a kind can take the King card and the Queen card. Doing so triggers the end game.
Like many games, [i]To Court the King[/i] is best taught while playing. However, the numerous possible interactions of the roles can appear fidgety to new players, which is a turn-off. Once they understand it, the game is fun and moves quickly. It is a very social experience as you cheer for your opponents or even make suggestions about which roles they should take. If someone told me about a fun, light, strategic dice game, I would have thought them a charlatan. However, [i]To Court the King[/i] does have some noble qualities after all.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=30]BGWS Review[/url]
item.conditiontext: English version by Rio Grande Games © 2006. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Recommendation 2010[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 6/29/10, Rated: 8[/i]
In an age of [thing=36128]deck building[/thing], I was very curious to see how a game could implement a "build a treasure map" mechanic. How would [i]Tobago[/i] provide multiple puzzles to solve if they were being determined as the game progressed? I had to find out. More importantly, I thought the idea was cool.
That's an important detail: I really liked the idea of this game before I ever opened it. I started with a positive bias.
As a result, I was fascinated when I saw how the board can be assembled in theoretically 32 different ways. The iconology for the clues, and the method of constructing the "treasure maps" are brilliantly simple. The moai-esque statue figures are fantastic. The ATV movement feels very similar to the token movement in [i][thing=855]Java[/thing][/i]. The treasure "auctions" are a novel way to distribute points, and players have to balance their contributions to each treasure.
The artwork is highly saturated, and pleasing. I was immediately reminded of two other [company=87]Zoch Verlag[/company] games: [i][thing=15817]Manila[/thing][/i], and [i][thing=13308]Niagara[/thing][/i]; [person=12587]Victor Boden[/person] was the artist for all three titles. I am a fan of his work.
With a few tweaks, [i]Tobago[/i] could be a "9:" first, treasure cards which are not revealed should be discarded without looking at them. If this means a curse card gets into the discard deck, then so be it. Second, unused amulets ought to have some point value, otherwise the whole amulet mechanism feels bolted-on. As is, [i]Tobago[/i] is an enjoyable discovery with a novel concept. It can easily be taught to new players, and that is a treasure indeed.

Too Many Bones: Trollin' 4 Fools! Tyrant Pack
Top Secret Spies
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 1986[/b]
[i]Posted: 5/18/06, Rated: 7[/i]
A seemingly simple game, that becomes more fun after repeated plays with the same group. It's the [i]metagaming[/i] that really enhances the experience.
[i]Top Secret Spies[/i] (the title of the version which I own) is a roll-and-move game with a twist: anyone can move any of the wooden "spies." Roll the die, and then use the number of pips showing as "movement points," which can be distributed however you see fit among all of the spies in play. Some of those spies will secretly belong to a player. Some will not.
The key then is to help your spy to earn the most points without being overt about it. [i][GAMEID=4636][/i] has a similar "hide your side" mechanism. It is a fun idea in theory, and enjoys a little novelty the first few times playing. That novelty wears out.
This is the point where playing with the same people can make [i]Top Secret Spies[/i] that much more interesting: you start trying to second-guess your opponents based upon their behavior in previous games. Has she been avoiding her real agent all this time? Red seems to be creeping up the board, but not being pushed ahead too fast. Maybe that's a clue.
Playing with the cards adds a bit more chaos and interest. The theme is well-suited to the game, and earns an extra point for being engaging and fun. An easy game to teach, and one that my entire family enjoys playing. We prefer playing without the cards, but with the bonus points for correctly guessing the "controller" for each of the agents.
item.conditiontext: [i]Top Secret Spies[/i] English version by Rio Grande Games. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Tragedy Looper
item.wishlistcomment: Played this at BGG.con. Great idea of repeating events to try to glean more information about the crimes. The anime-esque artwork and the darker themes may be a bit of turnoff for some. Being able to play through each scenario only once as a looper is also a bit of a drawback. Still, the looping mechanic is great, and I believe that there will be more scenarios published.

item.name: Trains
item.conditiontext: Complete and in pristine condition. Sleeved.

item.name: Trajan
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 11/14/18, Rated: 8[/i]
My inaugural "first hot game," at the first BGG.con I ever attended (2011). Played again seven years later at BGG.con 2018. And I had forgotten how good the game was.
I really like the Mancala mechanism of distributing resources and then the final one defining the action you will take. There's an elegant trade off between small moves (1-2 resources, which then become time steps) versus large ones: the small ones are very controllable and give you more opportunities for actions each age, while the big moves accelerate the end of the age.
The various tracks are still opaque to me as to which one is the best. What I have learned is that I can't invest in all of them equally; you definitely need to pick your battles and then invest. From there, see if you can manage the Mancala cadence to do well there. A good brain puzzle that I would like to spend more time with.
item.wishlistcomment: Played this at BGG.con, and I think I really like it. The Mancala/rodel mechanism is unique, and I finally started getting the hang of it towards the end of the game.
