UPDATE: Played this at BGG.con, and it was great!

item.name: Transformers Armada: Battle for Cybertron
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/16/06, Rated: 5[/i]
Both of my sons love [i]Transformers[/i], and I picked up this game a couple of years ago because of that theme alone. As far as Transformers go, I personally prefer the [i]Armada[/i] storyline to the subsequent [i]Energon[/i] and current [i]Cybertron[/i] incarnations, so I like the theme of this game, too.
It has a fixed card-deck component. This game was never intended to be a collectible card game (CCG) with booster packs; rather each character has his own deck of cards. The board is almost vestigial. The rules on line of sight are easy enough to understand, but once two characters have closed in on each other, it is almost impossible to escape by rolling the die and moving away. Thus the entire game comes down to lucky draws and smart plays -- similar to a real CCG.
The figures are in action poses, and come pre-painted, although they are not on a scale that would be compatible with the toys. Eight characters are provided. And perhaps because their card decks are different, some matchups are very lopsided. Megatron is almost impossible to beat one-on-one. Smokescreen versus Starscream is heavily tilted towards the Autobot (see my session report to this effect). Once these matchups are known (or sometimes even suspected), the game loses some of its luster.
[i]Transformers: Armada[/i] is a fun enough experience if you bring some of your own enthusiasm to the table. Lacking that self-motivation, this game is probably one to avoid.
item.conditiontext: Milton Bradley © 2003. Complete and in good condition.

It's a deduction game with a bluffing element and a pirate theme. It's not a "social deduction" game because you're not trying to figure out players' roles. Instead, you're looking for treasure. I love the way that you draw on the board with a ruler and a compass; it's very reminiscent of my work with charts in the Navy. Very interested in this one.

Strummed the 18xx chord even though this game is obviously a different, much lighter offering.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Baby Boomer Edition
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/15/05, Rated: 3[/i]
For the purposes of this game, a "baby boomer" is a person who was born (and presumably grew up) in the United States following the end of World War 2, up until the late 50's. You're not going to do well at this version of [i][gameid=2952][/i] if you aren't one, unless you're an extreme affecionado of that time period. I am neither.
When this version was originally released, it was very popular and therefore hard to come by. My parents wanted it, and we scoured the stores until we found it. For that reason, I've held on to this copy. But playing [i][gameid=2952][/i] with questions I can't answer is a dismal way to spend time.
[i]Updated: 9/16/05, Re-rated: 2[/i]
Given my equal rating of "3" for the [i][gameid=11628][/i], I need to show my disdain for this version. My kids can't answer the [i]Young Players[/i] questions, but at least I can. [i]Baby Boomer Edition[/i] is an exercise in futility.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/15/05, Rated: 5[/i]
[i]Trivial Pursuit[/i] was almost impossible to find when it was first released. The player markers' ability to hold the now infamous "pie pieces" was a novel idea. It was (and still can be) a fun social game.
Its problems include the amount of downtime that is created for the players who aren't moving. This condition is exacerbated if the moving player knows a bunch of (let's admit it) useless trivia. The board also becomes very repetitious: "I rolled a '3,' so I roll again. A '4,' roll again." Once you're working those spaces, 67% of the rolls either have you rolling again or answering a question for a pie piece.
The other drawback to the game is that it lacks longevity. Once the questions start to be repeated, it loses its novelty. You could extend the experience by purchasing the "booster pack" editions, but by this time you're probably burned out on [i]Trivial Pursuit[/i] in general.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Star Wars Classic Trilogy Collector's Edition
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 3/6/05, Rated: 4[/i]
I truly enjoy [i]Trivial Pursuit - Star Wars Classic Edition.[/i] My problem is that when I am playing, no one else does. I don't make claims to being an übergeek, but I am the most knowledgeable among my circle of friends.
The game itself looks good. The pewter figures have some nice detail, but they are also very soft. This is not a game that you will want to play with children, if you value keeping your tokens intact. The R2-D2 figure that is a random number generator takes too long for its series of annoying beeps to end, and to display the "roll."
The questions are many and varied. There is a category that basically is a grab bag of miscellaneous items, many of which are drawn from the disastrous TV shows of the time. If you have a group of fanatical Star Wars friends, then this game will be a lot of fun. If not, then this game will spend a lot of time on the shelf, wistfully waiting for someone to challenge you, the Star Wars trivia Jedi.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Young Players Edition Master Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/22/05, Rated: 3[/i]
In principle, a young player's edition makes a lot of sense. It should allow children an opportunity to be competitive with adults. I felt this statement was true when as a child, I would play this version with my mom. Now, when I attempt to play it with my own children, I realize how temporal of an edition this really is.
If you were a child or a young adult in 1984, then you know all of these answers. If you're a child now, you have little hope of getting them right. My boys do better with the [i][GAMEID=1297][/i].

item.name: Troyes
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/10/112, Rated: 7[/i]
The experience of learning a new game greatly influences the likelihood that you will want to return to it. Returning to a game grants you additional perspective to judge it. I learned [i]Troyes[/i] at BGG.con '11, and was taught by a long time Internet friend and fellow Werweolf player seanp. I [i]wanted[/i] to like the game.
The theme and artwork are very pleasing: I think the game looks [i]good.[/i] Dealing role cards to the different buildings enforces variation between games, and thus provides replayability: there is no scripted opening, here. Being able to modify dice values, and to purchase dice from other players results in many player options. Lastly, variable and hidden bonus conditions make it more difficult to evaluate those options.
The result is that [i]Troyes[/i] turns out to be very "thinky" for a game that uses dice as a resource. It is difficult to plan ahead for your turn, as the dice you want to buy may not be available by the time you're ready to play. The games moves more slowly than it should. This feeling may be mitigated when playing with experienced players.
Dice manipulation games have seen a resurgence. After having played many of them including [i][thing=43249]The BoardGameGeek Game[/thing][/i], [i][thing=55670]Macao[/thing][/i], and [i][thing=84876]The Castles of Burgundy[/thing][/i], I can say that [i]Troyes[/i] is the heaviest. If you expect dice games to be light, then you will be unhappy. If you expect medium weight games to eschew dice, then you will also be unhappy. When played with the right group, it is an enjoyable time even if it does feel a little long for what it is, but then again that could be said of any game. An average sentiment earns an average rating.

item.name: Troyes: The Ladies of Troyes
item.comment: Another shining example of a game or expansion that was eventually reprinted!

item.name: Tuareg
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/11/12, Rated: 5[/i]
[i]Tuareg[/i] is an attractive game in an even more attractive (read: very space-conscious) package. The theme is standard enough: you are a desert nomad, trading in various wares. There are two phases, and at the end of each the player with the most cards of each ware earns points. Nothing really new here.
There are some special cards (Donkey, Cave, Thief, and Map). Each provides its own situational benefit. The Donkey allows you to load more wares. The Cave allows you to "hide" up to two cards (note: once a card has been stashed in the Cave, it remains there until the phase ends -- be careful!). The Thief allows you to steal a card from another player, and the Map is worth two points.
Realistically, the game feels very scripted. Since cards are loaded in plain view, you can tell who has a majority in a given ware, and [i]there are no points for second place.[/i] I believe this oversight is [i]Tuareg's[/i] biggest shortcoming. Lading space is precious, so taking a card to deny another player points when I cannot achieve a majority hurts me more than the other player -- that's a space I could have used to strengthen my own position in a ware I could score. The Thief is a potential solution, but only if people have been collecting relatively evenly [i]and[/i] there is a ware on top -- you can't steal a ware from the middle or from the bottom of a loaded pile.
The map is somewhat interesting as a point-recovery mechanism: if I have several cards of a type for which I will not score any points, then I can at least use them to buy a map and secure two points. Still, going to the market and finding another card which supports a majority I do have is worth at least three points, so that's likely to be a better route to take.
The artwork is good enough to support the theme, and the entire game fits into a box the size of a standard card deck. Lastly, the game plays quickly, so as a light, themed filler [i]Tuareg[/i] is adequate.
item.conditiontext: Complete and in pristine condition. Sleeved.

item.name: Turing Machine
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 29 DEC 2022, Rated: 10[/i]
What an amazing accomplishment!
I need to preface this comment with a few disclaimers: I enjoy programming in all of its forms, and I [u]love[/u] cryptography. The concept of this game feels like it is bespoke. I wanted to like it. And yet, I had this nagging concern that setting aside the "punchcard computer" would reveal an otherwise pedestrian game. Was I ever wrong!
The goal is to determine a 3-digit number, with the digits being limited to {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}.
You set up a game of [i]Turing Machine[/i] by selecting [b]verifiers[/b] according to the puzzle's instructions. These are cards that have a logic statement, like "the purple number is odd or even," or "the sum of the blue and yellow numbers with respect to 6." Then you fish out answer cards, which have a 12x12 grid of checkmarks and red x'es. Each verifier has an associated answer card for that puzzle. Now the game begins.
You think of a number -- say, 345 -- and you pull the matching punchcards from the display: a blue 3, a yellow 4, and a purple 5. These punchcards stack on top of each other, and the result is a single hole. Then you choose which verifier you want to use, take its answer card, and place it behind your stack of punchcards. You can see the answer for this setup through the single hole in the punchcards.
You have to wrap your brain around the idea that this result is based on the guess you made, but is relative to the hidden number, the answer to the puzzle. Let's say you chose the verifier that checks the sum of the blue and yellow numbers relative to 6. Using the previous example of 345, 3 + 4 = 7; you are checking to see if the sum of the blue and yellow numbers is greater than 6 since your guess was greater than 6. If you see a green checkmark, then you guessed right! If you see a red X, then you still have gained some information: the sum of the yellow and blue numbers is either equal to 6, or less than 6.
There are 48 verifiers. 48 different logic statements that may be used. And while 20 puzzles come with the game, you can go to the [url=https://turingmachine.info/]website[/url] and generate millions of them. You can also ramp up the difficulty of the puzzles.
I'm having so much fun with this game!
It can be played competitively, with the goal of finding the answer before the other players. This added element creates more of a gaming atmosphere instead of a logic puzzle: if I ask one more question (use one more verifier), then I might tie or even lose. Do I make a guess now, and risk losing? This dynamic feels like publishing theories in [i][thing=161970][/thing][/i], which is another great game.
The programmer in me wants to reverse-engineer the game. Maybe I'll sit down and try to figure it out some day. In the meantime, I'm doing the daily challenge at a minimum. No other game in my collection gets played every day.
item.wishlistcomment: How have I missed this?!? Analog programming? 4C6F7665

item.name: Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 7/25/20, Rated: 10[/i]
Let’s get the compulsories out of the way: this is a big game with a big price tag. It’s possible that there is a halo effect with a dash of self-serving bias as a result (“I want to like this expensive game that I bought!”). I’ll try to be as objective as I can with no guarantees of success.
TLDR: [i]TI4[/i] is incredible! :D
[i]TI4[/i] is a space-based 4X game. You pick one out of a staggering number of races (17) and start out on your home world hex. As the game progresses you will be building up your fleet, expanding to new systems, researching technologies, and probably engaging in combat. The important thing to remember is that the winner is the first player to earn 10 points, and this detail is crucial: there is not a sure fire strategy that will always win.
You may like the idea of “turtling” to build up your resources and then unleashIng hell on the board, but the game may be won by the time you’re ready. Two objectives will be revealed at the start of the game and then one each round thereafter. Early objectives are worth one point each, while later ones will be worth two. You will also receive a secret objective that may be worth one or two points upon its completion, and you can get more. The player that adapts her strategy to completing an objective every round is going to be competitive by the game’s end. If she can complete two objectives every round then she’s likely going to win.
There are at least two other ways to earn points. One is to control a hotly contested planet named “Mecatol Rex” in combination with the drafted action “Imperial.” The other way is through diplomacy, if a point-scoring agenda card is revealed and you can garner enough support. Agendas appear after Mecatol Rex has been captured. These points are much harder to come by. You may occupy Mecatol Rex, but someone grabbed Imperial before you could get it. You might have both, but then get invaded before you can take the Imperial action to earn that point. There are many agenda cards so you might not see a point-scoring one. These point scoring options are boons, not the foundation of a strategy.
This dynamic is the core of the game, and what gives [i]TI4[/i] so much variability! The game isn’t “I’ll always play the Federation of Sol this way,” but rather “How can I adapt my racial strengths to this set of objectives?” I enjoy that challenge immensely, but it took me a few plays to truly understand it. This is a long game, so even saying “three plays to get there” is a significant investment of time.
The production value is top notch. There’s even a great deal of toy value in the quantity of plastic ships that are provided: the game looks epic on the table. There are so many things to like about [i]TI4[/i]. Once you’ve begun to appreciate its true nature and learned how to score points instead of following preconceptions you may have from playing 4X video games like [i]Master of Orion[/i], then hopefully it will be a “10” for you, too.
item.wishlistcomment: I am addicted to space-based 4X games, and this one is the granddaddy of them all. I have TI3 and all of its expansions, and this version is supposed to be streamlined. I'm actually looking forward to comparing and contrasting the two versions!

Ubongo
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/4/08, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: 8, 3P: 8, 4P: 9}
At first blush, here is yet another game which looks an awful lot like [i]Tetris[/i]. This style of game has been done before with [i][gameid=2453][/i], and to a lesser extent with [i][gameid=6411][/i]. However, peeking under the mask reveals a different take on the puzzle genre.
In [i]Ubongo[/i], each player gets her own set of puzzle pieces, and plays them on her own card each round. This isn't a directly-competitive game where pieces can block each other. Instead, it is a race to see who can fill all of the spaces on his card first, using the prescribed pieces as determined by a die roll. A sand timer is provided to keep the game moving briskly.
There is a scoring mechanism bolted onto the puzzling. It feels disconsonant at first, but after a small number of plays it makes perfect sense. It also provides an incentive to finish first, as the added mobility it provides can be crucial to enhancing your score.
[i]Ubongo[/i] is at its best when played with the full complement of four. It has been a solid hit with every person to whom I have introduced it. We have given copies as a house-warming gifts, and it has been requested by friends visiting from out of town. Spear yourself a copy while you still can.

item.name: Ubongo 3-D
item.wishlistcomment:
Anything worth doing, is worth over-doing. [i][thing=16986]Ubongo[/thing][/i] has been a sure-fire hit with everyone to whom I have introduced it. [i][thing=6411]Rumis[/thing][/i] not so much. Word at BGG.con 2012 was that this game is not like [i][thing=6411]Rumis[/thing][/i], and is definitely worth finding.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 1999[/SIZE][/COLOR] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 1999[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 5/14/06, Rated: 10[/i]
I arrived at [i]Union Pacific[/i] after having fallen in love with [i][gameid=9209][/i]. Yes, yes, I know that [i]Union Pacific[/i] is a re-release of an earlier game. I never played [i][gameid=43][/i]. I also acknowledge that I'm probably drawing some structurally unsound conclusions by saying that several parts of [i][gameid=9209][/i] were inherited from [i]Union Pacific:[/i] the little plastic trains, the similar map with marked spaces, a limited number of routes between cities, card "drafting" in the form of having four face-up cards in addition to the face-down deck. To me, [i]Union Pacific[/i] feels like [url=http://www.geekdo.com/boardgamedesigner/9/alan-r-moon]Alan R. Moon's[/url] first attempt to refine the formula that would eventually lead to winning the [i]Spiel des Jahres[/i] with [i][gameid=9209][/i].
[i]Union Pacific[/i] is by far the more strategically-challenging game. And where [i][gameid=9209][/i] can be confrontational, [i]Union Pacific[/i] can foster a sense of pure r{[b]betrayal[/b]}r. Do I go for a majority shareholding position in a single, giant railroad? Should I opt for seeking out uncontested dominance in smaller companies?
Should I let someone else build a behemoth, all the while collecting the shares I need to steal it out from under her? [i]Delicious.[/i]
The game board offers another interesting challenge: reaching a strategic junction can make a big difference in a railroad's ability to grow. Collecting the proper track cards to foster that growth is also important. All of these decisions are intertwined beautifully.
Every person (read: non-hardcore gamer) with whom I have shared [i][gameid=9209][/i] has loved it. That fact combined with its easy, colorful gameplay earned it a score of "10." However, I like [i]Union Pacific[/i] better, even though it is not as accessible. I love to play them both, but I'd secretly prefer to pull out [i]Union Pacific[/i] first.
[i]Updated: 12/24/09, Rated: 10[/i]
[i][gameid=9209][/i] has been taken down a notch. [i]Union Pacific[/i] now stands alone as the superior [url=http://www.geekdo.com/boardgamedesigner/9/alan-r-moon]Alan R. Moon[/url] train game I believe it to be!
[i]Updated: 2/6/15, Rated: 8[/i]
Five years later, the luster has faded from [i]Union Pacific[/i]. As a train-and-stock game, it feels flat in comparison to the 18xx series of games ([i][thing=17405][/thing][/i] in particular). During a dividend round, you don't get paid for each of your shares. Share prices can't fall, although the potential value of your set can increase as the railroad builds more connections. The ability to invest many shares of the same stock at one turn can be disconcerting.
I still enjoy [i]Union Pacific[/i], but now I see the randomness of share draws being a limitation instead of a benefit. And in that light, I think that [i][gameid=9209][/i] is now the better game between the two.

item.name: UNO: SpongeBob SquarePants
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/7/05, Rated: 5[/i]
Standard [i]UNO,[/i] with Spongebob characters on every card (always a good thing). The "version specific" card is called "Super Absorbency." It is a wild card, and has the following effect: when played, the player with the least number of cards must take one card at random from the hand of the player sitting to her left, one card at random from the player to her right, and one card from the top of the deck.
In play, this card is actually a nice addition to the base game! It provides a clean way to force the game leader to pick up cards, even if that person is not sitting next to you. It also doesn't have any restrictions associated with it, like a "Draw 4" card has.
[i]UNO[/i] is a relatively benign game for a hand or two, particularly with children. And they're the audience at whom this variant is "squarely" aimed.

Villa Paletti
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jarhes 2002[/b] [color=#959595][size=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 4th Place 2002[/size][/color]
[i]Posted: 1/6/09, Rated: 6[/i] {2P: 6, 3P: 6, 4P: 7}
[i]Villa Paletti[/i] has taken a lot of grief for having won the [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/url][/i] in 2002, but I can see why it did. It's brightly-colored: high color saturation is a common theme amongst recent winners. It's simple to learn -- another requirement. It also earns a full set of marks for introducing a new mechanism which hasn't been done in previous winners: it's a dexterity game. Had [gameid=2452] won in a previous year, then [i]Villa Paletti[/i] wouldn't have had a chance.
The detail that really surprises me is that it was considered for the [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Deutscher_Spiele_Preis]Deutscher Spiele Preis[/url][/i]. I think of that prize as being more of a "gamer's game," which usually means it is more robust and intricate than the winner of the SdJ. Yet here is a simple game which was highly regarded by both panels. So what's the deal here?
[i]Villa Paletti[/i] is a quirky-looking game. The "floors" look like they were conceived as set pieces for a Tim Burton movie. The resultant structures they produce look fantastical and absurd. Where most games focus on the accumulation of points or progress towards an end goal, here the journey itself is the game. [i]Villa Paletti[/i] does a good job of looking fun along the way. For this reason alone I sought out the Zoch Verlag version of the game, rather than the University Games one.
The game is ornate filler at best. It is most enjoyable when all four colors belong to actual players, rather than using the kludge of a rule of having neutral colors that must also be moved during a player's turn. At the same time, it's not really a "party" game because it can't support more than four players. Thus, [i]Villa Paletti[/i] falls into a no-mans land within my collection: there are other 4p games I'd rather play, yet it doesn't scale to be considered for larger groups.
An expansion which added new floor shapes and different-colored pillars to support more players would build up my rating for this game.

item.name: The Voyages of Marco Polo: The New Characters
Walnut Grove
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 2/15/12, Rated: 8[/i]
By the time you're reading this comment, you've undoubtedly seen previous reviewers say that [i]Walnut Grove[/i] is "[i][thing=31260]Agricola[/thing][/i]-lite meets [i][thing=822]Carcassonne[/thing][/i]." I can understand that sentiment. [person=11507]Klemens Franz[/person] has a very distinctive, pleasing style that is seen in most (all?) of [company=234]Lookout Games'[/company] titles. Plus, you're playing the role of a farmer, so there is that connection as well.
As for the similarity to [i][thing=822]Carcassonne[/thing][/i]: you draw tiles randomly from a bag. I know, I know: there is also a worker placement element that hearkens back to the meeples in [i][thing=822]Carc[/thing][/i], but here your workers only stay on their tiles for a season. The method of building out your player board feels more like [i][thing=27173]Vikings[/thing][/i] to me, or if I get into the wayback machine, like a micro version of [i][thing=4099]Keythedral[/thing][/i]. I can't begrudge commentators from making the more ubiquitous connection.
With all of the obligatory name drops out of the way, how does [i]Walnut Grove[/i] play? Objectively speaking, it feels scripted. The game boils down to your ability to exploit available bonuses, and the luck of the tile draw. Let me be more specific. In the Spring you draw tiles from the bag. Most of the time, you will only add one to your board. Each tile depicts two or three different terrain types. If you are fortunate enough to draw compatible pieces -- especially early on in the game -- then you will have an advantage in gathering resources. Knowing this is important can and should influence your decision about which tiles to keep.
Worker placement happens in the summer. You place your pawns on the contiguous regions which you want to harvest. One type of resource will offer a bonus if harvested this round, and thus presents you with the second scripted influence: If at all possible, you want to harvest that resource and receive its bonus. There's a similar bonus available in the Fall, but it's not as compulsory as the Summer bonus unless you're taking that specific town action.
The town is a rondel-like path lined with buildings which can be activated. This is the one opportunity for players to interact with each other as they vie for individual spaces. Pick your favorite game for an analogy of this mechanic: [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i], [i][thing=35677]Le Havre[/thing][/i], more recently [i][thing=50750]Belfort[/thing][/i], etc. You only have one pawn to place during this season, and competition can be fierce. Winter brings an attrition mechanism to cull resources from the game, and then you start over with Spring. Wash, rinse, and repeat for a total of eight rounds.
By the way, the one town option which offers a bonus in the Fall is selling your goods for coins. You can earn an extra coin if you sell the type of good depicted on the round marker. Coins are drawn at random from a bag, and have victory point values from 0 to 2. It's like the worst part of [i][thing=30869]Thebes[/thing][/i], only not quite so bad because the amount of effort required to draw from the bag is much, much less. In fact, there's a potential churn element to coins: they can be used as "wild" resources in certain situations, allowing you to get rid of the copper coins (value: 0) and keep more valuable resources to use later.
With all of that said, [i]Walnut Grove[/i] sounds like a pretty dry offering, right? Here's the thing: it simply [i]works[/i]. It has that one intangible element of [i]fun.[/i] It is really a resource management game, where the acquisition of resources is easy to understand. The random tile draw adds uncertainty and anxiety, but usually offers enough options to get by. The game moves briskly, and a four-player game can be concluded in 30-45 minutes. It feels meaty without being overly thinky, and it has an attractive appearance. I'm definitely looking forward to teaching this game to others.
item.wishlistcomment:
Played at BGG.con 2011. Wonderful game, although my experience was highly susceptible to bad tile draws, which in turn was influenced by turn order. More plays are needed to appreciate truly viable strategies.

WarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/2/10, Rated: 7[/i]
[family=4750]The Warcraft PC series[/family] is one of my all-time favorites. In fact, I could simplify that statement by saying that I heart all things [company=11812]Blizzard[/company]. They are the only remaining software developer that won't release a game until it's ready, and I have eagerly sampled their adapted wares as well. Getting this game was a no-brainer. Furthermore, I am fond of letting you know when I want to like a game: I figure such infatuation is likely to creep into my comments, so in the interests of full disclosure I let you know.
Now, a hallmark of a great Real Time Strategy (RTS) game is the balance between developing infrastructure versus the execution of military strategy. This balance is ever elusive, and made even more exquisitely agonizing in the crucible of a timed conflict. If you're not as efficient as your opponent, then you're probably going to lose. But board games in general are turn-based affairs: you do your thing, thinking about each and every nuance, and then I'll do mine. What do you get when you attempt to translate the hurried chaos of RTS into the calculated environment of turn-based play?
The answer is fruit salad: it doesn't really work well. [i]Warcraft: The Boardgame[/i] does a decent job of translating the mechanics from PC to the table: I can see the balance of training workers and fighting units, adding buildings, and buying upgrades. A game in progress "flows" across the map like the PC game, with Outposts enabling a "proximity build:" your units can be deployed closer to your enemy's strongholds if you can build and defend an Outpost. These are all Good Things. But the time pressure element is missing, and the game suffers for it. Without it, turns can drag on as players carefully consider the consequences of every possible action.
That's fine if the resource gathering and conflict resolution elements are completely predictable, as they are in [i][thing=875]Roads & Boats[/thing][/i], or in a more approachable extent in [i][thing=19600]Antike[/thing][/i]: careful planning is rewarded in each of those titles. In [i]Warcraft: The Boardgame[/i] these elements are randomly determined. That's a problem. I might not be able to build as quickly if I don't roll as well as my opponent in the "Harvest" phase. I may have to expand more quickly than I would prefer if my mines and forests are depleted early. The delays introduced by a turn-based system exacerbate this randomness: games can drag on even after they've passed the "tipping point" of player development.
The answer of course, is simple: use a timer. A standard chess clock suffices for a 2 player game. Give each player 2'30" to 3'00" cumulatively for all of her phases in a round. Stop the clock to resolve battles. Now the pressure is back on. If I linger to contemplate my moves, then I may not have enough time to complete all of my desired "Spend" activities. I may rush, and forget to Harvest with a worker. Suddenly I'm making snap decisions, and making mistakes. More importantly, [i]the game is moving quickly[/i]. If I don't roll well, then I won't have to wait long for it to be over.
Things get even more convoluted if you have more than two players. I have a G8 Timer, which can be programmed to accommodate up to eight players in a game. It's a godsend in this exact situation: Using a timer, the game jumps up to an easy "8!" However, we are now adding items which weren't originally designed into, or provided with the game. Players shouldn't have to go out and acquire an obscure gaming accessory in order to get their full measure of enjoyment from a game.
The remaining complaints about this title are double-edged: Yes, each faction feels similar because the wide variety of units in the computer games have been distilled down to three archetypes. Since I zealously played the video games, I call each unit by its proper name: Grunt, Footman, Ghoul, or Druid (silly Night Elves don't have a "proper" melee unit from their "Barracks" equivalent). This mental knowledge provides me with a layer of differentiation, but again I'm bringing something extra to the board game which wasn't designed into it.
[i]Warcraft: The Boardgame[/i] is a serviceable adaptation for the new initiate. I'm sure there are other games that will more effectively scratch that "battle" itch. For the Blizzard enthusiast who loves this world, and who can also bring a flexible timing solution along for the ride, then it's a blast. I'll split the difference between the respective "6" and "8" scores this game situationally deserves, and call it a "7."

item.name: Web of Power
item.comment:
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 7th Place 2000[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 3/20/06, Rated: 9[/i]
Area control (AC) with cards. I ought to be cringing at this point; see my comments for [i][thing=199]Manhattan[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=1041]San Marco[/thing][/i]. I like AC games, but traditionally they have included too much random chance to really win me over.
Until now.
[i]Web of Power[/i] is an awesome "little" game. I say "little," because the number of things you can do each turn is actually quite limited. You can take a maximum of two actions during your turn. The rules feel a little fidgety on first learning. Stick with it, and the rough edges fade into a beautiful mosaic of strategic options. The game definitely has the "it" factor: the sit on the edge of your seat, watching with nerve-wracking impatience, hoping for the right play to still be available. When it's your turn, you would love to be able to take [i]three[/i] actions, instead of only two.
The right move may be preventing your opponents from an easy score, trying to get a little slice of the action for yourself in a province, or a daring play in the hopes of winning a superiority in Advisors.
The total number of Advisors (from all players) that can be placed in a province is equal to the greatest number of Cloisters in the same province that are owned by any [i]single[/i] player. This limitation really adds a lot of tension towards the end of the game. The trick is to position yourself to gain the lead in cloisters by placing just one of them, and with your remaining point to place an Advisor. Most of the time, you find yourself one behind the leader in number of cloisters, wishing for that third move. Beautifully agonizing!
Proper hand management is important. The presence of two face-up cards next to the draw pile, along with the ability to turn in two matched cards as a wild card definitely reduces the amount of luck needed to win. In my opinion, these features alone make [i]Web of Power[/i] a superior AC game over [i][thing=1041]San Marco[/thing][/i] or [i][thing=199]Manhattan[/thing][/i]. Good draw pile control is perhaps even more important: you want to be able to bring the game to an end on your terms.
I haven't played [i][thing=18100]China[/thing][/i] yet, but if it is similar to [i]Web of Power[/i], then you should give it a try, at least online. It's a fun, relatively fast title that takes a simplified version of the Area Control formula, and produces a real gem of a game.

item.name: Wingspan
item.comment:
[b][media=484339]Replayable Episode 4[/media][/b]
[i]Posted: 28 JUN 2024, Rated: 8[/i]
This game feels like a lighter version of [i][thing=167791][/thing][/i] with tighter theme integration. The mechanisms make sense: birds eat food, birds lay eggs, birds have more birds. I even love the fact that it comes with a dice tower shaped like a birdhouse!
And while I love rolling dice, the one drawback is the dice drafting mechanism. Some players are going to get lucky and be able to select their desired food types, while you're still trying to limp to a reroll (and then hoping to see the ones you want). Other than that, this game is amazing.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Adventure Game
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 4/5/11, Rated: 6[/i]
We're big fans of [i][thing=17223]World of Warcraft: The Boardgame[/thing][/i], so I was excited when I picked up [i]The Adventure Game[/i] on sale. Familiar character names, faces, and powers greeted us as we set it up. We were a little disappointed in the number of classes present, but I would later discover that more were available as add-ons.
The first thing that felt wrong was the lack of faction enforcement: any character can travel to Undercity, not just Horde. Furthermore, there really isn't any feeling of "development" in this game: you draw your ability cards, and you get what you get. You don't choose to specialize in a specific "build," which makes your character's abilities predictable.
I am looking forward to exploring the other character classes, but I'm not sure that this game will ultimately have anywhere near the appeal of its larger sibling.

Still, this one would be nice to have.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
YINSH
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 1/24/06, Rated: 9[/i]
I'm definitely in the honeymoon phase with [i]Yinsh[/i]. The rules are clean and simple, without any of the "oops" scenarios like [i]en passant[/i] in [i][thing=171]Chess[/thing][/i]. The pieces seem to be well-made, although the board itself feels a bit off. I think it's because the finish has been left as some sort of paper, without any lamination or coating whatsoever. Any drink spilled on it will quickly be absorbed.
The game starts out feeling a lot like [i][thing=2389]Othello[/thing][/i], but quickly distances itself from that weaker entry by your ability to flip the markers of your own color to that of your opponent. The ability of rings to act as blockers as well as "row guarantors" is very interesting.
I play this game with my seven year-old son, who absolutely loves it. That recommendation in and of itself ought to be deserving of such a robust score, and [i]Yinsh[/i] deserves every point. I look forward to future plays and exploring its depths of strategy more fully.
item.conditiontext: Don & Co version © 2003. Complete and in pristine condition.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 8/7/11, Rated: 8[/i] {2P: ???, 3P: 8, 4P: ???}
[i]Yspahan[/i] has been an unplayed game in my collection for over a year now. When I'm looking to teach a new game to my family, I usually sort on Board Game Rank. Finally [i]Yspahan[/i] rose to the top, and we got it to the table. I remember hearing a lot of buzz about the game, and was interested to see what it was like.
To my surprise, there were dice! I'm always excited to see dice in a "Eurogame," because typically they represent too much chaos for that fare. The extended result is that when you do find them, their contribution has been implemented in an interesting way. In [i]Yspahan[/i], the dice control the access to resources or locations. I enjoyed this mechanic better than the resources in [i][thing=55670]Macao[/thing][/i], but not as much as the risk mitigation [i][thing=34635]Stone Age[/thing][/i].
The ability to invest in special powers may have been interesting in 2006, but it is pretty commonplace in 2011. This is another byproduct of the "cult of the new:" if you're not playing a game close to its release, then any innovations it may have introduced (and I'm not saying that [i]Yspahan[/i] innovated at all) will have had more time to be copied.
With three players, it's hard to find a reason to mess with your opponents versus optimizing your own play. My understanding may change as we further explore this game. I loved the camel meeples, and the artwork is richly saturated and pleasing. [i]Yspahan[/i] can be a fast playing game, with just enough complexity to be intriguing, but not so much as to cause analysis paralysis. In other words, it's a satisfying game to play with the family, and that's always a plus.
[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=65]BGWS Review[/url]

item.name: ZÈRTZ
item.comment:
[i]Posted: 5/13/06, Rated: 8[/i]
My first foray into the [i]Gipf[/i] project was with [i][GAMEID=7854],[/i] which I absolutely adored. I discovered that I enjoyed new abstract games, and wanted to try another. I labored over the decision as to which title I should buy next. [i]ZÈRTZ[/i] emerged as the winner.
The "rings" in [i]ZÈRTZ[/i] don't provide the same tactile and visual pleasure as those found in [i][GAMEID=7854],[/i] but the marble-looking balls do. It is easy to believe that they are members of the same family.
Like [i][GAMEID=2083][/i], if you have a capturing oppornity, you [i]must[/i] take it. Unlike that other game, in [i]ZÈRTZ[/i] players use all of the balls indiscriminately; there is no concept of "mine" and "yours." Therefore [i]ZÈRTZ[/i] is all about looking ahead, sacrificing pieces in order to force your opponent into a losing exchange.
I now have a confession to make to you: I [i]wanted[/i] to like this game. I really, really did.
That's not to say that it's a bad game -- it most certainly isn't bad at all -- but it also means that I was willing to put up with a lot of frustration when I didn't "get it" right out of the box. It was very hard for me to develop the right "vision" for this game. Who am I kidding? It's still a challenge. But at least now it is starting to click. [url=http://www.scat.demon.co.uk/zertz/strategy.htm]Steven Tavener's strategy guide[/url] has been immensely helpful in this respect.
[i]ZÈRTZ[/i] is an enjoyable game. My two sons are having fun learning it. Despite its initial difficulty, it is proving to be another winning entry from the [i]Gipf[/i] project. Now, which one should I buy next...

Zooloretto
item.comment:
[b]Spiel des Jahres 2007[/b] [COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 5th Place 1998[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[i]Posted: 2/21/10, Rated: 8[/i]
[i][thing=5782]Coloretto[/thing][/i] is a staple of a game. It can be easily taught, and it travels well. New gamers are intrigued by its novel card drafting mechanism where players don't keep cards they draw, but rather place them into sets on the table for someone else to consider. [i]Zooloretto[/i] obviously bears some similar traits (heh, "bears"), but it wasn't compelling enough for me to try until it won the [i][geekurl=/wiki/page/Spiel_des_Jahres]Spiel des Jahres[/geekurl][/i]. I collect the games which win that award, so I dutifully picked up a copy. Once I got past the sickeningly cute picture of the baby panda -- quite possibly the most over-marketed, and yet still overpowering animal archetype on the planet, like a furry Heidi Klum -- I found a very enjoyable game.
The odd thing is that I knew of [person=86]Michael Schacht[/person]. I consider [i][thing=491]Web of Power[/thing][/i] to be one of the finest Area Control games ever. [i][thing=8989]Hansa[/thing][/i] is well constructed even if it's not compelling. I shouldn't have been surprised when [i]Zooloretto[/i] offered a quality experience. The drafting mechanism from [i][thing=5782]Coloretto[/thing][/i] is still present: each turn, a player has an option of drawing a tile and then placing it as part of a set on a "truck" for the other players to evaluate, or else selecting a truck without drawing a tile. Side note: the racks don't look like "trucks," which is mildly disappointing. And if that's all there was to the game, then it would essentially be the same as [i][thing=5782]Coloretto[/thing][/i].
[i]Zooloretto[/i] stands apart due to a simple, yet clever monetary system that has been layered on top. Coins allow a player to expand her zoo, to swap creatures between exhibits and her barn, and even to purchase animals from her opponents. Coins can be gained as tiles, by filling an entire animal enclosure, or when a player buys an animal from you. What this additional system really does for you is create opportunities to postpone making a decision between drawing a tile or taking a truck. If you don't want to advance another player's cause on your turn by creating a perfect set he could take then you may be able to delay, forcing him to create a better set for you.
This constant balance between draw, choose, or delay makes [i]Zooloretto[/i] a much more satisfying game. Each move is significant. The artwork is attractive and highly saturated. The theme is very family friendly. It's almost sickeningly sweet, which is a drawback for me, but then there's that baby panda that always draws me back in. If it included baby koalas as well, then [i]Zooloretto[/i] would be unstoppable.
